PROCTEXT.PARA: COMMONWEALTH OF AUSTRALIA
PARLIAMENTARY DEBATES
SENATE
Hansard
FIRST SESSION OF THE THIRTY-SEVENTH PARLIAMENT
(SIXTH PERIOD)

PARA.TAB: The Senate, on 8 December 1994, adjourned to 31 January 1995, unless the President fixed an earlier day of meeting.
Pursuant to the Resolution of the Senate passed on 8 December 1994, the Senate met on Tuesday, 31 January 1995 at 2.00 p.m.
The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave—I inform honourable senators that Mr John Howard has been elected Leader of the Liberal Party, and he will lead the coalition to success at the next election. I take this opportunity to put on record our thanks to his predecessor, Alex Downer, for his very significant contribution to our party.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to a third generation logging contractor possibly sitting in the Senate today wondering whether he will have any work when he returns to Wandandian tomorrow. He has 25 employees, $3 million worth of equipment and is typical of seven or eight other logging contractors servicing six timber mills between Nowra and Bega. I ask the minister: does he realise that each one percentage point increase in interest rates costs that man and his business an estimated $10,000 and that the government has forced up official interest rates by 58 per cent in the last five months? Does the minister also realise how his government's confused logging policy is adding uncertainty to that logging contractor's business? What does the minister say to that particular logging contractor about the government's intention to now impose a so-called carbon tax, which will simply be a further tax on the fuel that this contractor needs to run a profitable business? I ask the minister: how does the government expect Australian businesses to survive, let alone prosper, with such foolish and confused policies?

—There is nothing confusing about the government's position so far as logging is concerned. The Prime Minister's statement was a straight down the line recognition of the reality that there are two major competing interests in issue in this country—the issue that is of deep concern to a very large number of members of the community about saving native forests and which not only is a matter for the Commonwealth government and its export woodchips policy but also is very much a matter, so far as the logging itself is concerned, of the responsibility of state govern ments.

PARA.TAB: It is about time people woke up to the fact that the basic responsibility for determining the future of this industry—whether it does or does not survive, or in what form or to what extent it survives—is very much a matter for the state governments. You put some of the heat upon them rather than just upon the Commonwealth. What we have been trying to do as part of the national forest policy strategy is get people together, get a rational assessment of the matters in issue and get a rational balance between not only the interest in the environment and saving native forests but also the interest that is so clearly and starkly there in preserving employment in this country and doing nothing unnecessary to undermine it.

We are acutely conscious of that side of the equation as well as the environmental one. That is why it is such a difficult issue and it is not dealt with sensibly by the kind of noisy malarky we hear from the other side of the chamber on this particular issue. I hope that, if we are going to see a new and sensible approach on policy issues from the other side, we will get a better recognition of the difficulty of drawing this kind of balance in this situation.

As to the question of a carbon tax or any other fiscal policy change that might be involved, that is of course something that is utterly unresolved at this stage. It is the subject of some discussion obviously within the government—as you would expect, given the nature of the fiscal issues that are confronting the country at the moment and the nature of the environmental responsibilities we have—but certainly no decision of any kind has been made, and we are acutely conscious of the employment and the economic implications of going down that path in any very substantial way.

As to the question of interest rates which was also raised, the situation is, of course, that you have to be sensible when an economy is coming out of recession to ensure that the growth that is generated by that is sustainable growth; that when you come to the traffic lights you can keep going, you do not have to come to a shuddering stop. You have to adjust the speed of the economy so the lights are always green, so that you can always keep going. That is why, of course, we have had a series of small changes, small increases in interest rates—to reflect the reality of an economy coming out of recession, surging with growth, surging with capacity.

There is a need accordingly to ensure, particularly given the lead times that are involved in these judgments, that the economy does not move so fast that it is necessary to over correct and produce a stop. That is why interest rates have been rising. The hope, of course, is that the overall situation of the economy, the demand side of the equation, is slowing down. There is some evidence for that. It is to be hoped certainly, as most commentators have been saying, that the nature of the economic situation and the nature of the government's response to it so far, is such that it will not be necessary to go further in any very drastic way down that particular path. That is a matter about which you cannot make premature judgments. Any responsible government recognises that and any responsible opposition should do the same.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is only this minister that would tell Australian business that it can cop a small interest rate increase, which is a 58 percent increase in five months. It just demonstrates how out of touch the government is. The real question is: does the government really understand what its policies are cumulatively doing to Australian business? You are forcing up interest rates; you are now seeking to impose upon them new taxes on production; and, in the case of this particular industry, you have added a confused logging policy. Does this government not understand that small business in particular cannot grow, cannot prosper and cannot employ in that sort of environment? When is this government going to face the realities of what it is doing to Australian business, rather than giving the sort of airy-fairy academic answer that has just been given by the minister today?

—Australian business, big, medium and small, is flourishing immensely more in an environment where, in the last September quarter, growth was running at 6.4 percent, underlying inflation at less than two per cent, and unemployment at under nine percent. They are running immensely more strongly than a time when the current Leader of the Opposition was sitting in the chair producing 10 percent inflation, growth of never more than two or three per cent, and, at the end of his tenure, unemployment of 11 percent. That is the comparison you should be conscious of, and that is what you should recognise so far as this government's achievement is concerned.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, and relates to an industry brief released last week by the Bureau of Industry Economics. This publication outlined that there is extremely strong employment growth in the services sector with some 420,000 jobs being created in service industries over the last two years. Against this background, can the minister advise the Senate of how the manufacturing sector is currently faring and indicate whether it, too, is exhibiting continued growth?

—I should thank Senator Colston for his question because it enables me to give some more and better particulars to the headline answer Senator Evans just gave to the opposition. The figures from a range of various statistical sources on manufacturing performance in Australia make the manufacturing sector in this country the stand-out performer in the Australian economy. Over the last two years, it has seen the strongest ever sustained growth in manufacturing production since the Australian Bureau of Statistics commenced collecting figures. We have done better in the last two years than ever before according to the bureau, which commenced the collection of figures in 1974.

PARA.TAB: Production increased by 12.2 per cent per year to the September quarter of last year. This has taken the surge of production to 12.5 per cent above the record in the June quarter of 1989. We are now at the highest ever level of growth in manufacturing industry production. The manufacturing sector has directly contributed 23.6 per cent of total growth in the Australian economy since 1991. That is an outstanding performance, when one considers that it represents only 16 per cent of gross production.

If one looks at investment as an indicator of future trends, one sees that in this section of the economy investment has been surging and is a foundation for continuing growth. Manufacturing investment went up by 10.3 per cent seasonally adjusted for the September quarter last year. Growth over the last four quarters represents 26.9 per cent—that is the year on growth—a huge amount of investment growth. The bureau's forward surveys suggest that these trends are set to continue.

If one looks at the export performance of this section of the economy, one can see an equally impressive performance. Manufacturing exports have gone up by 9.9 per cent each year in real terms since 1986 and 1987. Elaborately transformed manufactures, the most complex and sophisticated manufactured goods, have gone up the most. They have gone up by 17 per cent per year over the decade, which puts Australia as the best performed country in the OECD in terms of the growth in elaborately transformed manufactures. We now earn $11 billion from the export of elaborately transformed manufactures. We earned $2 billion just over a decade ago. This is set to continue.

The announcement last week by Mitsubishi Motors Australia that it has been selected as a world source for the next generation family sedan car indicates a great deal of confidence in the Australian manufacturing sector, and the Australian automotive sector specifically. Our quality is up, our prices are competitive and design and other inputs put us on the world stage as a leading player. It is evidence, too, that the government's policies in manufacturing development are working. The Button car plan is effective. It is also a compliment to the companies which have performed in this sector, particularly Mitsubishi which has adopted best practice guidelines.

There are two other surveys out which indicate what the future trends will be—the Chamber of Manufactures survey and the ACCI-Westpac survey of industrial trends. They come to these conclusions: strong growth went through in the December quarter; higher production levels were reported; significant increase in production is expected by most of the companies in the field; and profits and investment in plant and equipment are expected to remain high—a strong performing sector in the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Minister, Mr Keating has rejected your list of 1,300 forest compartments which were to be assessed before logging this year. Considering the disruption this debacle is now causing, to what extent have you satisfied yourself that the second list—the Keating list—of 509 compartments are areas of high conservation value which need further evaluation before logging, or have you had a loan of Mrs Kelly's whiteboard?

—As I have indicated, I believe that the decision announced by the Prime Minister in both his statements of 22 December last year and of 27 January this year represents a very balanced outcome on this issue and also a very good result for the environment. The 509 coupes and compartments that Senator Sandy Macdonald asked me about were selected from 1,300 that were covered by my original advice to Mr Beddall, the national estate areas covered by a section 30 advice which was supplied by the Australian Heritage Commission and a very small number for which more recent information has become available. As with my original advice, precedence was given to old-growth forest and wilderness values.

PARA.TAB: The 509 coupes and compartments identified represent those areas considered to be of the highest priority for the protection of their conservation values and/or those areas which could be strategically important for the development of a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system to protect old-growth forest, wilderness and nature conservation values.

Two states, Tasmania and New South Wales, have undertaken an assessment of the original list of 1,300 coupes since my advice was first released. The results of these analyses were taken into account when developing the list of the 509 highest priority areas. The assessment of the 509 coupes has generally resulted in groups—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. We have now had several minutes of a non-responsive answer. The question was: to what extent has the minister satisfied himself that that list of 509 coupes constitutes areas of high conservation value? It is a pretty simple proposition, and the minister has done everything but answer it. Mr President, I ask you to direct him, on the grounds of relevance, to respond to the question.
—There is no point of order; the answer is relevant.

—Thank you, Mr President. The assessment of the 509 coupes has generally resulted in groups of coupes or compartments being set aside which are near the boundaries of existing reserves or which form a geographic entity which could enable areas to be set aside in the future. There are relatively few isolated coupes or compartments.

PARA.TAB: In the time available, it has not been possible to ground truth these assessments. Consequently, a process of verification in consultation with the states will be undertaken. I am not expecting that that verification process will affect many more than just a handful of coupes. I am satisfied that moving to protect the 509 coupes and compartments has struck a—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The minister would be aware of media reports stemming from the recent release of a coalition discussion paper A Clean Australia, which was widely interpreted by rural industry organisations as advocating a compulsory ban on broadacre clearing of land. Can the minister advise the Senate whether the government has considered adopting such a policy?

—I did have a very careful look at what Mr McLachlan put out, as I do with anything that purports to be a contribution to better processes of dealing with land and water degradation in Australia. I have to say—along with the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, who said this on the day that the document came out—that the extraordinary thing about this document is that it is simply a reiteration of programs that the government has already got in place.
—Feeble!

—Really? You obviously haven't read it. Have a look at the entire water management section of it, which simply says that the coalition will continue to implement the initiatives of the Murray-Darling Basin council with one addition—a massive increase in spending.

PARA.TAB: The other part of the paper talks about an extraordinary proposition that the coalition will simply stop all further clearing for agriculture in Australia as a contribution to eliminating greenhouse gases.
Senator West interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very valid point that occurred to me at the time. I am astonished that such a simplistic policy on such an important issue could actually become coalition policy. You will simply stop all further clearing for agriculture in Australia—some members of the National Party might have views about that that they clearly have not been able to express—purely on the basis that it will be a contribution to eliminating greenhouse gases. You can argue validly for stopping clearing or, indeed, for reafforesting the 15 per cent of currently cleared land that has been claimed by the coalition it will reafforest as a habitat for flora and fauna, and for a whole range of other valid reasons. To suggest that that is what you need to do to act as a carbon sink is absolute nonsense which I would dispute absolutely, simply on agronomic grounds.
—Ha!

—You might be pleased to hear this, Senator Kemp. Research in Victoria carried out by the Victorian Department of Conservation and Natural Resources has demonstrated very clearly that soil, properly managed, is capable of sequestering more carbon than trees are. In fact, the solution—and it should be adopted—is whole farm management practices, particularly things like minimum tillage. If the land is properly managed, organic carbon levels in soil can actually be built up to a greater extent than they can in trees. The Victorian agricultural department has shown only too clearly that that in turn results in more productive cropping. So it is an absolute win-win situation. I notice Senator Brownhill nodding in assent. It is true: if you manage the land properly, you will not only absorb more carbon into the soil but you will actually get better cropping and better production as a result.

PARA.TAB: Not only is this an entirely fallacious policy on agricultural grounds, but it is also totally uncosted. Mr McLachlan said in the policy that to do this would be `both simple and inexpensive'. He based this on the South Australian process, which I have to say is excellent, of compensating landowners for taking land out of production and, in fact, not clearing it.

The current cost of that program—I have checked with South Australia—is around $120 per hectare. Translating that into a national policy, how the coalition can say in print that this will be both simple and inexpensive is beyond me. As I have pointed out already, the cost of implementing the reafforestation of 660,000 hectares of currently cleared land every year that it has targeted would be between $5 billion, using direct seeding, and about $15 billion, using plants. So the government, in pure fiscal terms, will not be adopting that either.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Did the Australian government officially sanction the recent visit to Burma by former Prime Minister Mr Bob Hawke? Does the minister believe it was appropriate for Mr Hawke to lead a business delegation to Burma with the aim of encouraging greater foreign investment, given that country's appalling human rights record? Is the minister aware of the major military offensive currently being conducted by the Burmese State Law and Order Restoration Council against the Karen and other minorities? Finally, given these disturbing new developments, will the government now consider methods of coordinating an international regime of economic and trade sanctions against the SLORC?

—The situation in Myanmar continues to be a deeply unhappy one. Daw Aung San Suu Kyi remains under house arrest despite the introduction of some dialogue with the regime and the hopes that had widely been felt in the latter part of last year that this might lead to her release in January. Those hopes have not been realised.

PARA.TAB: The national convention process shows at the moment no grounds at all for confidence that any kind of democratic accountability of the military regime will emerge from that process. Many political prisoners remain incarcerated. Political and civil freedoms are effectively non-existent. Forced labour is still a reality in many parts of the country. So far as minorities are concerned, the offensive against the Karen National Union, about which Senator Bourne asked, which the Australian government deplores and which has now already resulted in the fall of Manerplaw, has called in question any real commitment by the SLORC administration to reconciliation with the minorities.

The Australian government's policy under these circumstances is to continue to apply every conceivable form of pressure or encouragement or persuasion that we can that is likely to be effective, to try and get movement against a number of benchmarks that we have articulated. That approach has largely found common acceptance not only with the United States and Europe but also with the ASEAN countries, which are very much more influential than any of us in Myanmar, at the discussions we had earlier last year. Australia's position on trade and economic relations has led us to take the approach of neither encouraging nor discouraging trade and investment but holding out the prospect of more active support for trade and investment if again movement is made on those benchmarks.

It was against all that background that Mr Hawke made his visit to Myanmar a few days ago. I was not aware of the visit until after it had occurred. Mr Hawke did, however, seek and receive standard briefing from my department earlier in January before the visit when he indicated to them that he was about to go. Had I known that he was going there I would have expressed no basic objection to the visit itself for exploring commercial opportunities. To have done so would have been to discriminate in a way that we have not done with other business firms that have indicated a desire to go there and see the opportunities. As I said, we neither encourage nor discourage.

What I certainly would have done is urge him to use his undoubted stature and reputation internationally to make some very important points about the need for change in Burma, and in particular to address the intolerability of the continued detention of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi. In the end, Mr Hawke chose not to do so, though he had ample opportunity to make these points, particularly in his discussions with Khin Nyunt. I have conveyed directly to Mr Hawke, in a phone conversation which he initiated this morning from Hong Kong, my disappointment at the missed opportunity to reinforce the views of the whole world community in this respect and also the significance likely to be attributed by the regime to the issue not being raised.

Mr Hawke's response, to be fair, is that of course he feels intensely about these issues but that he will be in a better position to pursue them and to influence the SLORC if he has an ongoing or a continuing presence there, and at this stage he is simply in the early stage of doing just that. I have no reason whatsoever to doubt his genuineness in this respect but, as I indicated to him, I did differ quite fundamentally from his judgment in that respect. Mr Hawke also takes very seriously—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the minister answer part 4 of my question?

—Just to complete part 3, Mr Hawke, to be fair, is also immensely concerned about the drug situation in Myanmar, as we all are. One of the things he was discussing with the ambassador there, and is keen to discuss further with us and others, is what further things the international community might be able to do to either encourage further change in policy of a usefully supportive kind by the administration there or else, in some other way, try to address that particular problem. Mr Hawke does resent—and I can understand that resentment—some of the press references to his position on the drug issue, which is very firm whatever he might have felt about the appropriateness of taking a more robust line on the fundamental political and civil rights issues.

PARA.TAB: As to the last part of the question, I do not want to say any more than this: I have been actively discussing what we might now be able to do in the international community last week with Douglas Hurd in the UK and I will be doing that with Strobe Talbott, the Deputy Secretary of State, and will continue to work out what might be most appropriate. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Is the minister willing to give an undertaking that he and his government will not allow logging or roading in the 509 high conservation areas protected by the Prime Minister on Friday?

—As the Prime Minister announced last week, the government will do everything in its power to ensure the protection of those 509 coupes, until their values are properly assessed as part of the national reserve system through a regional forest agreement. The Minister for Resources is writing to woodchip companies and state governments to inform them of the areas that the government intends to protect, and the 222 national estate areas are explicitly protected in terms of the licence.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that the states have primary responsibility for the management of forests and, as the Prime Minister has indicated, the government wishes to work cooperatively with the states to find the most effective way to end logging in the 509 high conservation value coupes. The mainland states, of course, have accepted an obligation, in signing the national forest policy statement, to protect forest areas likely to be of high conservation value until such time as those values can be thoroughly assessed, a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system put in place and a system of forest reserves established. I think it is time that the states joined with the Commonwealth in honouring that obligation of the national forest policy statement.

Subject to the outcome of consultations with the states, it is anticipated that the principal means of protection for these coupes will be through conditions that are attached to the new licences. Of course, that will depend on the companies giving up their current licences, according to the processes that the Prime Minister outlined in his statement of 27 January. The Prime Minister has invited them to do so in order to remove the uncertainty that has been created by the Federal Court decision.

I believe that it is in the best interests of all parties involved in this issue that they respond positively to the invitation the Prime Minister has issued. State agencies will need to reschedule their planned logging activities to avoid the nominated coupes. If after such rescheduling the resources available to industry are inadequate, the government has indicated that it will work in consultation with the industry, the unions and the states to assess the need for industry assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It seems that the minister may be confusing power with political will. Does the minister say that the government does not have the power to control the operations of forestry companies, despite its use of the corporations powers, under the Constitution, to control Australian companies involved in sex tourism elsewhere in the world?

—The government has ruled out the use of the corporations powers in this regard. I really do think it is important that Senator Margetts sheets home any responsibility for logging in those areas to the state governments after the information is provided to them. The Commonwealth has given its commitment that it will do all in its power to protect those areas. It is not a commitment that we have made lightly; it is a commitment that the government intends to honour.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Is it the case that Mr Keating's list of 509 coupes of alleged high conservation value includes compartment 74 in the New South Wales Whian Whian State Forest which was heavily logged and culled in the 1960s and 1970s and is now made up of 25-year-old blackbutt? Does the list also include compartment 48 in the Barrington Tops State Forest and is it true that 80 hectares of the area was ringbarked in the 1950s? Is it also a fact that large parts have been regularly burnt and grazed and the remainder have been extensively logged in the past? How do these compartments meet the national forest policy statement definition of old-growth? If they do not, what are the high conservation values they possess?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Alston has shown his ignorance of the national forest policy statement. For your information, Senator Alston, there are more values than just old-growth and wilderness, and that is outlined in the national forest policy statement. I think most Australians would believe that many of those values are important. National Estate values are important; World Heritage values are important; bio-diversity values are important; and endangered species values are important. I point out to you, Senator, that on page 24 of the national forest policy statement, dealing with comprehensive regional assessments, those values are outlined very clearly. I will quote the NFPS for Senator Alston's information. It states:

PARA.TAB: These assessments will provide the basis for enabling the Commonwealth and the States to reach a single agreement relating to their obligations for forests in a region. Commonwealth obligations include assessment of national estate values, World Heritage values, Aboriginal heritage values, environmental impacts, and obligations relating to international conventions, including those for protecting endangered species and biological diversity.

ANSWER.PARA: I say to Senator Alston that the process that was used in determining these forest coupes and the original list of coupes that was provided by my department to the Minister for Resources was a transparent process, a consultative process, a rigorous process—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The minister can rabbit on as much as he likes about his consultation process. The point of my question was very specific. You were asked about compartment 74 and compartment 48. Are you telling us you have no idea what is contained in those two compartments or are you conceding the substance of the question?
—Order! There is no point of order. The general nature of the answer was perfectly relevant.

—Specifically in relation to some of the issues raised by Senator Alston I point out that in northern New South Wales, Mr Souris, the state Minister for Land and Water Conservation, in a press release of 30 January 1995 cited a particular area in the Enfield State Forest at Taree which he claimed contained a gravel quarry. That is true. But Mr Souris fails to acknowledge the fact that the quarry in question is very small and the compartment in which it is situated is, by comparison, extraordinarily large. He has claimed that a very high proportion of the 1,300 forest coupes, originally identified by my department in December, were previously being logged.

PARA.TAB: However, some of that may be true, Senator, and I have tried to outline to you the sorts of values that are important. You do have to take into account the intensity and the scale of the logging operations in the compartments that you mentioned. Presumably the minister in that respect was referring to logging operations carried out under a selective harvesting regime in which only sawlogs of the highest quality were removed at the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Faulkner, I do not know where you were in January. You were asked two questions about the Whian Whian State Forest and the Barrington Tops State Forest and you answered by telling us something about the Enfield State Forest. Can you confirm that of the 249 New South Wales coupes on the list only 99 were ever intended to be used for woodchip logging in 1995? Is it also true that 69, or 28 per cent, of the New South Wales coupes have been logged at least twice and some regularly logged for more than 100 years? Would you please explain to us how all that hacking and burning and logging constitutes high conservation value?

—What I can confirm to you is that the coupes that have been advised to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and to the Minister for Resources from the Department of Environment, Sport and Territories are those coupes that have the highest conservation values of the coupes that have been identified. The process that I outlined earlier in response to a question from Senator Macdonald was a thorough process, a process that was rigorous, a process that was consultative, a process that was open, a process that was transparent and, I believe, a process that stands scrutiny.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. I understand that this morning the minister chaired a meeting of the Market Australia Advisory Group. Will the minister advise the Senate of the purpose of Market Australia and will he also provide details of the strategy and approach that is being pursued in achieving the purpose of this group?

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Notwithstanding the opposition's interjections, this is a program that has widespread support amongst state governments and the private sector. It is a straightforward team Australia proposal which this morning reflected that cooperative approach in a meeting of the Market Australia Advisory Group. The meeting was attended by myself and my colleague Peter Cook, representing the federal government, Hendy Cowan from Western Australia, David Hamill from Queensland, Phillip Gude from Victoria and Shane Stone from the Northern Territory, together with representatives of other Commonwealth government agencies and representatives of the private sector.

PARA.TAB: The Market Australia initiative had its origins in the McKinsey report on behalf of the Australian Manufacturing Council about emerging exporters. The report identified a concern for Australian companies, particularly small to medium enterprises, and identified the need to raise international perceptions—by implication, particularly in our region—about Australia's capacity in the manufacture of sophisticated goods and the provision of sophisticated services.

There has been some delay in the commencement of that program to enable research to be undertaken because I did not wish—and the other ministers and representatives shared the view—to respond merely to an assessment as general as that from McKinsey, so we undertook a research campaign in seven markets in the Asian region which substantially reinforced the concerns which McKinsey outlined and gave some indications of the sort of campaign we ought to undertake to deal with them.

The matters we dealt with this morning particularly related to marketing campaigns conducted essentially by the Commonwealth but with the cooperation of, and some funding from, the private sector to seek to change those images. It is a truism of any sort of marketing that images are quick to form and slow to change. But it is important to have a campaign to start the process of change. This morning's meeting decided to test the marketing concept in selected markets, particularly China, Indonesia and Thailand. We will be looking at some sector specific activity probably in the Republic of Korea.

This is not all the Market Australia campaign will be doing. It has already got under way campaigns in association with the private sector to promote Australia's skills in rural telecommunications, aerospace and environmental technology. The meeting this morning also decided that the campaign should concentrate on some specific sectors over and above those which I have outlined and will be using case studies of Australian excellence in high technology goods and services to support that.

The advisory group proposed quite forcefully—and I think accurately—that there need to be sets of performance indicators against which the success of the campaign can be measured. It is not intended that it should be funded by the public sector as a long-term proposal. It is intended that we will seek to show whether a strategy such as this can succeed and, if it can, we hope that it will then be taken up by the private sector. We will be having discussions later this year and early next year about initiatives to encourage the private sector to take up this proposal when the government commitment to it concludes.

I think it is an important and appropriate initiative. It is the sort of thing that the public sector should initiate briefly as a catalyst in concert with Commonwealth, states and the private sector in the hope that, if it succeeds, it will become a continuing feature of Australian market performance subsequently funded by the private sector. I thank all those corporate and state and territory representatives for their cooperation and assistance this morning.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Is the minister aware that the safe sex guide that the minister launched in November contains a section which advocates sodomy and anus licking? Did the minister and government give their approval? How is this consistent with the government's HIV-AIDS strategy? What was the cost of the guide to the government?

—I am very well aware of the guide attached to the December issue of Cleo magazine. By and large, it was widely circulated in the community in December and, probably, still in January. The guide, commissioned by the department, was produced by Cleo and the cost, as I recollect it, was about $250,000. It is a very comprehensive guide. It targets in particular a population of young women, principally 18 through 25 but possibly even younger than that. I can assure you, Senator, that, from my experience to this point, many more than young women have been reading that comprehensive sex guide.

PARA.TAB: It is disappointing that you should stand up and pick out one or two of the issues in that guide that might be a cause of eye stretching. The guide covers a whole range of issues, such as safe sex and good practice, to address the questions of concern for young people. One is the critical issue, as we recognise now, of trying to prevent sexually transmitted diseases.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you read it as a mother? As a parent, have you read it?

—I do not know in which category I have read it, Senator, but I have certainly read it. I am certainly aware that for thousands of youngsters in that age group that document goes to answering the questions they want to ask and want answers to. It talks about how to prevent AIDS. It talks about how to prevent pregnancy. It talks about how to prevent the spread of chlamydia, syphilis and gonorrhoea. It also talks about achieving orgasm and a whole lot of things.

PARA.TAB: The question really is: where do you stop, Senator? If anybody asked you questions in the privacy of your medical practice, would you answer those questions? Why, when so many people are concerned about anal intercourse, safe practices and so on, should that report not contain that information?

It is better to stress that this document covers comprehensively all the issues of concern to young people. I think it is important. You may want to check with what young people ask you. It is not promoting those practices; it is talking about—

TALK.START.PARA: —It does.
—No, it does not. It does not promote anything. It is presented in a very informative and non-judgmental way.
—You haven't read it.

—Shouting will not make it any different. Your shouting will not change the facts. This is a report that responds to the clear needs of providing vital and significant information to people in that age group. It is information that those people asked for. It is also clear that many in that age group, particularly in the younger age group of 14 to 18, do not have all the information, given the number of youngsters who are becoming infected with sexually transmitted diseases. We know the concern of youngsters who get pregnant when we do not want them to or when they do not want to, and we know the problem of AIDS. So for all those reasons it is important to look at this document as a balanced effort to try to comprehensively provide information for all those people rather than be outraged at some small sections of it. It is to be read as a whole. Senator, you check how the young people respond. (Time expired)
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Has the Prime Minister read this document?
—There is nothing that I can say to that.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. Can the minister confirm that the company Barry Arnold and Sons was responsible for exporting more than 150,000 tonnes of woodchips from northern Tasmania in the last quarter of 1994? Did this company have a valid export licence for that load? If so, what were the terms and conditions of that licence, including relevant dates, quantities and the source of materials? Does the company have a current valid licence to export woodchips? If so, is that licence part of the 2.889 million tonnes to be exported from Tasmania? If not, why and how would that export take place?

—I cannot answer the detailed parts of that question. I am happy to take it on notice and provide a more detailed response to Senator Bell. I can tell Senator Bell that Barry Arnold and Sons Pty Ltd has a licence which expires in March this year. However, the volumes that were available to Barry Arnold and Sons Pty Ltd under this licence have already been shipped. The Commonwealth is aware that Barry Arnold and Sons shipped woodchips in excess of approved volumes. The matter is now being referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions for his consideration.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If the volumes have been exceeded, those chips have left our shores. What penalties will be sought in this regard? Will it be a financial penalty or a condition of licence? From that, we have to ask what sort of process this is. How often is this happening around Australia? What do these quotas mean when we have an excess to a quota? Will we get the chips back and rebuild them? What process will take place?

—I have indicated in the answer I just gave that the Commonwealth is deadly serious about ensuring compliance with the conditions that are placed on these licences. With the greatest respect in terms of what penalties we will be seeking, the government does not seek penalties. In the first instance, the appropriate action, as I understand it, is being taken today; that is, the Director of Public Prosecutions is being advised of this. It will be a matter for the DPP to consider whether there are enough grounds for charges to be laid. It will then be a matter for the courts. In addition, the minister has already announced that the surveillance role of the Commonwealth in respect of these licences will be significantly enhanced.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. In a letter to the Minister for Resources dated 7 September submitting the first instalment of your forest preservation list you said, `In preparing my advice I have been rigorous in identifying forests of high conservation value.' If that was so, why and how did the government more than halve your rigorously determined list from 1,300 coupes to 509 coupes? Why did the Prime Minister claim in his press conference of 27 January that environment groups would have been happy with 200 or 230 coupes before Christmas? Is it not simply the case that the list you submitted was nothing more than a regurgitation of the extremist Green ambit claim that had no scientific basis? Could you inform the Senate of how many of the Prime Minister's 509 coupes have previously been logged and how many are predominantly plantation forests?

—The basis of my advice to Minister Beddall was a decision by cabinet at the end of 1993 that I advise the Minister for Resources on the applicability of the national forest policy statement as it applied to export woodchip licences. I have, as I have indicated in this chamber time and time again, taken seriously that responsibility and also the conservation elements of the national forest policy statement, one of which, as I have mentioned before, is the so-called moratorium clause of the statement which says that until assessments are completed forest management agencies will avoid activities that may significantly affect those areas of old-growth forest or wilderness that are likely to have high conservation value.

PARA.TAB: I was charged with the responsibility of providing Mr Beddall with advice on conservation values. I did that from the perspective of the environment minister. As you know, Mr Beddall, with his responsibilities under the national forest policy statement, is required to take into account other considerations as well. Not only does he take into account environmental considerations in coming to his conclusions; he also takes into account social and economic factors as he makes a determination.

The 509 coupes have been identified as those of the highest priority that are required to protect areas of environmental significance pending a full assessment as part of the regional forest agreement process. Those areas have the potential to be strategically important for the development of a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system. The point is that they were areas assessed as having outstanding conservation attributes such as old-growth values or wilderness values; or they might be endangered species habitat or perhaps there was a conjunction of a number of other values. Particular attention was applied to coupes in areas listed on the Register of the National Estate or those where harvesting operations had the potential to impact on World Heritage values and, in coming to the 509 coupes, supplementary information and comments from state agencies were also utilised.

In the first process, Senator, the state that you represent in this chamber did not comment—in fact refused to comment—on the information I made available to it. That was not very helpful. There is, as you know, and as I have outlined in answer to a previous question today, a verification process for these coupes which will involve state agencies, and I hope that the Tasmanian agencies will be involved in this regard. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is all very well to try to obfuscate the matter and blame Minister Beddall, but the simple fact is, Senator Faulkner, that you indicated on 7 December that you had applied a rigorous test. Why is it that that rigorous test was not good enough for the other 791 coupes that have now disappeared from the government's list? You avoided answering the question relating to what scientific basis there was to his determinations. You talk about consultation, you talk about all the values of these areas but you do not tell us who advised you. Is it not a fact that it was just from the extremist Green movement that you sought advice as opposed to getting proper scientific advice as to the true value of these areas—because you play to the tune of the Green movement—without, as you admitted, giving consideration to the people of regional Australia whose families and communities depend on this vital industry?

—No, it is not true. I repeat that the Minister for Resources, the Prime Minister and the whole of the government, in reaching their position, took account of not only environmental factors but also other factors. As I said, social and economic factors are important in that assessment.

PARA.TAB: The process that was undertaken by my portfolio was a thorough one, and it was one that was coordinated by the portfolio. One of the inputs to that process came from consultancies from conservation groups in the states—that is true—but the assessments were made by my portfolio. All of my portfolio agencies—the Australian Nature Conservation Agency, the Heritage Commission, the Commonwealth EPA and the new forest branch I established in my department—were responsible for coordinating that process. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—In accordance with procedural matter No. 16, I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Resources for an explanation as to why there has not been an answer to a question on notice asked by me—the number of which I do not have at hand but have advised the minister.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In responding to Senator Bell's inquiry, I dob myself in by saying that there is a second question which Senator Bell did not raise with me but which is also outstanding. The question numbers are 1893 and 1901. My advice is that I should apologise to Senator Bell for the delay. The facts are that the answers to both of these questions are being finalised today. I will forward them to Senator Bell as soon as I can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out to the Senate that the reason for my raising this particular matter was not to make a great point of the tardiness of the answer, nor to be concerned in particular about the other question which is unanswered, but, rather, to point out that question on notice No. 1893 was of the same ilk as the question without notice I asked today. In other words, it was a question about the process that this government has in place with regard to the export of woodchips from this country.

PARA.TAB: For the edification of honourable senators, question on notice No. 1893 pointed out that alleged breaches of prescription in compartment 13 of Croobyar State Forest had come to our notice. We alleged that activities were taking place which were not in accordance with the national forest policy statement. We therefore asked: what is the forestry policy statement worth if breaches could be noticed on 22 November 1994? We wanted to know what was being done about it and whether a new licence would be issued to these people if such breaches were in fact found to have occurred. The fact that it has taken so long is not really the issue. The real issue is that we are concerned—and the Democrats have a right to be concerned—about the forest policy statement. We want to know whether the government is serious about enforcing it.

I appreciate the fact that Minister Collins, in his answer to my question without notice, was able to say that there is an increased supervision of the terms and conditions of these licences. But, in the case of 27 November, we would have thought that there would be some sort of response to suggest that this government is serious about policing its own policies. It is not that we want inspectors hiding behind every tree or people running around in hard hats poking about in other people's business all the time, but we do want some attempt to demonstrate that this government is serious about the terms and conditions that have been established. It has got a policy. Let us see it enforce it.

Suggestions and allegations have been made and I would have expected a much more immediate response. I look forward to the minister's response, which I have been assured is forthcoming. But I make the point that, if there can be two examples found here, I wonder what else is going on.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter Senator Bell has just raised exemplifies completely the government's handling, or mishandling, of this whole forest policy issue. It is just further evidence, if it needs to be given, of the absolutely incompetent way the environment minister and the resources minister handle these things. They have made Australia a laughing stock from a business investment point of view. They simply cannot handle, and are incapable of managing, the forest industry in Australia. It is something that was supposedly agreed upon in 1992 by the Commonwealth and all the states.

PARA.TAB: The government in my own state of Queensland has been trying to get the Commonwealth government to move. It has been unable to do so simply because this federal government has no idea of how to handle Australia's forest industry. Its ministers in the relevant areas are incapable and incompetent of managing these areas, and the sooner they get aside and let some competent ministers handle the issues, the better off Australia will be.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), to a question without notice asked by Senator Alston this day, relating to logging and woodchipping.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Faulkner said that the process of nominating the original 1,300 coupes was thorough, rigorous, open, transparent, done with consultation and will stand scrutiny. What hogwash! What absolute nonsense! He knows it and his government knows it. Everyone who has been interested in this matter knows that he and his government deliberately went about sponsoring extreme green groups throughout this land to come up with their nominations. In fact, he gave those groups $120,000 of taxpayers' money to come forward with the 1,300 coupes.

PARA.TAB: He gave them only seven weeks to do it, and so it was done in a very cursory, offhand way. He did not consult with the experts in the states—and he acknowledged today in this chamber that the state governments are the experts in land management and do in fact hold all the detailed information. Did he consult with them? No, he did not.

With regard to the specifics that Senator Alston asked the minister about and which he failed to answer, let me refer the Senate to a letter in the Financial Review of the 16th of this month by Dr Hans Drielsma, the Managing Director of the State Forest of New South Wales. Dr Drielsma said:

It is . . . interesting to note, therefore, that in the north-east of NSW, 125 out of 155 areas nominated as having high conservation value (ie, 80 per cent) have been logged at least once previously, presumably destroying their natural values.

SPEECH.PARA: It was the minister himself who said in this chamber just a little while ago that the highest values the government was chasing were for old growth and for wilderness. Dr Drielsma said:

PARA.TAB: Many of the areas, in addition to previous logging, were ringbarked or given . . . silvicultural treatment . . . to encourage good . . . regeneration. Obviously, these treatments have been highly successful.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole thing has been a sham. I refer to a note put out by the Tasmanian government in December. Again, of the 181 areas nominated of the 1,300 that were in Tasmania, planned logging has been completed in 14 of those coupes. Logging is in progress in a further 19 of the coupes. A further 117 have been previously logged for a variety of products, including sawlog, pulpwood, mining timbers and firewood.

PARA.TAB: This whole thing was a sham, and the minister and the government knows it. It was a deliberate move by the government to try to con suburban Melbourne and Sydney that it was supportive of Green sentiments. The government thought it could play one side of the coin as well as the other by renewing the licences. It thought it could get away with doing that. The demonstration outside this parliament by the people who are directly affected and the demonstrations that have been in Tasmania, Perth and in forest areas all around the nation show that it will not work.

The minister knows what the solution is. The solution is to get agreement between the Commonwealth and the states as to what are parks and what are multiple-use forests. The minister claimed here today that his process has been open and transparent. He blamed the states for not settling the national forest policy process and ending up with regional agreements. What a load of hogwash. He knows as well as I do that his department and the Greens—Toyne and Co.—have been the source of obstruction on this matter.

The states have tried to get criteria out of the Commonwealth for this regional assessment process, and they have failed. It really has been a shonky business by the minister. The community of Australia ought to be well aware of that. The government has been trying to play politics for the benefit of suburbia and to the detriment of all the affected people in the forests throughout regional Australia.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —In December 1993 the cabinet decided that the Minister for the Environment would provide advice to the Minister for Resources on matters relevant to the national forest policy statement as it applied to the granting of woodchip export licences. The process I undertook in developing that advice, I believe, was the most comprehensive, thorough and transparent that has ever been undertaken. It was, however, complicated by a lack of cooperation from state governments.

PARA.TAB: All states were advised in July 1994 by DPIE of the Commonwealth's information requirements on the renewal of export licences. The states' response to this request for information was very patchy and in many cases quite late. In fact, a comprehensive list of coupes likely to be logged were only ever received for Tasmania and the southern forests of Western Australia. This made the task of developing advice for Minister Beddall very difficult indeed.

On 22 August the acting environment minister wrote to state ministers informing them of my initiative with the conservation organisations and inviting them to comment and to advise the department on the advice from the conservation organisations when received. This was also made clear and contacted at official levels.

The New South Wales and Tasmanian governments responded that they would not cooperate in the assessment process. When reports were received from conservation organisations in early November, they were forwarded to state governments, NAFI, the Forest Protection Society and the CFMEU. They were asked to comment and provide information on any areas to my department. There were almost no responses to that invitation. No analysis was provided on the merits of individual coupe analysis.

My portfolio analysed information from a wide range of sources before making its recommendations to me. As part of that process, the conservation organisations were funded to provide substantiated advice on areas likely to be of high conservation value. My advice in no way was an endorsement of the information provided by the conservation groups. My department undertook its own detailed assessment of the conservation significance of the areas that were planned for logging. It involved itself in a step by step process.

The geographic locations of the coupes were checked. The Australian Heritage Commission checked coupes against information that was held on the register of the national estate. This information included the growth stage, the disturbance history and the presence of endangered species in the vegetation communities for the areas concerned. The environmental resources information unit used GIS technology to map the location of coupes with information holdings on nationally threatened species, including rare species of plants obtained from the records of museums, herbaria and botanical gardens around Australia.

ANCA plotted the location of coupes against information holdings on rare and threatened species and communities, wetlands of significance and migratory paths of birds. ANCA also undertook a detailed analysis of the significance of places for the conservation of biodiversity, including an analysis at a national level of the importance of regions or areas.

The conservation status of forest communities was checked by the portfolio against all the available information. Where it was considered to be poorly reserved, the area was also listed as likely to be of high conservation value. Analysis was undertaken on habitat requirements and strategies that needed to be put in place for protection of species listed in the Endangered Species Protection Act. The AHC was also involved in analysing the information against the national wilderness inventory. This represents a very thorough and detailed process.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join this debate very briefly and for one reason: to put paid to the lies that have been perpetrated by the green lobby movement around Australia, particularly around Western Australia, during the last few months. This has led to the fiasco of the cancellation of those licences, and that is why we see the ring of trucks outside. It is good to see a display of the machinery that we have in the forests, but it is very unfortunate that those machines are not in the forests working and earning foreign export income for Australia rather than sitting idly around here.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) could see the green lobby votes going out the window some time before Christmas, he decided to do something about it and overrode two of his ministers—Senator Faulkner and Mr Beddall—cancelling those licences, which had been issued under the national forest agreement almost two years ago. He had to intervene because he could see those green lobby votes disappearing. That is why we have the 509 blocks around Australia locked up. I refuse to call these blocks `coupes'—I expect chickens to be running out of them.

What effect does this have on Australia's economy? We know what the economy is doing. It means the loss of jobs. It means the loss of jobs and incomes in remote areas—not around Canberra, not in Senator Faulkner's town and not in Senator Gareth Evans's new electorate of Holt, but out in those remote areas where we cannot afford it.

These are the lies the Greens put around. If you listened to the Greens—I half believed it myself for a while—you would think good, straight, millable karri and jarrah logs were going into woodchipping. That is a lie. That is a plain lie because only five per cent of hardwood forest goes into woodchipping as a by-product. The logs do not go in as a whole. The Democrats are not bad at pushing this lie either. Only five per cent of the hardwood goes in. Otherwise, that material would be left on the forest floor to rot and cause further diseases in the forest or to burn and add more expense. This way it has a value. The Greens say that that is the case. I say it is all lies.

In all states of Australia, public forests are controlled by state authorities. In Western Australia they are controlled by the Department of Conservation and Land Management. It manages the forest. It decides what logs are cut, what logs are not cut and where not to cut. For example, it decided that there would be no cutting for 200 metres on either side of a stream. It decides not to cut on too steep a bank—anything over 15 degrees, I believe—whereas a lot of other countries cut on steeper banks. CALM decides all that.

It decides what may be cut and then it decides the trees that have to be left behind for natural seed. When it allows the logging, then it appoints the contractors to fell the trees. CALM does that. Private enterprise does not do it—willy-nilly to make a fast buck. CALM decides. It has its own dedicated contractors. Then it has dedicated contractors to cart those logs to the mill. It sets the price the mill has to pay.

You would think that is probably where the control of those logs finishes. But it does not. In Western Australia, the mill has to undertake that 70 per cent of first-grade, hardwood timber logs go to value adding, which puts paid to the argument of Mr de Bruin of the South Australian softwood industry. He said last night on television that 90 per cent finishes up in housing. That is a lie also. He is only protecting the softwood industry.

We could debate for a lot longer than five minutes on this matter, but the lies the Greens are perpetrating are what caused the Prime Minister to come in to save the green lobby votes for himself for the next election by overriding the licences.

If the green lobby group and the Democrats have a message, let them tell the truth. They should tell the truth about what happens. I know what goes on in the forests of Western Australia. I have made a good study of it and I know what is going on. The two Greens are missing today. Sorry, three Greens are missing today—there is a new one—but we hope they will come in and join this debate in time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainty before the law, I believe, is a most important principle for not only the democratic process but also the prosperity of Australia. As it applies to industry, as it applies to the jobs of workers and as it applies to the environment, the government's new policy fails on that crucial test.

PARA.TAB: The government's announcement on this matter is absolutely confusing. That is a matter that is common ground for persons who are supportive of the forest industry and also persons who are supportive of the environment. I fit into both categories, I hope, and quite a lot of people fit into that category—supportive of the environment and supportive of the industry. Frankly, knowing the number of foresters that I do, I take exception to the fact that they are classed very often as vandals of the forests.

I had the pleasure recently of tenting with my wife up in Blue Tier in north-eastern Tasmania. Not many people know about Blue Tier—only the locals, and I happened to marry a local. It was a wonderful experience there for four or five days after Christmas. That was an area that a century ago was mined for tin. What has happened there is that Forestry Tasmania has ensured that that particular area is protected, and I refer to the massive myrtles that are swept by the mists of a night-time watering of the whole area. Forestry Tasmania has protected that area.

I take exception to what Senator Faulkner says about no cooperation between the states and the government. I, along with everybody else, had thought this was gone from politics when the Resource Assessment Commission did the study and the national forestry policy statement emerged. In fact, that statement said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . until the assessments are completed—
when it was talking about various assessments—
forest management agencies will avoid activities that may significantly affect those areas of old growth forest or wilderness that are likely to have high conservation value.

Apparently Senator Faulkner thought that as minister he was the only one able to make that particular assessment. That was not what was envisaged in the national forestry policy statement. In fact, the states in cooperation with various Commonwealth areas did the assessments.
