TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. You will see there the efforts made by that organisation in an endeavour to ensure that the assessment was transparent, was auditable and was in fact based on scientific rigour. I challenge the minister to state where in the assessment there has not been that scientific rigour and that transparency and where the assessment fails the test of auditability. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too rise to speak on Senator Gibson's motion to take note of Senator Faulkner's answer to Senator Alston's question on coupes. I note that the question referred specifically to New South Wales. But in his answer the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) wandered all over the place, as he has done also in his comments here.

PARA.TAB: I am going to make reference to some Western Australian aspects. In particular, I want to pick up the point made by Senator Harradine about certainty before the law and also that there must be some ability by people who deal with governments to have faith in government statements—ministerial statements, in particular.
In connection with Western Australia, I refer in particular to the 1992 AHC-CALM agreement. At that time the then minister, Mrs Kelly, heralded that agreement by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe this is an outstanding example of the way in which federal and State agencies can work together for common good . . . I hope it's the beginning of a new relationship between forest industries and State governments.

She further went on there to say that this would improve the productivity in the forest sector while conserving the National Estate. At the time this was supported, might I add, by Senator Coulter, the then Leader of the Australian Democrats, by Senator Chaney, who was the environmental spokesman for the opposition, and by a number of other people, including some from the Green movement.

PARA.TAB: We now have a situation where that has been thrown out the door. It is indeed unfortunate that both Senator Collins and Senator Faulkner have chosen to leave the chamber, but I note that the Leader of the Government, Senator Gareth Evans, is here. I put the fact that we are already seeing the fallout of this particular decision with the uncertainty that is apparent here: Whittakers, one of the operators in Western Australia, has applied to the Stock Exchange to suspend trading of its shares and this has been granted. This is the sort of thing that happens when we have a government that is inconsistent in its policy position and does not know where it is travelling. There is conflict between Senator Collins, Senator Faulkner and Minister Beddall in the other place. We now have the intervention of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). As a result we have thousands and thousands of jobs at risk, with the flow-on effects of that into our current account, higher national debt, higher interest rates and all other things flowing from them.

What we have to say to those sitting on the other side in relation to this is that if they are going to change the rules of the game, if they are going to say that they no longer have faith in what the Australian Heritage Commission did in 1992 in making the assessment in terms of the Western Australian forest—if they no longer have faith in that decision and the identification process that went on then, then they should damn well come out and say so. They should just be a little bit honest about it. They should not hide under it and undermine the industry, undermine the people involved in it, mislead the people who are genuinely concerned about conservation values, undermine the work that has been done by the conservation and land management division in Western Australia and totally confuse everybody in the process.

That is the challenge that this government has to answer as to why it has changed its particular position. It certainly cannot be for conservation reasons. It certainly is not because of the management of the particular operations that go on there, whether it be saw-milling or—as Senator Panizza said—picking up the residue of that saw-milling and utilising it for chipping and earning export dollars. It is all about the government's political position and how it perceives it can buy votes. It is not about the best interests of Australia. It is not about the best interests of the particular states involved in it. It is not about honouring agreements which have been put in place, as I have mentioned, between the Australian Heritage Commission and the conservation and land management department in Western Australia. In fact, it is a total no confidence vote in those entities.

But, in terms of identifying the `coupes', as they are called in Western Australia, one must ask why the government got a list from the conservation council but never bothered to refer those on the list to the conservation and land management division and, as I understand it—but I cannot be certain about this—nor did the government bother to have those identified or assessed by the Australian Heritage Commission. The government has gone back in over the top of the work that was already done in 1992; it has given no valid reason for the action it has taken; and it has thrown an industry, a very successful industry, into chaos.

Finally, I wind up my remarks by asking: why did Senator Faulkner refuse the invitation to go down and inspect the management programs now occurring in the south-west forest? I think a visit there would be an object lesson to him and to anybody in the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion to take note of the answer by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) and congratulate the coalition senators who have spoken before me. It is an absolute insult to this chamber and indeed an insult to the forest industry and the families and communities that it supports that the minister is not in the chamber to listen to the debate on such an important issue.

PARA.TAB: The simple fact is that, on an economic basis, this is a multi-billion dollar industry earning vitally needed export dollars for our economy. We know that our balance of trade is blowing out every month with now multi-billion dollar deficits turning in by the month. The one area where the federal government could be redressing that is in the area of providing certainty, as Senator Harradine so eloquently put it, to the forest industry.

But, no, it does not. Why not? Because it has only one agenda. That agenda is to do the work of the conservation movement—that is, to fund the conservation movement and to give it reports to act upon to close down certain forest coupes. We ought to be aware that the 146 areas of high conservation value in Tasmania, which Senator Faulkner previously listed, were seriously flawed in science. Some 80 per cent of the areas that he nominated in my home state did not qualify under the national forest policy statement definitions of high quality, old-growth and wilderness. Large numbers of the areas nominated had a history of past logging and reafforestation.

I put it to this house that it is absolutely essential for sound public policy that there be certainty, that people know the process and that the process is fair and reasonable so that the outcome can be looked upon and accepted by the community at large. What Senator Faulkner has done, on his own admission, is to consult with only the green movement, the conservation groups. To make it easier for them, he threw in $120,000 to assist them.

What was the purpose of that? Well, his predecessor has told the world how the Labor Party operates—Whatever it takes. It is not what is good for Australia, not what is reasonable and not what is sound—whatever it takes. In this case, it is whatever it takes to get the green vote. We in Tasmania had an outrageous government called the Green-Labor accord. It destroyed the economy of our state. The Liberal government is still trying to get Tasmania out of the doldrums created by the Green-Labor accord. The people of Australia ought to be aware that this government is in fact a de facto Green-Labor accord wreaking exactly the same havoc over Australia that the Michael Field/Bob Brown government did to the people of Tasmania.

It would be a great tragedy if people like Bob Brown were to come into this place. They would continue to destroy the lives of people, their investments, their livelihoods, their families and their communities. That is what this debate is all about. It is about time that the Labor Party put its principles on the line and said to the workers and trade unionists of this country, `We support you before the extreme greenists.' This is its test. It has already failed it. It has the opportunity to redeem itself before the next election. If it does not, I am assured that the workers within regional Australia will absolutely desert the Labor Party and we will regain all those seats that are required to ensure that John Howard becomes the next Prime Minister of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to contribute briefly to this debate by saying that our actions as a nation over the past many decades have brought us to the situation where today we are desperately debating the nature and extent of one of Australia's major industries.
—Order! The time provided for this debate has expired. I understand an arrangement has been made to extend the debate. Does anyone wish to seek leave to extend the debate for a further 30 minutes?

—I seek leave to extend the time to take note of answers by 30 minutes. I think it has been agreed by all parties that that be permitted. Without pre-empting anything, I indicate that there are three more senators from our side who wish to speak and I think there are two Democrats who wish to speak. Then I understand that Senator Herron wants to move a motion to take note of another answer. There will be five more speakers on this issue and one on a separate issue.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is wrong that we should be here today after so many years of this government still unable to resolve this issue. Senator Panizza, quite rightly, described the particular system that was being used in Western Australia which took account of the needs and aspirations and particular concerns of West Australians about their geography and environment.

PARA.TAB: We have heard descriptions of the arguments put forward by Mr de Bruin from South Australia—arguments which Senator Panizza has rightly described as being particularly relevant to South Australia's softwood industry, an industry which is not replicated anywhere else in Australia. We have everybody in this debate approaching it from a particular point of view based on their particular world view and with their particular information.

This is the debate to take note of Senator Faulkner's answer. In his answer he described a process which he felt was transparent, consultative, thorough and rigorous—the list that Senator Gibson gave when he first sought to take note of this answer. There could be some dispute about whether that process was thorough or public enough.

I think what we are really debating is not actually that but some of the phrases and the slogans which have crept into this—slogans which have replaced actual discussion and actual information. One of the slogans that we pass over far too readily without thinking about what it actually means is the expression `high conservation values'. We are still debating what that really means. It could mean that in that area there are heritage values, national estate values or values which would protect endangered species.

I think one of the values which has not received sufficient attention in this debate so far is the value where you have a remnant species which needs to be protected. I know that at least all the Tasmanian senators in this chamber know of the incredible value of the remnant species Huon pine. It is crucial that we protect, in all instances, every single example that we can find of that particular species. Of course, that also applies to a number of other particularly valuable species in Tasmania.

In Tasmania, whatever else happens in a coupe or a block of forest, as Senator Panizza described them, if that particular area contains a representation of some of our minority species of timber, it could justifiably be argued that there is reason to protect it. That is why we see what appears to be difficult to understand when there has been exploitation beforehand, when there may have been quarrying work or tin mining—

TALK.START.PARA: —But they are doing that now.

—I agree with that, Senator Watson. I do not dispute what you are saying at all. If in an area there has been some quarrying, mining, bushfires, logging, railways—goodness knows what there might have been—and if there is representation of one of our threatened species, our remnant species of timber, then there may be justification to preserve the whole area. That is a very good example of the complicated process that should be undertaken when assessing the value of these particular coupes of forest. There are so many problems in this debate that no one person could define them, but I think one of the big problems has been the fact that reasons have not been fully explained for the offering up of some of these areas for protection.

PARA.TAB: What we need to see is a process by which the reasons for logging this area rather than another are fully explained and debated and what is contained in the national forest policy is enforced. When licences are given, they should be enforced. The operator must be obliged to comply with their terms and conditions, and suitable penalties should apply. That is what I have been on about today. That is what we ought to be discussing in great detail in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) has confirmed that the 509 coupes which have been reserved by the government are all of high conservation value. But we also know that some of these areas have been logged more than once in the last 100 years. I put it to the minister: if an area has a high conservation value after having been logged more than once in the last 100 years, why will it not continue to have a high conservation value in 100 years time?

PARA.TAB: One of the reasons the minister has given as to why something might be declared a high conservation area is that it might contain endangered species. I put it to the minister that the biggest endangered species around at the moment might be the timber worker. This has been a cynical exercise to appease the Greens at the expense of timber workers and their families, at the expense of jobs in the productive sector of the economy and at the expense of our foreign debt—

TALK.START.PARA: —And regional Australia.

—As Senator Boswell points out, it has been at the expense of regional Australia. This government is very unsympathetic to regional concerns. If you ask people out there in the community what are the three things they are most worried about, they will say families, debt and unemployment. This particular dispute encompasses those three areas quite distinctly. It is at the expense of our foreign debt, timber workers and their families, and the creation of sustainable jobs.

PARA.TAB: The timber industry has had decades of uncertainty. Every time groups of selfish radicals put pressure on this Labor government, it just caves in. Our native forests are some of the best managed forests in the world. Over the last 50 years—maybe more recently than that—many forest inquiries studies and EISs have been carried out. Senator Faulkner recently bankrolled the Greens for a further study which was not conducted in a scientific way but which was carried out by the environment movement itself. The timber industry has suffered sabotage of its equipment and life threatening action such as putting iron spikes in trees, cutting down power poles—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are the people they give $120,000 to.

—They encourage them. All these cowardly acts have become more and more prevalent as the radical environmentalists attempt anything to close down a viable and much needed industry. Last year Australia exported about $780 million worth of timber and imported about $2.4 billion worth of timber and timber product. Much of this imported timber is from countries such as Malaysia and Indonesia which have very little in the way of sound forest management.

PARA.TAB: I put it to the Green movement that, if it were truly interested in the global environment, it would not be attempting to close down our well managed and sustainable forests to the detriment of the world's forests. Generally, the international environmental organisation supports sustainable management of our native forests. However, the local organisations appear determined to oppose it at every opportunity.

There is much more at stake than the so-called woodchip industry. Those of us who live and work in rural New South Wales appreciate the full worth of the timber and forest product industry to our local communities. It is one industry which has prospered during the drought, keeping jobs and income in otherwise hard-pressed towns of rural and regional Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support my colleagues. On Saturday morning, with my colleagues Senator Gibson, Senator Watson and others, I was very proud to march through the streets of Launceston in the pouring rain along with 3,000 members of the forest industry. Alongside us were state and federal members of the Labor Party. It is an indictment of this government and the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), who is here today, that this situation has arisen. I do not think those forestry workers, loggers and truck drivers wanted to be there and they do not want to be here today protesting. They want to get on with their jobs and families. They want to make some money and get on with life.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that this minister and this government have put them in a position where they have no other way to go but to come here and demonstrate and march through the streets to put their side of the argument. Until now, we have only heard one side of the argument—indeed, the answers we got today were only one side of the argument. Why is it that the government is funding one side of the argument and not supporting the other side of the argument? Why is it that the unions and some Labor Party members have to join with us to try to make a point? Why is it that all the time so-called compromises keep on eating away into the livelihoods of those in the forest industry?

I note that Senator Harradine tabled some documents that were given to him this morning by a forester from New South Wales, David Ridley. I sat through a briefing with him. He talked about the very controversial area at Eden in New South Wales. He took us through the process that the forest industry in New South Wales is going through at the moment. I was quite amazed. I believe that the same thing happens in Tasmania. They look for everything. The whole process is transparent, scientific and auditable; they are the three words he used.

I wonder how much further the forest industry is expected to go. If Minister Faulkner has talked about being even-handed, why do the loggers have one-year term leases? If the government is out to be even-handed and fair, at the very least these licences and leases should be for a period of five years to allow the industry to have something that is bankable when it tries to borrow money and something that gives it some security.

In my state, we have had some 20 assessments, inquiries and impact statements over the years. No doubt everybody would agree that everything was not good initially. We have come a long way. There is possibly further to go. But the fact is that we have a minister and a government that can create so much uncertainty in a state that is really crying out for development. At present, we have the prospect of at least one pulp mill downstreaming woodchips. The uncertainty that has been created by this move of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and his minister will cause havoc in my state of Tasmania. It will send a clear message to people throughout the world who want to invest in downstreaming woodchipping in Australia that this is not the place to come. That is not what we want. Unfortunately, that is the message that is being given. I think it is the message that the extremist green movement wants to put out.
An incident having occurred in the gallery—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! If there is any further clapping in the public gallery, I will have the people responsible for it removed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask you to have patience with the forest workers. They are desperate. They are coming here because their jobs are on the line. I ask you to excuse them if they do get a bit emotional, because everything depends on the outcome of what happens in the next couple of days.

PARA.TAB: Today in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans said, as he tried to pass the buck to the states, that the states were not signing the national forest agreement and that therefore they could not get any accommodation. I have letters here from Mrs Kirner and Mr Fahey, the Premier of New South Wales, all pleading with the federal government to give them the criteria to allow them to go ahead and sign or complete the national forest agreement.

The national forest agreement was signed two years ago. The criteria that would allow the agreement to go forward has not come from the federal government. If it is anyone's fault that this debacle has happened, it clearly rests with the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) and his department.

It is a debacle. Today as I was approaching the parliament I saw on the lawn members of the forest union abusing the federal government. For one minute I thought I was at a National Party rally. That is an absolute debacle, and it is a debacle caused by the Labor Party not knowing which horse to back. Does it back the workers, the traditional supporters of the ALP, or does it back the white wine socialists, the Volvo socialists?

It is very simple: you cannot ride two horses in one race. The Labor Party is trying to do that and it is getting itself into a mess. The signal that you are sending out to the unionists of Australia is that you have deserted them. They have been prepared to pay $180 a year of their hard-earned wages to support your government. The unions are the organisational strength of the ALP and you have ratted on them, you have deserted them and you have walked away from them. You are sending out the clear message that the ALP no longer represents the working class men and women of Australia.

Now you have got yourself into the absolutely ludicrous position of removing those 509 coupes, of allowing sawmilling and timber cutting to go ahead. Huge resources will be burnt down, will be put through the fire hole. Huge resources that are worth export income to Australia will have to be either left on the floor of the forest or burnt—wasted. Dollars are going up in smoke.

The other thing that may happen if the sawmills cannot get a return on their woodchip is it may reduce the mills to unviability and put a number of people out of work. Those are the two options: burn the timber, burn the resource—if you can live with that, the price of timber and homes will go up—or shut down the mills in regional Australia. As my colleague Senator Sandy Macdonald said, the timber industry has sustained a number of rural towns that have been hurt by the drought.

This government has a lot to answer for. It has a lot to answer its unionists for. I give the government this message: find out who you are backing, pick the industry that you are supporting. At least Senator Devereux had the honesty to say that he was agreeing and was deserting the ALP and the work force. But you guys are trying to cover two areas—the Green movement and the worker—and you are not succeeding in either of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —A moment ago Senator Sandy Macdonald gave us figures which underscored the serious deficiencies in the forestry industry in Australia over a large number of years. He indicated that the disparity between Australian exports of forest products and imports went to several billion dollars.

PARA.TAB: I am a member of a number of conservation bodies, and have been since the mid-1950s, and I make no apology whatsoever for the position taken by the conservation movement over a long period. It is the conservation movement that has been telling the forestry industry and successive governments over many decades that we should get into extensive plantation forestry. I point the finger here at the opposition, which was in government right through the 1950s, the 1960s and into the early 1970s, and then from 1975 to 1983, for its failure to insist that the forestry industry in this country be based on plantation forestry.

In the state of South Australia, where we unfortunately chopped down our small amount of forests very early on and established plantation forestry in the 1920s mainly in the south-east of the state, we have and have had for decades the only forestry commission that has been running at a profit. A few moments ago Senator Calvert talked about Tasmania. Doesn't he recall that the Tasmanian government had not so long ago to write off $450 million worth of debt which the Tasmanian Forestry Commission has got itself into because of the total inadequacy of the way it was managing the forests?

I am particularly sympathetic towards those men and women who work in the forestry industry because at present they are the meat in the sandwich between inadequate government policy over decades and a totally inadequate policy by the forestry commissions and the forestry industries in every state of Australia except South Australia. They are the people who are now being screwed. They are not being screwed by the conservation movement; they are being screwed by the inadequacy of the policies which have been pursued over a long period.

The claim that has been repeated here today that it is only waste which is going to the chippers is a lie. I have been to many forests and seen exactly what are the operations. I suggest to the opposition that, if it goes and has a look, it will see at least 30 per cent of the timber which is being cut down is being left on the forest floor. I have seen it in Queensland; I have seen it in New South Wales; I have seen it in Victoria; and I have seen it in Tasmania. Again, it is the workers who are being screwed in this because many of them—they are outside this building with their rigs—are working on contracts in which they are paid by the tonnage of logs delivered to the chippers. The companies have mobile chippers. They could go out into the forests, chip there and transport the timber in bins, which can be seen around this building also.

Those workers, who have those expensive rigs and who are tied to large overdrafts, are forced by the system to go out and take just the maximum weight of timber to the chippers. Logs two feet in diameter and branches are being left on the forest floor and burnt simply because it is not economical for those workers, because of the economic situation that the chipping companies have put them in, to pick up those important pieces of timber and take them in to be chipped.
It is simply not true that this industry is efficient economically or efficient in terms of the timber that it has used. As I say, I express

SPEECH.PARA: great sympathy for those workers who are really being caught as the meat in the sandwich. I believe it is wrong for them to blame the conservation movement. If we had taken notice of the conservation movement from the 1960s onwards, we would be at least 20 to 30 years down the track towards having more extensive plantation forestry, and there would be adequate timber both for the imports which Senator Sandy Macdonald referred to and also for the supply of timber and chips to Australia.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Herron this day, relating to the endorsement of a safe sex guide.

SPEECH.PARA: I move this motion reluctantly, because this is an issue. I am not a subscriber to Cleo magazine, but my attention was drawn to this so-called sex guide by a columnist in the Courier-Mail called Lawrie Kavanagh, who is regarded very affectionately by people in Queensland as a voice of the people. I would like to read into Hansard something he said in his column which I think is apposite to this. He states:

PARA.TAB: If anything Australia has been at the forefront of the looney left, politically correct takeover of society, a takeover sanctioned, indeed encouraged, by our politicians.

What is it about our politicians that they almost break their weak spines bowing to the world's whims, particularly the whims of the looney left? Such a numerically small nation with such a huge contrived guilt to bear. How does Australia stay afloat, I wonder?
How long will we continue to put up with looney left minority excesses, I wonder?
Many of those excesses slip by because the majority either don't know or don't care.
That must have been the case with Carmen Lawrence's endorsement of a national women's magazine "safe sex guide" in its December issue.
Carmen has been touted as a chance to become our first female PM and is Minister for Human Services and Health at this stage.

As her department and our taxes collaborated with the magazine to produce the "safe sex guide", it seems only natural that the Minister should endorse it with enthusiasm, but the question is did she do a Ros Kelly? Did Carmen Lawrence read the "guide" before she wrote her endorsement which ended with this recommendation: "It deals with sexual health in a factual and non-judgmental way and is a resource that everyone should read".
If she did read this "guide" then she has recommended the delightful and health-giving joys of anal intercourse, or sodomy as it was called in less enlightened times, for heterosexual couples.

So does "Julie, 23," one of the case histories in the "guide", endorse sodomy with enthusiasm—". . . each time, the sense of forbidden fruit has made it so exciting . . . the vibe is more primeval, more erotic . . . like losing your virginity all over again".
But remember, as the Health Minister of this nation says, it deals with the issues in a non-judgemental way.

And after all it does not fail to stress the need to take precautions and use condoms, certainly when "Anal stimulation can be enjoyed in various forms through rimming (licking and sucking on the area around the anus)" which the "guide" reports can be a "real turn on".
I hope you appreciate these extracts from the "safe sex guide" because it is a resource that everyone should read and a lot of concerned people worked long and hard with your money to produce it.

But while nothing the looney left minority writes, says or does would surprise the majority, the Health Minister's endorsement of anal intercourse and its associated health-giving foreplays is a bit of a worry.
For instance medical experts believe AIDS would be virtually wiped out in Australia if anal intercourse, or sodomy, was suddenly to disappear.
Yet here we have a national Health Minister endorsing a tax-funded "sex guide" which recommends the very act that can lead to death.
Unless, of course, the Minister did a Ros Kelly and didn't read the material before endorsing it. In which case she is still a bit of a worry.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the article that was in the Courier-Mail. I speak here as a parent—a parent of seven daughters and three sons. I speak as a medical practitioner with over 30 years experience. The reality of life is that that Cleo guide advocates this as a normal sexual practice. It puts it out in glamorous fashion as something to be enjoyed and an activity that normal people should encourage.

PARA.TAB: I am sending a copy of this guide—at least the extract that I referred to—to every member of parliament, on both the government side as well as the opposition side, because it is an issue that affects all of us in this society. It is not something that should be fobbed off as being just something about which a crazy fellow on the other side is trying to score off the government. I am not. It is something fundamental in this society. We have to stop advocating this in society because, if we advocate that it is normal, we destroy the basis of the family unit and we destroy the very fundamentals that we stand for.

I am certain that this guide affects not only the Christian churches but also the ethnic groups in our community. It affects every mother and father in this community. Any doctor will tell you that anal intercourse is damaging to the rectum. Various associated conditions are caused by this, like fissures in the anus, chemical irritations of the rectum, damage to the sphincters of the anus, warts and all the other communicable diseases. This is a matter of very serious significance.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on 15 November 1994 of Thomas Vernon Gilmore, a member of the House of Representatives for the division of Leichhardt from 1949 to 1951, and the death on 1 January 1995 of Reginald John Birney, a member of the House of Representatives for the division of Phillip from 1975 to 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Mifepristone
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned showeth:

(1) That the trials of the abortifacient drug Mifepristone (RU486) are against the public interest in that they use women as guinea pigs for trials of a drug which causes death to the unborn future citizens and adds undue risk to the health of women.
(2) That when RU486 is used with a prostaglandin it exposes women to a disproportionate risk of pain, bleeding and more serious complications.
(3) That when RU486 is used as a `morning after pill' its effect is abortifacient in that it stops implantation of a human embryo, a future citizen, in the womb.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will legislate to ban the importation and use of RU486 in Australia.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Faulkner (from 473 citizens), Senator Hill (from 26 citizens) and Senator Woods (from 808 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We are dismayed at the continuing destruction of old growth and wilderness forests around Australia, despite the National Forest Policy Statement jointly signed by the Commonwealth and all States except Tasmania.

Intensive logging, most often to feed a voracious woodchip industry is underway or planned for many high conservation value forests. These forests should be protected by the commitments of the Commonwealth and State Governments under the NFPS.
These forests include:

PETITION.PARA: Coolangubra Wilderness and other areas of the S.E. Forests of NSW along with rainforest and other N.E. areas of NSW including Wingham, Mistake, Richmond Range, Chaelundi, North Washpool, Barrington and Dorrigo.
The Southern Highlands, Great Western Tiers and Tarkine Wilderness of Tasmania.
The Karri and Jarrah forests of S.W. Western Australia.
The Errinundra Plateau and other areas of the East Gippsland forests of Victoria.
The rainforests of the Proserpine region of Queensland.

PARA.TAB: We request that the Government act urgently to protect our precious forests by utilising the Commonwealth's legal and constitutional powers, including:

PETITION.PARA: Refusal of export woodchip licences
Powers to control corporations
Protection of areas listed on the register of the National Estate
Protection and effective funding of areas identified for their World Heritage values.

PARA.TAB: Genuine and effective action by the Government to protect these and other old growth and wilderness forests is critical. A comprehensive plantation strategy rather than exploiting native forests is the way forward for a truly environmentally responsible timber industry. We further request that the Government take effective action without further delay.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Coulter (from 5,111 citizens) and Senator Faulkner (from 51 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Aerial Spraying
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to phase out aerial spraying in accordance with recommendation 39 of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned draw to the attention of the Senate:
We are proud to fly the Australian Flag and will oppose any changes to it.
We support the Constitutional Monarchy and will oppose any moves to turn Australia into a Republic.
We believe in loyalty to the Crown and Nation, pride in the National Anthem and respect for our existing Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled—
The petition of the undersigned show:
We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the current arrangements for federal road funding discriminate savagely against Western Australia.
The petitioners note particularly that:

PETITION.PARA: Western Australians contribute $700 million in federal fuel excise revenues and receive only $150 million in return
Western Australia has 25 per cent of Australia's national highway, yet only receives 7 per cent of the National highway allocation.

PARA.TAB: This means that major investment funds are not available to upgrade deficient roads and create an efficient road network.
Your petitioners therefore request that:
The Federal Government ensure that Western Australia receives its fair share of funding for existing and proposed national highways.

PETITION.TITLE: Female Genital Mutilation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

PARA.TAB: 1. Concern at the fact that genital mutilation of girls is occurring in Australia;

2. Concern that the likelihood of a woman facing discrimination on the grounds of sex if she returns to her country of origin is not considered to be sufficient reason for granting a woman refugee status.

PETITION.PARA: Your Petitioners pray that the Senate in the Parliament assembled should, together with the House of Representatives:

PARA.TAB: 1. Classify genital mutilation as an illegal activity;

2. Follow the Canadian government's decision to allow potential `discrimination on the grounds of sex' to be sufficient reason for granting refugee status to women who would otherwise be returned to their country of origin;

3. Ensure that any such legislation is only one part of a broader strategy which includes community education about negative consequences of the mutilation practice, particularly peer education within the affected communities and education of the media in a non-sensationalist way.

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That the ancient and irreplaceable native forests in the South West of Western Australia are being destroyed by logging for woodchipping, that many species in these forests are in danger of extinction, and that Federal Government intervention is urgently needed to protect our natural heritage.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in parliament assembled, should call on the Federal Government to:
1.immediately use its powers to protect Hawke, Sharpe, Giblett and Rocky blocks and all other high conservation value and old growth forests in the South West of Western Australia,
2.refuse to renew woodchip export licences unless it is guaranteed that the wood comes from tree crops, agroforestry or plantations and,

PETITION.TITLE: Olympic Games Merchandise

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PETITION.PARA: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia:

PARA.TAB: Urges the Federal Government to bring down legislation that all merchandise bearing the Sydney Olympics 2000 insignia shall be made in Australia from material made in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: UHF Transmission in Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.The UHF line-of-sight transmission is not suited to Tasmania's mountainous terrain.
2.It is unjust that compulsory UHF has resulted in poorer reception for many Tasmanians and that those living in weak "pockets" have outlaid of up to $450 in order to receive the signal.
3.It is unjust that many low-income Tasmanians and pensioners do not have the means to outlay hundreds of dollars so they can view their own television sets.
4.Compulsory UHF has resulted in some Tasmanians being denied a signal.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled:
Call on the Government to:

PETITION.PARA: (a)honour its commitment to ensure that first class television reception is delivered to all the residents of Tasmania by providing additional funding for the urgent implementation of the necessary number of transmitters.
(b)provide all Tasmanians with access to their own national broadcasters, the ABC and the SBS.

PETITION.TITLE: Homeless Rate Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows that:
1.We are concerned that teenagers are able to leave home by obtaining young homeless rate benefits without adequate investigation.
2.We believe that the flawed nature of the guidelines governing eligibility for young homeless rate benefits is in some circumstances encouraging family breakdown.

3.With the number of young people receiving youth homeless rate benefits increasing by a factor of ten over the past six years, we consider that there are insufficient programs to help keep families together.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should:
Call on the Government to:
(a) review the guidelines for young homeless rate benefits; and
(b) show a greater commitment to programs which prevent family breakdown.

PETITION.TITLE: Desertification
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We, the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the proposed signing of the UN Convention on Desertification has the potential to adversely affect the rights of farmers to manage their farms, and of local authorities to govern their shires as well as infringing the constitutional responsibility of the states on land management issues.
We therefore request that the treaty not be signed without first receiving the scrutiny and approval of the Senate and subject to such reservations as the Senate might recommend.
As your petitioners in duty bound shall ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the child support scheme.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate support the following changes.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

(2)That the Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel; the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
(3)That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
(4)That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
(5)That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
(6)That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

(7)That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the Churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PETITION.PARA: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill intends to bring about changes which will grant more power to the Human Rights Commission, which in itself is not a court but can recommend offenders be taken to court not under Australian law but under a foreign law.

And that Australia has signed 2223 UN treaties and covenants compared to the United States 400. In the US all treaties and covenants are debated in Congress, but here in Australia the Government of the day has the power to sign these instruments without any debate taking place in Parliament.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
To the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

Whereas the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill 1994 is a direct surrender of Australian sovereignty to the dictates of an unelected United Nations Human Rights Committee made up of foreign nationals, many from countries with no respect for human rights, and

Whereas it will deprive States of their ability to legislate, in accord with community views, on any matter of public policy which touches on sexual conduct b ecausde such legislation could be overturned by the High Court following UN Human Rights Committee rulings.
We the undersigned pray that the Senate will reject this Bill.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled—

PETITION.PARA: The petition of the undersigned show that:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that as the current debate proceeds on the Family Law Reform Bill, that the role of the grandparents be included in discussion, with particular emphasis on the needs of the children affected by divorce (including defacto partnerships).

We submit that the grandparents, in the majority of cases, can be the one "constant" element for the children, to help maintain their stability and peace of mind, with someone who is part of the extended family and whose main concern is their wellbeing.
Your petitioners therefore request that:

PETITION.PARA: The Federal Government amends the Family Law Reform Bill to ensure that the role of grandparents be included in any considerations of the needs of the children affected by divorce (including defacto relationships).

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

Motion (by Senator Robert Ray)—by leave—agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to amend the Migration Act 1958, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum and move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

The purpose of this bill is to enable the recently enacted safe third country provisions of the Migration Act 1958 to cover Vietnamese refugees who had already been successfully resettled in the People's Republic of China but who lodged claims for a protection visa in Australia after 30 December 1994. More generally the bill is also to enable the safe third country provisions of the Act to have effect from a specified date preceding the date of commencement of any future agreements and relevant regulations.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last session of Parliament the Government introduced safe third country amendments to the Migration Act to ensure that certain non-citizens in relation to whom there is a safe third country, or who are covered by the Comprehensive Plan of Action for Indo-Chinese Refugees (CPA), should not be allowed to apply for a protection visa. The purpose of the legislation was to prevent forum shopping by people who had already found a country which offered them protection, or whose claims for refugee status had been rejected under an appropriate determination system. The first application of the legislation was in respect of people who arrived in Australia from Galang in Indonesia where they had been assessed as not being refugees under a refugee determination process approved by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

The legislation has been effective in ensuring that the relatively small numbers of asylum seekers from Galang arriving here after the legislation was passed were returned and others in similar circumstances were discouraged from attempting to circumvent the Comprehensive Plan of Action brokered by UNHCR. What the current legislation did not foresee was a situation where large numbers of people arrive very quickly from a place where they have received effective and on-going protection, but with which Australia does not have an existing safe third country agreement. Under the legislation as it stands, Australia has no choice but to process to finality all claims from these people lodged before a safe third country agreement has been reached. In other words, it is possible for people to arrive in Australia from what is in fact a safe third country, and access our refugee determination system because an agreement between that country and Australia has not been negotiated. This is not in the interests of the safe third country, the country to which the asylum seekers travel or UNHCR. It encourages rapid and destabilising irregular movements of people and undermines the concerted actions of governments and the UNHCR to provide durable solutions in countries of first asylum.

From October 1994, 695 people, largely ethnic Chinese Vietnamese from Southern China, have arrived by boat in Australia. Neither Australia nor China considers it desirable to encourage this flow of people. More importantly, information from UNHCR, the Government of China and our own representatives in southern China has shown conclusively that these people have received the protection of China since they began arriving there from Vietnam in the late 1970s. The details outlined in the statement on the prescribing of the PRC as a safe third country, which will be tabled in Parliament shortly, reveal the group in question to have been treated humanely and that every effort has been made to help them integrate socially and economically into Chinese society. To encourage the belief that simply by sailing to Australia they, and the many like them who remain in China, can undermine the resettlement efforts made on their behalf by China and the UNHCR is wrong. The Government does not believe that this in the best interests of the ethnic Chinese Vietnamese community in China and it is not in the best interests of the international community.

Australia makes a considerable effort internationally, through our overseas aid program, our significant contribution to UN peacekeeping initiatives and our assistance to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, to support efforts to help refugees return to their own country or to resettle in their country of first asylum. Where resettlement in Australia is the most appropriate approach, cases are considered in an orderly way under our Humanitarian Program, which this year will bring 13,000 people in need of resettlement to Australia to begin a new life. The irregular and illegal movement to Australia of people who have no grounds for claiming to be refugees from China undermines these and similar efforts made by the international community.

On 30 December 1994, it was announced that the Government would introduce into this session of Parliament legislation designed to ensure that, from that date, certain unauthorised arrivals from the PRC would not be allowed to gain access to Australia's refugee determination system. The announcement underlines the fact that a country may have, in fact, been a safe third country well before it has been prescribed as one by Australia. To alleviate the paradoxical situation of a country appearing to be an unsafe country one day and a safe country the next, and to avoid the possibility of a similar situation to that which we have recently found ourselves in respect of China, Australia would have to negotiate safe third country agreements with every country in the world.
The sensible alternative, clearly signalled on 30 December 1994 in the case of the boat arrivals from China, is to amend the legislation to enable Australian law to reflect the pre-existing reality.

The bill being introduced today will allow the sensible operation of the safe third country legislation by ensuring that all people who have protection in a safe third country will be treated in the same way, rather than the anomalous situation that exists under present law where people from the STC who apply before a safe third country agreement is concluded are allowed to engage our protection obligations whereas those who arrive in precisely the same circumstances but after an agreement has been reached cannot.

The legislation `will not, and cannot result in people being returned to a country that is not a safe third country. No-one will be returned unless they are covered by a safe third country agreement or there has been proper examination of their claim for protection. The legislation also does not apply to anyone who has been granted a substantive visa or to whom it has been determined Australia owes protection obligations before the safe third country regulation takes effect.

It should also be noted that the Minister retains a non-compellable discretion to allow a person's application to remain valid despite this legislation if the Minister judges that to be in the public interest.

This bill seeks to make Australia's contribution to international efforts to reduce the large-scale illegal movement of people effective and consistent. Its main effect will be to eliminate inconsistencies in the way people are dealt with under the safe third country provisions of the Migration Act who are in all respects the same, other than in the date they arrived in Australia. It contains a very effective safety net to ensure that people affected by it are either returned to a prescribed safe third country or allowed into our refugee determination system.
I commend this bill to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum and move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
This bill has two purposes, both of which relate to the need to protect the integrity and effectiveness of Australia's refugee determination system.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill's first purpose is to ensure that the fertility control policies of the government of a foreign country are disregarded in determining if a non-citizen is a member of a particular social group within the meaning of the Refugee Convention as amended by the Refugee Protocol for the purposes of considering an application for a protection visa.

Australia was among the first to sign the Refugees Convention, and the Migration Act and our refugee determination system reflect the seriousness with which we take our obligations under the Convention. The Convention states that a refugee is a person who has a well-founded fear of being persecuted for reasons of race, religion, nationality, political opinion or membership of a particular social group. A commonly used example of the kind of social group the Convention had in mind is that of the Kulaks of the then USSR who were persecuted because they were a land owning class which the Government of the day wished to eradicate.

Useful though the ground of social group undoubtedly is, it is also the most difficult to define in practice. Assessment of whether a claimant is a member of a particular social group is usually left to those who administer and review our refugee determination system. However, the implication of the recent Federal Court judgement that a person may be recognised as a member of a particular social group simply because he or she is a person to whom the fertility control policy of a foreign government applies, or who objects to such a policy, has such potentially serious consequences that the Government has decided to introduce the current bill.

The Government considers that the recent judgement distorts the meaning of the Convention ground of particular social group to such a degree that the integrity and effectiveness of Australia's refugee determination system would be threatened if it were allowed to stand.

To regard a large proportion of the population of China, or any country, as a social group and therefore as potential refugees simply on the basis of their government's fertility control policy is inconsistent with the intention of the Convention to provide protection to refugees with a well founded fear of persecution.

In introducing this legislation I emphasise that the Government is not questioning that the Convention ground of particular social group is a useful and necessary concept. Indeed the Government is seeking to bring the application of this concept into line with our international obligations following the recent Federal Court decision.

I also wish to make it clear that this bill will not deny access to our protection to a person who seeks it as a member of a particular pre-existing social group, or on any of the other Convention grounds, who has a well founded fear of persecution because of fertility control policies. What this means is that a person from a particular village or workplace who is subjected to the rogue application of a fertility control policy in a manner which amounts to persecution could still have a claim accepted under the legislation introduced today. Nor will a person who is a member of a particular religious, political or racial group subject to the persecutory application of fertility control policies be denied consideration of their claims under this legislation.

The Government is concerned to address issues which might arise from gender based persecution and has been working actively in this area for some time. For instance our Humanitarian Program contains a specific women at risk component which targets resettlement assistance to refugee women in particularly vulnerable situations.

However, the Government is concerned to ensure that the Convention is interpreted correctly. This will ensure the retention of public commitment to our refugee determination system and the integrity and effectiveness of that system. Incorrectly diluting the meaning of particular social group under the Convention has the potential to undermine that public confidence and the ability of our determination system to do the job it was set up to do—to afford protection to genuine refugees.

The legislation introduced today will help provide a common sense approach to the definition of a particular social group under the Convention by precluding the possibility of very large numbers of people with nothing in common but that they may be affected in some way by the fertility control policies of their government being caught within the definition of a social group under the Convention.

The second purpose of the bill introduced today is to prevent a non citizen from making further applications for a protection visa when they have already made an application, whether or not the prior application has been finally determined.

Australia operates one of the most thorough, efficient and equitable refugee determination systems in the world. A person's claim is assessed against the Convention definition of a refugee, and if it is not accepted at the primary stage, the person may appeal to the independent Refugee Review Tribunal which may reverse the primary decision. If a person's claim is still not accepted at the RRT stage, it is open to that person to seek review on administrative law grounds from the Federal Court.

Under current legislation, when a person has exhausted this process, it is not difficult for them to lodge another application for a protection visa and start the whole process again. The fact that repeat applications serve to delay the removal from Australia of the applicant has led to their increased use. The processing of these repeat applications, which like the initial application are free of charge to the applicant, is both expensive and time consuming.

When a system is fair, open and contains the right to appeal the primary decision, claimants will generally have no need to repeat the whole process to get a fair hearing. That fair hearing is amply provided by the system as it exists already. The bill introduced today therefore will have the effect of barring repeat applications in the majority of cases. Its intention in doing so is to protect the integrity of, and support for Australia's refugee determination system and to ensure that available resources are expended on claims for protection which have not yet been exhaustively assessed.

In introducing this bar on repeat applications, the Government is aware that there will remain circumstances in which particular repeat applications may merit consideration. These cases are likely to include repeat applications which contain information which was not available to the claimant during the course of the first application, and which is of a nature that is likely to have a real bearing on the assessment of the need for protection. Events in the country of origin of the claimant that have occurred since the first claim may also mean that a second consideration is warranted. The Government has therefore decided that the Minister will retain a discretion to allow particular repeat applications to be assessed by the full refugee determination process.

Although the Minister's non-compellable discretion may only be exercised by the Minister personally, measures will be taken to ensure that all cases in which the Minister might wish to exercise his or her discretion are identified and brought to the Minister's attention. In such cases the Minister will present to Parliament the reasons for the exercise of his or her discretion.

Both aspects of the bill introduced today demonstrate the Government's resolve to maintain a refugee determination system that is targeted towards those with a claim to Australia's protection under our Refugee Convention obligations. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has estimated that there are some twenty million refugees in the world today. Australia has an obligation to help these people through the most effective means at our disposal. We meet this obligation through our overseas aid program, our assistance to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, our significant contribution to UN peacekeeping initiatives, our Humanitarian Program, which this year will bring 13,000 people in need of resettlement to Australia to begin a new life, and through our on-shore refugee determination system.
When the need arises to defend these efforts and to maintain their credibility, public support and effectiveness, as in the present case, the Government will do so.
I commend this bill to the chamber.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, on behalf of the President I present the following report of the Auditor-General which was presented to the President since the last sitting of the Senate pursuant to the order of 13 February 1991:

EMPHASIS.TAB: Report No. 17 of 1994-95—National Media Liaison Service: a loophole in accountability?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to comment on this very important, albeit very brief, report of the Auditor-General. There has been very widespread concern in the community about the capacity of this government to use taxpayer funds for partisan political purposes.

PARA.TAB: This report indicates that the Auditor-General sought to carry out an efficiency audit of the National Media Liaison Service. The 1 1/2 pages of the report indicate that the government and the service blocked the efficiency audit. In other words, the Auditor-General was not allowed to assess the efficiency of the work that is carried out by the National Media Liaison Service—more commonly referred to as aNiMaLS. This is a very serious matter which has come before the chamber and which has been brought to our attention by the Auditor-General.

The role and functions of the National Media Liaison Service were set out some years ago by Senator Bolkus. The first role was to provide accurate and timely information on government policies and programs to the media throughout Australia, as well as information on policies to interest groups within electorates.

The second role was that representatives in each of the state capitals, Darwin and Townsville should cooperate with ministerial staff to coordinate media arrangements but not have any direct responsibility for arranging itineraries. The third role was that state representatives are to provide local members of all parties with details of government programs.

The fourth role specified was that representatives will not work with local or state party branches and will not be involved in party programs, nor electoral campaigning. The fifth role was to coordinate the distribution of detailed information on government policies—and I stress that it is government policies—and programs from the information units of various departments to local media. The final role was to monitor local media to provide media summaries. Monitoring, however, was stated as being secondary in importance to media to achieve information dissemination.

We know that, whatever the role specified there, the NMLS in fact carries out work that is very substantially different. It costs the taxpayer $1.5 million. The essential work of the National Media Liaison Service is not, I believe, to inform the public about the activities of the Labor government but to monitor and analyse the work of the opposition. It is no wonder that the Auditor-General was very savage in his report about the blocking of an efficiency audit. The last thing the government wanted was for the Auditor-General to look at the books and to look at the work that has been carried out in this unit.

I give notice that I shall be calling before a Senate estimates committee on Friday the director of the National Media Liaison Service, Mr Epstein, so that he can explain to the Senate just what work he has been carrying out. We intend to pursue this with vigour. The government has set out the role of the National Media Liaison Service, but we know from what the press says and we know from the activities of NMLS that it is carrying out a very different role indeed.

It is interesting that the West Australian of Tuesday 17 January 1995, after this report was tabled, ran an editorial headed: `Time to axe partisan media unit'. I wonder if Mr Epstein, in his monitoring of the media, circulated that to the press gallery. I wonder if he circulated it to ministers of the government. Among other things, the editorial in the West Australian stated:

SPEECH.PARA: If the Keating Government was serious about saving public money and enhancing the integrity of the political process at the same time it would move immediately to scrap the National Media Liaison Service.

PARA.TAB: Abolition of the service—which is little more than a taxpayer-funded propaganda unit—would remove a blot that has perverted the nation's political system for too long.
And saving the $1.5 million it costs to run the service each year would be a small contribution to the big cuts that the Government needs to make in its spending. . .

SPEECH.PARA: I put it to the Senate that there is continuing a serious misuse of public funding. We all remember the infamous sports rorts affair. We remember a number of multicultural grants being made before the 1990 election which were never announced to the wider community. We know the ability of this government to use funds it compulsorily raises from taxpayers for party political purposes. If the government wants to have a taxpayer funded unit, a taxpayer funded hit-squad, to attack the opposition, then let it come out and say that that is what it is doing and let us have a debate on that issue. But the government should not pretend that it is a government information unit.

PARA.TAB: As I said, I give notice that we in the opposition will be pursuing this matter with vigour at the estimates committee to find out precisely what Mr Epstein and his mates in the unit have in fact been doing and what sorts of files they are collecting—not on government information but on people in the opposition: leaders and senior shadow ministers. I seek leave to incorporate in Han-
