TALK.START.PARA: —The National Media Liaison Service is not the only media arm of the government. It has also the Ministerial Media Group, which has some 12 to 15 employees. So there is a very extensive use of taxpayer funding to attempt to promote government activities, and much of the group's work seems to be mainly concerned to look at the activities of the opposition.

PARA.TAB: It is clear that the government itself has been embarrassed and has hidden behind the Audit Act as it stood to prevent the efficiency audit by the Auditor-General. But in the coming weeks a new audit act will be brought before this parliament. The former Auditor-General, Mr Taylor, says that he understands that this act will not provide explicitly for the performance audit mandate of the Auditor-General to extend to activities such as those of the National Media Liaison Service, but he goes on to say—I suspect he must have been told by the government itself:

SPEECH.PARA: I understand, however, that it is intended that this will be addressed by regulation only and therefore not be a central tenet in the provisions of the legislation. The accountability arrangements for all activities that involve the use of taxpayers' funds should be enshrined as a central tenet of the provisions of any new Auditor-General Act.

If, as the government has hinted, the new regulations will in the future allow an efficiency audit of the National Media Liaison Service, I am prepared to place a bet that the activities of that unit will be changed very rapidly. Files will be cleaned out and shredded to avoid any close examination of the work of this unit.

PARA.TAB: The government will have to come up-front. If it wants to use taxpayers' money, it will have to be explicit about what those funds are being used for. It will not be able to use the front of pretending to provide government information when in actual fact 23 people are employed as a political hit-squad. I hope those people understand the seriousness of this. I believe it is time this parliament took action to ensure that the accountability the Auditor-General mentioned in Report No. 17 is properly carried out.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on the Auditor-General's report on the National Media Liaison Service. I point out in opening that in the budget last year, in which the government sought to further squeeze the Auditor-General, it was the Democrats who were able to press for a wider and more comprehensive brief for the Auditor-General and also to extract from the government an undertaking that the Auditor-General's financial situation would be improved so that he could more adequately carry out his very important task. The Auditor-General is one of those individuals, one of those institutions, who actually stand between the executive government and corruption.

PARA.TAB: With that as a background, I believe the parliament must take very careful note of this report from the Auditor-General. Here we have a report from a very important servant of the parliament. He is not a servant of the executive government. He is a servant of the parliament, therefore a servant of openness, and indirectly a servant of the Australian people in general.

The Auditor-General, in his report, is informing the parliament that he is unable to undertake his duties because of barriers which, in this case, have been put up by executive government. The proposed efficiency audit of the National Media Liaison Service was to be part of a broader efficiency audit of government information and advertising. This audit was to address the economy, efficiency and effectiveness of the government's massive information and advertising activities, and we share many of the concerns that Senator Kemp has just mentioned in relation to the activities of this body.

The NMLS, or aNiMaLS as it is known in popular jargon, plays a vital role in the government's information machine. Many have long suspected that aNiMaLS is a purely political beast designed to publicise the case for re-electing the Labor government and to collect any dirt it can on the opposition through its extensive media monitoring. In using the term `opposition', we would include ourselves because we believe that the government would also be wanting to collect dirt on the Democrats, Independents and minor parties.

ANiMaLS has constantly denied this allegation, arguing that its job is to publicise government activity rather than the government per se. An efficiency audit would have been a very effective way of proving the case one way or the other, but there is the hole to which the Auditor-General refers. ANiMaLS, while paid out of government money, is not technically part of any government department. Therefore, the Auditor-General cannot conduct an efficiency audit of the service without the approval of the minister—in this case the Minister for Administrative Services, Frank Walker.

The minister's response delivered to the Australian National Audit Office in November was that the proposed review was ultra vires. He has refused to allow the auditor of public money to attest whether public money is being used efficiently and effectively. This is frankly scandalous. It highlights the urgent need to pass and to strengthen the Auditor-General bill coming before this place next week. It highlights the need for the mandate of the Auditor-General to be able to access any government body whatsoever in any of the bizarre forms that this government has created and to examine what has been done with the money.

I wish to foreshadow that the Democrats will be seeking to amend the Auditor-General bill next week to confirm the widest possible mandate for the Auditor-General. This is in line with the steps that we took last year to widen the Auditor-General's brief and also to guarantee that he had more adequate facilities to carry out his task.

The minister should not be let off the hook. The government or the Department of Finance has already agreed that organisations like aNiMaLS should be subject to efficiency audits and is drafting a regulation under the new bill to achieve this. Ignoring the question of where it should be, in regulation or in the bill proper, the fact is that after the bill comes into effect, most likely on 1 July, an efficiency audit will be possible. So the question still stands: why is the minister now denying the Auditor-General access to NMLS? What has aNiMaLS got to hide between now and 1 July?

Suggestions that were hinted at earlier, that there will be a massive shredding of documents before that occurs, may well indicate what the minister does have to hide. I call on the Minister for Administrative Services or his senior minister, the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley), to immediately authorise an efficiency audit of aNiMaLS and/or any other information or advertising agency of government not within his department but within his portfolio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the two former speakers, I join in calling upon the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker) to conduct an immediate inquiry into the National Media Liaison Service, commonly known as aNiMaLS. I refer to the Auditor-General's report No. 17 in which he states:

SPEECH.PARA: NMLS—
the body in question—

is therefore not subject to the normal accountability mechanisms in place over Government programs. As a consequence, although NMLS is fully funded by the taxpayer and its stated roles and functions are predominantly administrative in nature, its operations are not subject to the scrutiny normally associated with the expenditure of public monies.

What we have here is a grave breach of accountability of government expenditure and the operation of bodies that act at the government's direction. We also have another grave issue and that is the fact that the government is using taxpayers' money to conduct operations which are of an electoral nature. In fact, an editorial in the West Australian dated 17 January this year stated:

By sending to media groups transcripts of statements by Opposition MPs highlighting any blunders, policy or personal conflicts or other material damaging to the coalition, it has played a blatantly partisan role.

That was stated in the editorial of the West Australian earlier this month. So even sections of the press can recognise what a partisan political role this body plays at the expense of the taxpayer. In fact, on 17 January this year there was a report on this body in the West Australian which followed a previous report in that paper which had stated that aNiMaLS had assembled old video clips and a dossier damaging to John Howard in anticipation of his replacing Alexander Downer as Liberal leader.

PARA.TAB: There have been complaints before by previous Liberal leaders as to the partisan role that this body plays. The press has picked this up and has recognised that this indeed is a most serious situation. The government is pushing a propaganda line, a line which is anti-opposition or anti any opposition to it, using taxpayers' money in the process. This body scrutinises anyone who dares voice opposition to the government and sets to work exposing any conflicts or problems that opposition might have and then sends it off to the media. That is really what this body is all about.

It is outrageous that there cannot be any scrutiny by the Auditor-General of this body and its practices. It is not surprising that when the Auditor-General set out to scrutinise this body he was stopped. That any body such as this should not be subject to scrutiny by the Auditor-General is frankly outrageous. I join with previous speakers in demanding that in the interests of democracy and in the interests of accountable government there be an immediate inquiry into this matter. I ask fellow Australians to wake up and look at what the government of the day is doing. It is using taxpayers' money to pursue its own political ends via this nefarious body.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is vitally important that the people of Australia understand what is happening to the sum of $1.5 million that is dedicated from their taxes to fund the National Media Liaison Service, commonly known as aNiMaLS. That organisation employs 23 staff. What is their role and what do they do? Senator Kemp has already alluded to what they do. Senator Ellison has highlighted an example that was referred to in the West Australian and, to the best of my knowledge, in the fortnight since that article appeared the National Media Liaison Service has not attempted to deny the allegation made. Of course, we know why it was not denied—because undoubtedly it is true. ANiMaLS trades in political sleaze in an attempt to damage the opposition.

PARA.TAB: The audit office sought to inquire into the National Media Liaison Service. The scope of the proposed audit was to assess the economy, efficiency and administrative effectiveness of government information and advertising activities. What on the face of that could be more innocuous, except if you have something to hide and behind the facade of this agency a more sinister agenda is being pursued? Of course that is why the audit was refused.

In October of last year the Audit Office sought to have an interview with the National Media Liaison Office. This was declined several times; in fact, it declined to enter into any—and I underline the word `any'—discussions whatsoever. One can only speculate as to why that would be the case. Undoubtedly, it was because it was concerned as to what would be revealed.

The Audit Office then, quite properly, wrote to the minister seeking his assistance in resolving the impasse. But what happened? The minister replied on 5 December saying that the `review you propose is ultra vires the Audit Act,' and referred to a legal opinion—undoubtedly, once again obtained at taxpayers' expense to create a legal technicality behind which the government could hide and avoid an audit of the National Media Liaison Service. Of course, technically it was ultra vires. However, the new Audit Act will overcome that problem and, once it has come into force, hopefully we will get to see what this outrageous organisation has been engaging in.

One can ask why the minister has simply delayed the inevitable. Undoubtedly, the National Media Liaison Service will get the shredders working overtime to ensure that nothing is left behind which could indicate the type of work it was doing. But of course it begs the question: why didn't the minister say, `Look, technically you're not entitled to audit aNiMaLS. But I, as the responsible minister, am more than happy to have this part of my administration audited by you to confirm that it is a genuine body, to confirm to the people of Australia that the likes of Senator Kemp have been pedalling untruths about the National Media Liaison Service.' This would have been a classic opportunity for the minister to embrace an audit to show that Senator Kemp has been absolutely wrong.

But the government has not embraced that opportunity. It has run from that opportunity with its tail between its legs. It does not want an audit because the allegations being made by Senator Kemp and others are undoubtedly true and correct. Of course, as the auditor says, the National Media Liaison Service—in other words, $1.5 million of taxpayers' funds—cannot be subjected to efficiency audits under the Audit Act.

Very interestingly, today I read the Salvation Army's budget submission. I saw how the funding for the Salvation Army in certain areas had, in fact, declined over the past few years. That $1.5 million could have been much better used by the Salvation Army to keep its funding up to level rather than to fund this political propaganda machine.
The situation is, as stated in the audit report:
The Parliament, through both the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts and the Standing Committee on Finance and Administration, has expressed the view that all—

SPEECH.PARA: and I stress `all'—
Commonwealth undertakings, of whatever legal form, should be audited by the Commonwealth Auditor-General.
I have read those words from the bipartisan report of those committees. Those committees are of the view that everything ought be audited. So the Labor Party embraced that—

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't misrepresent what that report says.

—Senator Coates interjects and says to me, `Don't misrepresent what that report says.' I was quoting from the Auditor-General's report which is currently before the parliament, and I will repeat it again for Senator Coates. It states:

PARA.TAB: The Parliament, through both the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts and the Standing Committee on Finance and Administration, has expressed the view that all Commonwealth undertakings, of whatever legal form, should be audited by the Commonwealth Auditor-General.

SPEECH.PARA: They are not the words of Senator Abetz; they are the words of the Auditor-General. So Senator Coates, in his fanatical defence of the National Media Liaison Service—which organisation these people use for their political purposes in seeking to destroy us—will undoubtedly give us a great explanation as to why the Auditor-General got it wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not by private auditors; that was the point of the report.
—You missed the point, John.

—I think Senator Kemp is quite right; Senator Coates often misses the point. Clearly, government senators are very concerned about this, and the commencement of interjections from the other side clearly indicates they are very nervous. So they ought be. Whilst they might have been able to stymie the Auditor-General, I would not think them able to stymie the Senate estimates committee process. The Senate estimates committee has the power to call before it certain individuals and, in fact, ask them how they spend the day and who tells them what to do—who told them to develop this video of John Howard clips from the past; who gave them that direction; and how is that of assistance to the people of Australia?

PARA.TAB: We know that it may be of some assistance in the Labor Party's desperate attempt to hold on to office. But we know that, with the leadership change and the way the Liberal Party is performing now, we will see a change in government. No matter what attempts the Labor Party makes through this sleazy National Media Liaison Service, which it will not subject to audit, we will still win, we will still beat it. The reason for that is that the people of Australia are starting to see through the way this government acts. As former Senator Richardson said, the Labor Party will do whatever it takes; no matter how immoral, no matter how amoral, it will do whatever it takes. When it comes to a question of public accountability of $1.5 million, it will hide behind a legal technicality to protect its propaganda machine. But the people of Australia are now aware of the sorts of campaigns being undertaken by the Labor Party, and that is why they will reject it at the next poll.

This Auditor-General's report is, quite frankly, a very sad reflection on the way this government operates. Whilst there is a legal technicality, which I trust will be overcome by the new Audit Act, I would have thought the government could have shown good faith by saying to the Auditor-General and the people of Australia, `Look, there is a legal technicality, but we don't mind that legal technicality; we will not rely on it. We invite you to audit the National Media Liaison Service and see what it really gets up to.' But the government did not want that, and the reason for that is very clear.

This report is a very sad reflection on this government's commitment to public accountability, its commitment to integrity. In fact, the government's reaction—as demonstrated by the Labor Party interjections during this debate—clearly confirms the very worst fears of many Australians; that is, that the National Media Liaison Service is not a dinky-di organisation but simply a front for the Australian Labor Party to pedal its propaganda.

I look forward to Senator Kemp's investigations at the Senate estimates committees and to hearing some of the alleged media advisers within that organisation explain how they really do fill in their day, what their tasks are and how they benefit the people of Australia. This report really deserves much greater prominence because it highlights the politically corrupt way the government goes about its business.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate can well ask: what has the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Frank Walker, got to hide? We have to recognise that it is not just a loophole in the law that has enabled this spying, cheating organisation financed by the taxpayer but directed by this government to escape the scrutiny that all bodies spending taxpayers' money should be subjected to. Everyone accepts that proposition, which is stated in the amending Audit Bill which has not yet passed this chamber.

PARA.TAB: This is a matter of principle that the government accepts should be enshrined in law and yet, because there is a loophole in law at the present time, this organisation, which is a disgrace and which has demonstrated itself to be a propaganda arm of the Labor Party, not of the government, is spending an inordinate amount of its time eavesdropping on opposition statements and operating in a political way. For example, as we have heard it has drummed up a video of Mr Howard's past statements. This organisation is being protected from proper scrutiny, as I said not by a loophole in the law but by a decision of a minister of this government, Frank Walker.

Mr Frank Walker has the power to allow the Auditor-General, as it does with every other body, to conduct a proper investigation of the National Media Liaison Service. He has refused that permission. He has decided to block the Auditor-General from investigating the expenditure of $1 1/2 million by a dishonest, crooked organisation that was appointed by a dishonest, crooked government for dishonest, crooked purposes.

Why would the minister make that personal ministerial decision? Is it because the minister does not support the principle that this government is now pursuing that all expenditure should be subject to audit? Does this minister have something to hide, or does it fit into the pattern of deception by this minister in his dealings with this parliament of which so many of us are well aware. I am certainly aware of this because of his disgraceful responses to my requests to have my electorate office in Wollongong moved after the lease expired to an area near my principal place of residence.

This minister will do or say anything in pursuit of political power. When he exercises his discretion, he invariably comes down on the side of self-interest rather than in the interests of this nation. Here we have yet another example. Perhaps he is following the `honourable' tradition of the previous ministers who have been in charge of this disgraceful body. We had Mr J.J. Brown, a former member of the House of Representatives, who `resigned'. We have had a self-confessed professional liar called Richardson.

We have had some people in that role whose activities are beyond reproach, but they are the exceptions. The minister at the table, the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan), is one such minister. I do not think anyone here would direct the sorts of remarks I am directing to the other occupants of that office to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Too generous?

—But I would not be so generous in respect of Madam Whiteboard, who had her claws in this matter for a while. There was Senator Bolkus, and the less said about him in this context the better. We have a tradition of ministers, obviously appointed by a government, whose main objective is to misuse taxpayers' money through this organisation in a disgraceful way. The government has picked people to run or to have administrative control over the organisation who, in general, it feels will operate in a blatant and dishonest political way.

PARA.TAB: That is what this debate is all about today. This government has chosen to misuse taxpayers' money in this way. It has chosen to misuse the minister's discretion in this way so that the minister can block a proper inquiry of the expenditure of this money. There is a deliberate pattern of deception and deceit, but we expect that from this government.

We have to recognise that an efficiency audit is not just an audit to determine whether this organisation is being efficient. It is an examination of whether it is properly spending taxpayers' money and whether the pattern of its expenditures relates to its objectives and its directions on how it should be spending its money and what it should be doing. We have already heard about the role of the National Media Liaison Service. There is hardly any evidence that justifies this organisation spending its time spying on the opposition or creating videos of past speeches of the new opposition leader.

Naturally, an efficiency audit would determine whether this body is spending money in the manner which is appropriate to its creation. The fact clearly emerges, as a result of the refusal by this minister to allow this inquiry, that money is being improperly spent. Part of the $1 1/2 million—we do not know how much—being spent by the National Media Liaison Service is being improperly spent.

This raises another interesting question. It was the Attorney-General's Department that told the minister that, in its opinion, the Audit Act did not in fact cover efficiency audits of this body. It seems unfortunate that all the Audit Office had to rely on was advice from the Attorney-General's Department. There was a clear conflict of interest within the Attorney-General's Department. I do not know what sort of glass walls they have there. If the Auditor-General had the right to seek independent legal advice, I wonder whether it would have been the same as the advice that the Attorney-General's office gave to the minister. After all, I suppose you can say that it is the minister and the ministry that employ the Attorney-General, not the Auditor-General.

If the advice did have any partisan elements, to what extent would the best interests of the client, the Auditor-General, be served by the Attorney-General's Department, bearing in mind its relationship with the minister, rather than with the Auditor-General? Whatever the merits of the advice, we have a simple situation where the government has deliberately blocked the proper inquiry that is appropriate and relevant and accepted for every other government body.

I raise in passing an interesting question. According to the answer to a question asked by Senator Calvert last year, it was said that the cost of the National Media Liaison Service in New South Wales was $140,558, of which 84 per cent was involved in wages and salaries.

Animals is located in the central business district of Sydney in fairly substantial office space. It would surprise me, in view of the likely cost of that office space, that 84 per cent of the $140,000 spent in New South Wales related only to wages and salaries. I wonder what would be the costs of equipment, maintenance and so on. I wonder what the hidden costs are of aNiMaLS that are not revealed in this document. I wonder what—

TALK.START.PARA: —Their location in this parliament.

—The location in this parliament—I acknowledge the interjection. That is exactly another issue. What is the real cost, as against the hidden cost, of aNiMaLS? There is one thing about the Auditor-General. He would certainly have pursued the question of cross-subsidies, hidden costs, deals and backdoor operations done by this government with aNiMaLS.

PARA.TAB: It is a matter of some significance that raising this question was one of the last acts of Mr J. C. Taylor, the Auditor-General, before he took early retirement because of his disgust with this government. It seems to me to be of some substance and significance that one of his last acts was to point out the impropriety of the government, the disgraceful behaviour of the minister and the mismanagement of taxpayers' money by the National Media Liaison Service. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I am not sure whether to thank you for your very strict enforcement of standing orders or thank the minister for his indulgence; I will have to get that clarified later on. I wish to speak briefly about an ILO convention which has been tabled, not in the Senate today but since the last day of sitting. This is the ILO convention No. 174 and recommendation No. 181 entitled Prevention of major industrial accidents.

PARA.TAB: Mr Acting Deputy President, as you will be aware, I have been very concerned about the lack of involvement of the parliament of this nation in the consideration of the treaty-making activities of this government. There have been many cases where multilateral conventions, UN treaties and conventions, have been signed, as well as ILO conventions which have been done, without any proper consideration by the parliament or without any public debate.

Often some years down the track we find that under international law Australia is bound to act in a certain manner. Of course, the most dramatic example of that was really the discovery by many Australians that, for the first time since 1986, Australian domestic disputes could be adjudicated offshore by UN human rights committees. I have expressed my concern a number of times in this parliament that such an important decision was taken by the executive without any significant public debate or any wider consideration of the long-term ramifications of such an action.

Equally, in relation to the ILO, this is a tripartite body—a body which I think over a long period of time has generally enjoyed the support of unions, industry and governments. Regrettably, I think, because of the actions of the Keating government and the industrial relations ministers and the secret treaty making of the government, that tripartite and bipartisan approach to the ILO has come under very severe pressure.

Just before the last election, the Keating government ratified ILO convention No. 158, concerning the retrenchment of employees, without making a press release. We discovered after the election that Mr Keating and his colleagues had ratified this convention hours before the writs were issued. This convention, along with a number of others, provided a head of power for the so-called Industrial Relations Reform Act, which in itself has now been challenged before the ILO. But the point of me drawing this to the attention of the Senate today is that I have not had time to closely examine the convention, which has been put before us today, and whether there are ramifications of this which would require more careful consideration.

I note that it has gone to state officials and that the ACTU is supportive of the convention but, interestingly, Mr Brereton tells us that the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry is supportive of the development of a national standard `described below'. It is not clear from what Mr Brereton tells us in this document whether the ACCI is supportive of the ratification of the convention. If it is not, it would have been handy for Mr Brereton to actually inform the Senate why it is not supportive. I put that question. It is one to which I would be interested to receive an answer.

I was intrigued to read in the background statement tabled by Mr Brereton that `in accordance with article 19 of the ILO constitution the Australian government is required to submit the text of new conventions and recommendations to the competent authority—that is, the Australian parliament—following their adoption by the International Labour Conference'. I would be intrigued to know whether that practice was followed with ILO Convention No. 158? If that practice was not followed, what flowed from that? I will be seeking further advice on this matter.

It is important that this parliament consider very carefully international treaties and conventions which the executive government goes off and signs. A number of UN multilateral conventions have had quite profound effects upon the legal system of this country. Although I welcome the fact that the text has been signed and that the minister has given us a covering statement, I think the ratification of this convention raises important questions for this parliament, such as: what is the position of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I rise to support my colleague Senator Kemp. I wish to make some observations about international conventions and what I term their misuse by this Australian government in particular in setting domestic law. I draw the attention of the Senate to Senator McMullan's questioning of our right—if I can put it that way—to address that issue at this time and question what the procedure should be. The third paragraph of the background statement of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) reads:

SPEECH.PARA: In accordance with Article 19 of the ILO Constitution, the Australian Government is required to submit the texts of new Conventions and Recommendations to the competent authority, that is, the Australian Parliament, following their adoption by the International Labour Conference.

One complaint I hear constantly is that these conventions are not dealt with by the parliament in a proper manner. We get these conventions delivered to us. They have already been agreed to, and that is it. Even when they are tabled here, our right to examine them and question them is challenged. It provides some insight into the arrogant attitude of this government when it comes to these types of conventions.

PARA.TAB: I can well and truly understand having international treaties and international conventions between two nations for defence reasons, trade reasons or a whole variety of reasons. But I can never understand why they have to be used to establish domestic law and, in particular, to override the constitutional rights and authority of the states.

Many of the conventions of this country have been overridden and overruled by legislation carried through this place in recent years. I find that absolutely and totally untenable. It is unsatisfactory. In fact, it is wrong. Sooner or later this whole situation has to be resolved. I am damned if I can live with a situation where people in Geneva or elsewhere determine what happens in the parliament of this country. That is what has been happening. I must mention that it was just over 12 months that we dealt with the Industrial Relations Reform Bill, which relied very heavily on conventions.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was passed by this parliament.

—That bill relied very heavily on conventions which were not passed by this parliament. They were used by this parliament to override the rights of the state. Where has it got us? We now have at least three cases—if not more—in the High Court of this country. That is where it has got us. It is being challenged. We have an enormous wastage of resources. The way that you people have behaved is a lawyer's dream. Today, you challenged our right to even discuss it in this place.
—If you don't know what you're talking about, don't say anything.

—I know exactly what I am talking about because I was watching what you did. I heard what you said. I know what you were trying to do. You were trying to prevent us from raising this issue in this place.
—That is a lie.
—That is not a lie.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! Minister, you are well aware of the standing orders. Would you withdraw that remark.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is also a standing order about imputing improper motives, which he just did. I do not care; he can say what he likes about me, but he cannot seek the defence of the standing orders when he is breaching them. I do not care what he says about me. I have never sought to have anything withdrawn. I do not care. But he cannot breach the standing orders and then seek their defence. He is telling untruths about me. He totally misunderstood what I was doing—everybody else in the chamber knew—which was to allow proper process for these conventions to be discussed, not an abuse of the process.
—Minister, I am concerned with the language and I ask you to withdraw that particular remark.
—Of course I will withdraw, but I have to say that he cannot breach the standing orders and then seek to use them.

—We have just seen a further abuse by a minister of the standing orders of this place. It does not worry me whether or not Senator McMullan calls me a liar. A colleague of mine said to me, `If you get this over in about seven minutes, you'll get away with it.' The fact is that this government has consistently misused international conventions to override the rights of the states and this place in a manner which is not in the best interests of Australia. It suits the lawyers of the country. It keeps the High Court of this country occupied. Until we get a process where these conventions are properly examined and dealt with in the best interests of Australia, we will continue to see legislation being passed on the basis of conventions being challenged in the High Court. That is fact; it is not myth. It is happening right here and now in this place.

PARA.TAB: I do not object to some of the material in the conventions. I object to the fact that they are not brought into this place and debated

SPEECH.PARA: properly so that a decision can be made by the Australian parliament as to what we should be agreeing to internationally. It is a total abuse of the sovereignty of this country. I will conclude my comments at this point. I will continue to pursue this issue of having a proper process for as long as I can. No convention should be agreed to unless it has the approval of both the houses of parliament of this nation.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

BREAST CANCER SCREENING AND TREATMENT IN AUSTRALIA
MINISTER FOR HUMAN SERVICES AND HEALTH
Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
5 December 1994
Senator Sue West
Chairperson
Standing Committee on Community Affairs
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2601
Dear Senator
Please find enclosed the response of the Government to the report of the Senator Standing Committee on Community Affairs of 9 June 1994 on the above matter.

The report of the Committee is a substantial record of progress and opinion on breast cancer screening in Australia as it was in 1993. It has been a useful exercise in reviewing the implementation of the National Program for the Early Detection of Breast Cancer and in identifying areas for further development.
The Government accepts or supports the great majority of the recommendations.
Yours sincerely
Dr Carmen Lawrence
FORWORD
On 27 May 1993 the issue of breast cancer screening and treatment in Australia was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs.
The terms of reference of the inquiry were to examine:
Breast cancer screening and treatment in Australia with particular reference to:
(a)the current state of the National Program for the Early Detection of Breast Cancer;
(b)cost efficiency of the screening program;
(c)Commonwealth/State funding;
(d)organisation of screening and treatment services;
(e)the availability of screening; and
(f)Medicare rebate;
with the aim of determining the optimum service for Australia.
The original reporting date of 1 March 1994 was delayed to 9 June 1994 to accommodate the high level of interest displayed.
The Committee made a total of 27 recommendations (listed at Attachment A.)

The recommendations relate to breast cancer screening, workforce issues, the collection of data, research and access to radiotherapy services. Two recommendations are concerned with biopsy and the Government is awaiting the outcome of an inquiry into the management and treatment of breast cancer being conducted by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs in relation to these.

A number of the recommendations relate to areas within the direct control of the Commonwealth. Others would require the co-operation of the States and Territories to implement, or are within their jurisdiction. All State and Territory Health Departments and the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare have been asked for comment on the Senate Committee Report. Discussions relating to workforce issues have commenced between the Commonwealth Departments of Human Services and Health, Employment Education and Training, and Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.
The Government either accepts or supports 24 of the 27 recommendations. The specific response to each recommendation follows. A summary of the responses is at Attachment B.
