EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
BACKGROUND

The Report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on Sexual Harassment in the Australian Defence Force entitled Facing the Future Together, was tabled on 25 August 1994.

The Inquiry commenced hearings on 4 February 1994 and concluded on 7 June 1994. The Committee comprised six Senators with Senator Gerry Jones as the Chairman. The Committee received 122 written submissions from individuals, including submissions from current and former Service personnel, and 16 submissions from various organisations. Evidence was heard from 57 witnesses at the public hearings, in some cases more than once. Four witnesses appeared in-camera before the Committee. The Report contains 42 Recommendations with topics ranging from re-defining policy documents and refining training and education programs, through to the severity of the censures handed down to personnel from HMAS Swan.
Terms of Reference for the Inquiry are at Appendix A, and membership of the Committee is at Appendix B.
CONTEXT

The Terms of Reference for the Committee arose out of allegations of incidents of sexual harassment that occurred in HMAS Swan during a tour of duty in South-East Asia during 1992. The most serious allegation was that of sexual assault of the female medical officer by a fellow officer. At a subsequent court martial the accused officer was acquitted.

The Committee firmly endorsed the principle of equal opportunity for women in the Australian Defence Force. The Report emphasised that, in order to achieve integration, personnel at all levels must be educated on gender-related issues. Further, Defence Force managers must have and use effective tools to manage these issues.
While dealing with and reporting first on the incidents in HMAS Swan, the Committee inquired into the nature and extent of sexual harassment throughout the Australian Defence Force.

The Committee was complimentary of the initiatives taken by the Navy after the incidents in HMAS Swan to further the integration of women and eliminate sexual harassment. However, the Committee felt that the Army and Air Force, while having plans in train, were not proceeding with the same degree of urgency and commitment evident in the Navy. Army and Air Force are affording a high priority to this issue and have developed the appropriate mechanisms and put educational programs in place. It is important that the three Services and the Australian Defence Force Academy maintain this momentum. The continuing commitment by the leaders of the Australian Defence Force is imperative if the Defence Force is to meet the challenges of integration.
SUMMARY OF THE REPORT FROM THE SENATE INQUIRY
This overview provides comments on the main themes emerging from each of the chapters of the Report.
Chapter 1—Sexual Harassment

This chapter provides a general overview of sexual harassment not only in the Australian Defence Force, but in the community as a whole. The Committee noted that under the revised definition in the Sex Discrimination Act: `it is now no longer necessary for the complainant to demonstrate disadvantage as a result of sexual harassment. The crux of the difficulty with this definition lies in the very subjective nature of the criterion itself.' The definition of sexual harassment is not clear and organisations' and individuals' perceptions may differ markedly.
Chapter 2—Sexual Harassment in the Navy

This chapter builds on the comments in chapter 1 but specifically addresses the incidence and nature of sexual harassment or sexual assault in the Navy. The Committee believes that adequate statistics were not available as many members were reluctant to complain for fear of retribution.
Chapter 3—Accommodation in HMAS Swan

This chapter acknowledges that accommodation in HMAS Swan, which carries a crew of 250, is cramped in both the working and living conditions. Modifications to the accommodation in existing vessels can be expensive and must be balanced against other factors such as their remaining time in service. This class of ship has undergone some modifications but, as they will be phased out of service at the turn of the century, extensive modifications are not economically viable.
Chapter 4—Behaviour of Officers Ashore

Chapter 4 examines the behaviour of officers from HMAS Swan during the deployment in South East-Asia, and concludes that the crew was generally well behaved, although some examples of immature behaviour were displayed.
Chapter 5—The Terms of Reference of the Board of Inquiry

A Board of Inquiry was established primarily to investigate allegations of sexual harassment against a female Reserve medical officer, Dr Carole Wheat, by fellow officers. This chapter looks at whether the Terms of Reference of the Board of Inquiry were sufficient to enable it to consider any aspects of unacceptable behaviour that occurred on board HMAS Swan.
Chapter 6—Recommendations of the Board of Inquiry

This chapter addresses the many recommendations made by the Board of Inquiry including: the censuring of the four individuals in Swan; gender issues; sexual harassment of junior sailors; management styles; and Defence Instructions on the management of sexual harassment in the Australian Defence Force. Eleven of the 42 Recommendations are covered in this chapter.
Chapter 7—Disciplinary and Administrative Action Taken

This chapter closely analyses the mechanisms within the Australian Defence Force for maintaining good order and discipline. It questions whether the administrative action taken against individuals named in the Board of Inquiry was appropriate and relates this action to the Recommendations of the Board.
Chapter 8—The Court Martial

This chapter deals with the appropriateness of the decisions made as part of determining whether sexual assault charges should be laid, and a court martial convened, in reference to an officer serving in HMAS Swan in 1992.
Chapter 9—Integration of Women in the Navy

As women moved into more non-traditional areas of employment, each of the Services was able to determine how and at what speed to proceed with the integration of women within its ranks. Chapter 9 examines the content and the timing of directives from the Government in relation to the integration of women into the Navy, with particular reference to sea going appointments, and the actions taken by the Government relating to the Board of Inquiry.
Chapter 10—The Navy's Response to Sexual Harassment

This chapter addresses the appropriateness of actions taken by the Navy subsequent to the establishment of the Board of Inquiry, to address the issue of sexual harassment on Navy ships. It considers in detail the range of initiatives set in place to manage sexual harassment.
Chapter 11—The Good Working Relationships Project

The long-term aim of this program is to bring about cultural change within the Navy. Because the focus of this program is on interpersonal relationships in the workplace, the effects of the Good Working Relationships project will be more evident in five to ten years time. This chapter addresses the Term of Reference which requires the Committee to evaluate the Good Working Relationships project being undertaken by the Navy. Nine of the 42 Recommendations are found in this chapter.
Chapter 12—Sexual Harassment in the Australian Defence Force

The Committee's Terms of Reference required it to examine the nature and extent of sexual harassment in the Army and Air Force. This chapter addresses many issues ranging from the culture of the Australian Defence Force, Defence policy and responsibilities of senior managers, through to community attitudes.
STRUCTURE OF THE RESPONSE

The Senate Inquiry's Terms of Reference focused primarily on sexual harassment in the Navy, however, the incidents in HMAS Swan have served as a catalyst to focus the Australian Defence Force's attention and efforts to address gender issues and sexual harassment in particular.

Each Service is responsible for implementing the policies and initiatives that apply to the Australian Defence Force as a whole and in accordance with its operational requirements. Consequently, the Response explains the different approaches taken by each Service and the Australian Defence Force Academy to the recommendations.
The Response follows in sequence the 42 Recommendations. Some of these have multiple parts, hence there are 66 separate components.
Overall, of the 66 components of the Recommendations, 53 are supported, four are supported in principle, five are supported in part, two are not supported, and two are under examination.
The Recommendations that are:
supported in principle are—11, 16, 39Vb, 39VIa;
supported in part are—3, 9, 10, 14 and 39IIIa;
not supported are—1, 2; and
under examination are—27 and 39Va.
RESPONSES TO RECOMMENDATIONS
Recommendation 1
The Committee recommends that the definition of sexual harassment under the Sex Discrimination Act be redefined to reflect more clearly
the hierarchy of complaints;
the advantage, where possible, of the complainant informing the alleged harasser that his or her behaviour is offensive;
the appropriate mechanisms and legal sanctions for the different degrees of seriousness of the unlawful behaviour
RESPONSE
Not Supported
The Government does not consider that amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act are necessary or appropriate.
Recommendation 1 (point 1 and point 3)
It appears that the bases for this recommendation are:
the Committee's concern that the broad nature of the definition creates uncertainty, in so far as it could encompass an extremely wide range of behaviour; and
the Committee's concern that the subjective element of the test is relied upon too heavily in the determination of a complaint (paragraphs 1.28 and 1.33).

The current definition of sexual harassment was drafted to reflect Government policy which is that, in determining whether sexual harassment has occurred, there is a need to consider the complainant's perception of what has occurred, balanced against a test of what a reasonable person in all the circumstances would have anticipated (Explanatory memorandum to the Sex Discrimination and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1992). This test provides the flexibility which is necessary to accommodate the wide range of behaviours capable of constituting sexual harassment. It also permits the assessment of individual cases on their merits, taking into account all surrounding circumstances.

Government policy is that the complainant's perception (the subjective element of the test) is relevant to determining whether sexual harassment has occurred. Whether a person feels sexually harassed will depend on circumstances particular to that individual (for example, age, sex, race, culture and relationship to the alleged harasser). This is reflected in the words "in all the circumstances". To ignore the complainant's perception of the conduct in question fails to acknowledge the often devastating effect on a complainant of sexual harassment and the differential effect of particular conduct on different complainants.

The proposal to establish a hierarchy of complaints (Recommendation 1—point 1) with a corresponding delineation of the appropriate mechanisms and legal sanctions for the different degrees of seriousness of the unlawful behaviour (Recommendation 1—point 3) is at odds with current Government policy. The legislation does not currently differentiate between types of harassment because all such behaviour is based on disrespect and abuse of power. The Government has indicated that it will not tolerate sexual harassment in any form. Sexual harassment is a generic term which is capable of encompassing a wide range of behaviour. It would therefore be virtually impossible to list every type of behaviour which is capable of constituting sexual harassment. Construction of such a list would be a necessary precondition to insertion of a hierarchy of complaints.

The establishment of a hierarchy of complaints would also not take account of the differential effects on a complainant of particular behaviour. In effect, a hierarchy would operate to devalue the effects on a complainant of particular behaviour and send a message to the community that some forms of sexual harassment are of a lesser concern.

To draw a line between certain types of harassment and allocate specific sanctions to each would undermine the system of conciliation and the flexibility of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to provide a remedy that is appropriate in the circumstances. The emphasis of all the human rights legislation administered by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission is on conciliation and providing a remedy appropriate to the circumstances in question. To prescribe particular penalties for particular types of behaviour is contrary to this approach.
The Government therefore believes that it is unnecessary to amend the Sex Discrimination Act as recommended by the Senate Committee in points 1 and 3.
Recommendation 1 (point 2)

This recommendation does not take adequate account of the power differentials between the person harassed and the harasser and the effects of sexual harassment. The Recommendation appears to be based, to a certain extent, on the Committee's view that a person who is harassed should have an obligation to confront the harasser.

There are many reasons why a person who alleges sexual harassment is unwilling or unable to confront the alleged harasser; these include the effects the alleged harassment has had on the complainant and the power relationship between the parties. According to Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, the majority of persons bringing sexual harassment complaints before the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission are young women who feel unable to speak to the harasser. Women who do wish to confront the alleged harasser and have a complaint dealt with informally should be encouraged to do so, however, this is a very different proposition to the one being put forward by the Committee. The Committee's proposal has the potential to create a situation in which a complainant is required to inform the alleged harasser that his or her behaviour is offensive or to justify that the circumstances were such that it was not possible to do so, before proceeding to an outside body. The proposal may create a strong disincentive to the making of complaints and has the potential to create further legal and administrative hurdles for the complainant.
Recommendation 2

The Committee recommends that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission should investigate the proposal that the requirement under the Sex Discrimination Act for employers to take all `reasonable steps' to prevent an employee or agent from engaging in unlawful acts of sexual harassment should specify that, as one such `reasonable step', the employer should provide support, through an appropriate off-line, internal unit in the organisation (such as Sexual Harassment Contact officers) or, facilitate access to an external agency (such as the Sex Discrimination Commissioner), for the person who feels harassed to bring to the attention of an alleged harasser (directly or indirectly) that the person's behaviour is offensive, intimidating or humiliating.

Such action should be seen as different from a formal complaint alleging sexual harassment and provide an opportunity for both parties to clarify the situation and be made aware of the possible consequences if offensive behaviour continues. The purpose of the measure is to assist in resolving genuine misunderstandings before they become a major difficulty in the work relationship, particularly in situations where the person who feels harassed feels unable to prevent the offending behaviour by his or her own action alone. The measure would also simplify the resolution of a subsequent complaint, should such a complaint be formally lodged.
RESPONSE
Not Supported

The Government believes that it would be inappropriate to put such a requirement in legislation. Such detail is dealt with more appropriately in policies developed by individual employers to suit their needs.

The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission's training package for managers and supervisors on eliminating sexual harassment from the workplace encourages and points out the advantages of developing an `in house' process for dealing with sexual harassment complaints so that they can be dealt with expeditiously and less formally. The package notes the need to ensure that `in house' sexual harassment policies should always include mechanisms for informing a person alleging sexual harassment of all the options so that people can make an informed choice about how to proceed.

Additionally, it is not clear from the Recommendation whether recourse to `in house' facilities would be a precondition to the lodging of a formal complaint with an outside body. All complainants should have the option of choosing to deal with a situation of alleged harassment in a manner which is comfortable to them. They should continue to have the option to proceed directly to an outside agency or attempt to resolve the situation in accordance with internal policies and procedures for dealing with sexual harassment.

The Australian Defence Force already provides assistance through many avenues, outside the formal complaint processes, and these include toll-free telephone numbers, Sexual Harassment Contact Officers, Equal Employment Opportunity Coordinators, Student Counsellors and access to mediators through a conflict resolution process which may include the involvement of external consultants.
Recommendation 3

The Committee recommends that Navy pay greater attention to the in-port activities of its personnel to gain the maximum benefit from these visits while minimising the potential for unacceptable behaviour. The Committee recommends that ships' officers, in conjunction with the Australian Defence or diplomatic representatives in the countries to be visited, identify possible suitable cultural, sporting and social in-port activities and make the arrangements for interested crew members to participate. This function could best be undertaken by officers, such as doctors and chaplains, who are responsible for the health and well-being of the crew.
RESPONSE
Supported in Part
The Government supports the principle of maximising the benefit of Navy ship visits to other countries.

Australian diplomatic representatives are consulted routinely about the program and activities for individual Navy ship visits to their countries of accreditation. The arrangements take account of host country culture and of the recreational facilities and opportunities available to the ship's company. Program activities typically involve a range of sporting fixtures and access to local recreational facilities. Particularly, in developing countries, members of the ships' companies frequently undertake valued civic action projects such as maintenance work or improvements in schools and health clinics.
The recommendations of the Senate Inquiry have been conveyed to relevant overseas posts requesting that they take particular account of this Recommendation in the future planning of Navy ship visits.

The visiting ship through the designated Visits Officer, appointed by the Commanding Officer, establishes early and continuous liaison with the local Naval Agent or Australian representative in preparing the program for the visit. This formal program of `suitable cultural, sporting and social' activities is arranged consistent with the length of the port visit. Organised activities for a particular port are promulgated to the ship's company well in advance of the date of arrival to facilitate selection of sporting teams, arrangement of tours and registration of interest in other activities.

Commanding Officers are responsible for the health and well-being of their subordinates. Visits Officers may be appointed from any branch including medical, dental or chaplains. However, medical officers are not well placed to undertake this task because port visits usually involve increased demands on a medical officer treating patients of ships in convoy or making arrangements for specialist reviews and tests with local medical facilities that are unavailable in a ship at sea.
The Navy stresses the importance of arranging appropriate in-port activities at Commanding Officer and Executive Officer designate courses.

The Army and Air Force will continue to liaise with Australian military, civilian as well as local community representatives for recreational, cultural and welfare purposes, both within Australia and whilst deployed overseas.
Recommendation 4

The Committee recommends that care be taken to ensure that the choice of legal counsel appointed by Navy, Army and Air Force to assist with multiple inquiries or legal proceedings into the same or related matters does not give rise to perceptions of possible conflict of interest.
RESPONSE
Supported

The Defence Instruction relating to inquiries into `Matters Affecting the Defence Force' will be amended to give guidance on the appointment of counsel to assist Boards of Inquiry. The guiding principle is that counsel will not be appointed to appear in Military Courts or to assist Boards of Inquiry or other tribunals if the involvement of counsel will reasonably give the perception to any interested party that the appointment could cause a conflict of interest.
Recommendation 5

The Committee recommends that the Defence Instructions covering Inquiries into Matters Affecting the Defence Force be amended to include a requirement, in the case of an inquiry into personnel matters such as sexual harassment, to inform all witnesses, including those who are not directly the subject of recommendations, of their status at the conclusion of the inquiry. Consideration should also be given to advising all those directly involved in an inquiry of the outcome of any action taken pursuant to the inquiry as soon as possible after decisions on the implementation of the inquiry's recommendations have been made.
RESPONSE
Supported

The Defence Force considers it appropriate, in the case of an inquiry into personnel matters, to inform all witnesses of their status and the outcome of the inquiry in relation to matters relevant to them. It is intended that the Appointing Authority for the inquiry will provide witnesses with this information as soon as possible after decisions on the findings of the inquiry have been made. The relevant Defence Instruction will be amended to provide necessary guidance.
Recommendation 6

The Committee recommends that supervisors be clearly instructed and required to record in writing whether a performance assessment of an individual is based on a short period providing limited opportunities for observation of the performance of that individual.
RESPONSE
Supported

Performance appraisal is an integral part of the Australian Defence Force's personnel management policy. Performance appraisal is based on principles of honesty and integrity and provides the primary tool by which personnel are selected for promotion and career progression. They also provide feedback to individuals about their performance. By definition any performance appraisal requires a subjective assessment to be made about the performance and ability of subordinates. However, each Service has clear and comprehensive guidelines setting out the methodology and the responsibility in raising a performance appraisal report.

In the Australian Defence Force officers and enlisted members are observed for a minimum period before a performance appraisal report may be rendered. This observation period varies from three to six months depending on the Service involved.
Recommendation 7

The Committee recommends that a special effort be made to ensure that all qualified entry personnel be given sufficient information to understand the regulations governing public employment in the Defence Force and Navy's way of applying those regulations to its organisation.
RESPONSE
Supported

Present Navy policy is that qualified entry officers will not be posted to sea until they have completed the full new entry program. Qualified entry officers receive advice from Navy Office as well as individual career counselling during their initial training course. This advice is under review to ensure that the regulations governing public employment in the Defence Force, and the Navy's way of applying those regulations to its organisation, is comprehensively covered. Additionally, the contents of literature for prospective applicants covering such issues, as conditions of service, career paths and possible sea postings, is under review.

The Army employs direct entry officers in their specialised roles. Prior to appointment, each candidate is advised, in detail, of conditions of service, likely employment prospects and a possible career path. Any additional tasks required of these officers are included in their initial training or imparted during attendance, by selected direct entry officers, at subsequent generalist or specialist courses. Army will include aspects of employment and the laws governing employment in the curriculum for the direct entry officer course.

Air Force qualified entry officers are comprehensively apprised of the conditions of employment in the Service during the recruiting and induction process. All qualified entry officers undertake courses that provide them with knowledge of the conditions applicable to their Air Force service.
Recommendation 8

The Committee recommends that Navy continue, through the Good Working Relationships program, to examine and improve all aspects of work relationships within and between the various functional groups in the Navy. In particular the Committee recommends that further detailed studies be carried out, with the assistance of expert consultants, into the impact of group dynamics on the individuals in the Navy, and on the organisation more generally, with a view to harnessing more effectively the human resources available to achieve higher standards of performance and behaviour.
RESPONSE
Supported

The nature of service life places strong emphasis on individuals contributing positively to the team of which they are a member. This will be affected by the interaction between individuals and the dynamics of the group as a whole. The Australian Defence Force takes the view that all its personnel need to be aware of how these aspects affect themselves and their colleagues.

The Navy is conducting a study into the impact of group dynamics on individuals and on the organisation. Separately, the review of the Divisional System will in part address these issues. Both Army and Air Force are examining the need for similar studies within their respective Services, and if appropriate, the Services will implement the recommendations as soon as practicable.

Given the teamwork requirements of most Army employment, the potential social adjustment, such as working in mixed gender groups, of all applicants is checked by the interviewing psychologist prior to entry. Army is particularly concerned with teamwork and seeks every opportunity to enhance it. Army is expanding its entry training in group processes, and post enlistment and undergraduate training opportunities in behavioural sciences.

The Air Force Equal Employment Opportunity strategy is a similar program to Good Working Relationships, known as `One Team'. `One Team' aims to achieve their goal of sustaining a total force of Service, civilian and contracting personnel working as one professional team.

Within the Australian Defence Force Academy's Leadership Training Program, group dynamic processes are addressed throughout the three years of the course. The program includes learning exercises on the themes of teamwork, power, influence and appropriate leadership behaviour, and the psychology of individual and organisational behaviour.

This training is closely related to instruction provided in the Military Professionalism and Ethics, Interpersonal Relationships and Character Development Programs. These programs establish the standards of personal behaviour required by individuals in the Australian Defence Force and the responsibilities of leaders to ensure those standards are maintained.
Recommendation 9

The Committee recommends that in all its training and education courses on gender awareness, Navy stresses the responsibility of all individuals involved in incidents of unacceptable behaviour and sexual harassment. While it may not always be possible for the person who feels offended to tell the offender directly, the person who objects to the behaviour has a responsibility, especially if the offensive behaviour could also be interpreted as jocular or light-hearted, to tell at least one other person about it, preferably someone well placed to support the person who feels offended to resolve the situation before it deteriorates further. To facilitate such communication the identity of all Sexual Harassment Contact officers as the personnel best equipped to offer support should be readily accessible to all personnel; moreover all personnel should be clearly advised that they may approach the Sexual Harassment Contact officer in their own unit or in any other unit or division.
RESPONSE
Supported in Part

The Australian Defence Force strongly emphasises that the preferred method of resolution is for the person offended by the behaviour of another to bring it to the early attention of the offender, wherever possible, or to the attention of a third party. Conflict resolution strategies, the identity of Harassment Contact officers and the availability of the 008 telephone facility are outlined during training and education courses.

Sexual harassment is an abuse of power. Responsibility for eliminating it must rest with the employer and with the perpetrator. The Government agrees that, where possible, it is preferable that complaints be resolved informally between the parties. However, to place responsibility, in all cases, on a complainant to confront a perpetrator does not take account of the sensitivities and the power differentials in many working relationships. This is why a range of support mechanisms must be available to assist in conflict resolution.
Headquarters Australian Defence Force maintains a register of all Sexual Harassment Contact officers which is periodically reviewed, re-issued and advertised.
Recommendation 10
The Committee recommends that the Navy:
re-examine the adequacy of the nine week qualified entry officers' course and the reserve officers orientation course and consider extending the courses to a full six months;
consider setting a minimum recruiting period to allow for longer training;
give new medical recruits the opportunity to take day and weekly running trips before taking up a longer sea posting;
wherever possible, give new medical recruits a sufficient period on shore before posting to sea;
make a determined effort to post medical officers to ships in time for them to take part in the work-up of the ship before deployment;

identify specific naval tasks that can be effectively undertaken by medical and dental officers at sea in addition to their professional medical duties to assist them in being accepted as fully integrated members of the team; and

ensure that the qualified entry officers in both the Reserve and the Permanent Naval Force are clearly informed about these additional tasks and are adequately equipped, during their initial training, to carry them out.
RESPONSE
Supported in Part

The qualified entry officers course has recently been extended to 13 weeks and incorporates a two-week sea phase. This is intended to cover all the non-specialised training required for qualified entry officers on joining the Navy. Validation, including reviewing the course length, will take place on completion of the first extended course. It is not feasible to extend the Reserve Officer Orientation Course to 26 weeks because, generally speaking, Reservists are not able to take leave from their primary employment for such a prolonged period. This is the main reason why this course is presently two weeks' duration. The content and duration of this course is currently being examined. Options for providing sea familiarisation to Reserve medical officers are being examined.

Extending the initial minimum service period for qualified entry officers to cover additional training is not considered viable, given the difficulties in attracting such officers for Naval service for the currently prescribed period of Short Service Appointments. To extend further the initial service period would only exacerbate the current difficulty being experienced in recruiting qualified medical officers.

The posting policy now in place requires a new entry medical officer to be posted to a shore billet for the first year of full time service before being considered for sea service. This allows them to become familiar with the Navy and to complete their training in the Navy medical specialities such as nuclear, biological, and chemical defence, underwater medicine, aviation medicine, management of severe trauma and burns, sports medicine and gynaecological emergencies at sea. A similar posting policy for Reserve medical officers is being examined.

Every effort is now made to post medical officers to sea in time to take part in the ship's workup. However, this is not always possible due to regular shortages in the number of medical officers required throughout the Navy. Also, not all ships undergo a workup prior to deployment.

In addition to Divisional Officer duties which are undertaken by officers from all branches, collateral duties such as Entertainment Officer, Sports Officer, Education Officer and Resettlement Officer have in the past, and continue to be, allocated to medical and dental officers. Such duties are carefully allocated to ship's officers by Commanding Officers with due regard to the interests, capabilities and availability of individuals. The issue of collateral duties for medical and dental officers at sea is being examined in detail.
Recommendation 11

The Committee recommends that the provision of the medical services on board naval vessels be reviewed, with particular focus on the benefits to be gained from making sea postings available to registered Navy nurses. The review should include an evaluation of the benefits of replacing Petty Officer Medic positions with fully qualified nursing staff, as well as the feasibility of nursing staff, in certain circumstances, being appointed to replace medical officers.
RESPONSE
Supported in Principle

The rigorous nature of Service life requires that all personnel be fit and healthy and capable of operational deployment. The Australian Defence Force recognises that personnel may be exposed to significant risks during the conduct of their duties and seeks to provide a level of care equivalent to that provided in the civilian community and commensurate with the inherent risks of the tasks at hand.
Within the Australian Defence Force, the health team comprises medical, dental, nursing officers and medical assistants of both genders who provide care relevant to operational requirements.

In Navy, the provision of medical services at sea is continually under review due principally to the introduction of new classes of ships which have smaller total crew than those they replace. Other issues that determine the level of medical services are the operational role, area of deployment and access to medical support from other ships in convoy.

Under peacetime conditions the posting of a medical officer to each major Fleet unit is not warranted by the size of the dependent patient base. A medical sailor with advanced clinical skills (which equates to a medical assistant with additional skills in diagnostic and management procedures), provides an adequate level of medical care. Registered nurses and medical sailors with advanced clinical training are not interchangeable. Registered nurses could assume this role with additional training in some diagnostic skills and familiarisation with the seagoing environment.

The role of medical officers at sea is that of providing a higher level of treatment, particularly in remote areas or when there is a risk of injury in combat situations and when it is impractical to divert the ship from its primary role. In such circumstances the replacement of medical officers by nursing officers would not result in an enhanced higher level of care.

While it is true in recent years that the Navy has experienced a shortage of junior medical officers available for sea service, this situation has arisen from a previous decision to cease undergraduate entry recruiting. Resumption of undergraduate recruiting has taken some years to restore staffing levels. The effects of normal wastage and the introduction of structured training to prepare medical officers for an initial sea posting have also taken some time to redress the situation.

The view of the Committee that `many of the nurses now in the Navy have substantial Navy experience behind them that would stand them in good stead at sea' is not substantiated by the fact that presently 11 of the 19 Lieutenants/Sub Lieutenants have served less than five years.
Notwithstanding, it is intended to conduct a review encompassing the following:
the scope of any supplementary training required for registered nurses to meet the skills required for a single health billet at sea;
the requirement for a registered nurse to have commissioned officer status or not and consequent accommodation requirements on future ships;
the influences on recruiting and retention of nursing officers;
the balance of male/female nursing officers and implications for posting to mixed gender ships; and
the influence on retention of medical sailors with reduced opportunities for sea service at higher ranks.
Consistent with the implementation of the women at sea plan and posting policy, Navy endeavours to post one female medical sailor to every major Fleet unit which has female sailors embarked.

The Army has a comprehensive medical support structure which has evolved due to the nature of the battlefield. In Army's Area of Operations, the medical capabilities increase as a casualty is evacuated to the rear. At the `front', medical assistants and medical officers are integral to combat units, such as infantry battalions, and carry out emergency medical aid to casualties before evacuating them rearward. Within, and progressively to the rear of the logistic support area are the field ambulances, field hospitals, general hospitals and then, regionally located in Australia, the military hospitals. It is in these medical support facilities that casualties can be held, treated and nursed and these units are staffed with medical officers, nursing officers and medical assistants who provide the appropriate level of medical support and care for the casualty.

Within the Army structure, medical and nursing staff are well utilised in their roles and, where the need arises, can be deployed wherever there is a need for their respective skills. For example, medical detachments for United Nations' deployments are custom-designed to meet the needs of the size, location, mission, and, where possible, the gender composition of the force, as well as the health threat and the cultural and religious background of the host country.

Air Force nursing officers provide nursing care in all Air Force health facilities. In addition, nursing officers provide operational health support, aeromedical evacuation and general and specialised nursing duties during exercises, deployments and peacekeeping duties.

The medical assistant in the Air Force supports the nursing officer and the medical officer and while there may be some overlap in the capabilities of the nursing officer and medical assistant, the two groups function cohesively to provide optimal health care to patients. The level of training required by specific procedures determines the appropriate person to perform the given task.
Recommendation 12

The Committee recommends that an in-depth review be conducted of all positions at sea with the objective of more clearly identifying the personal characteristics, skills and aptitudes that are considered essential for service at sea. The review should include identifying minimum physical requirements including strength and flexibility, and characteristics such as resilience to stress, adaptability, and teamwork, that are appropriate for the conditions and for the technologies actually in use today.
RESPONSE
Supported

The Navy is reviewing the methodology for conducting a review of all positions at sea. The objective will be to identify more clearly the personal characteristics, skills and aptitudes, and minimum physical requirements considered essential for sea service.
It is also relevant that:
A review of recruiting as a function, including criteria for entry, will examine some of these aspects.
The following criteria are currently used to assess a potential applicant's resilience to stress, adaptability and teamwork during interviews by recruiting officers and psychologists.

PARA.TAB: Recruiting Officers' criteria:

PROCTEXT.PARA: Compatibility and Lifestyle. Expectations of military life, discipline, commitment and personal qualities.
Peer Association. Interests including hobbies and sports, friendships, groups and relationship to the military.
General Assessment. Overall impression, realistic impressions, and maturity to commitment.

PARA.TAB: Psychologists' criteria include:

PROCTEXT.PARA: capacity and motivation for study appropriate to category/branch requirements;
specific motivation for entry and category/branch;
attitude to authority;
attitude to serving at sea;
employment record;
educational record;
personal adjustment and maturity; and
social adjustment, especially ability to relate to peers.

The Navy does not support the proposition that sailors be allowed to remove themselves from ship billets if they develop reservations about their ability to handle life at sea. To allow such a situation would have the potential to affect operational effectiveness and to create posting turbulence with resultant short notice postings to other sailors. This in turn would have the potential to lead to family crises, dissatisfaction with Service life, discharge and shortages of trained personnel. Current policy provides avenues for Commanding Officers to land personnel who are assessed as being unable to fulfil their sea service obligation due to welfare or medical reasons, or where there is a degree of incompetence or disciplinary problems which warrant discharge action being taken.
The Army has similar criteria to the Navy and has scheduled a similar review to be conducted for all Army trades during 1995/96.

Similarly, a review of Air Force occupations is currently being undertaken to ensure that selection procedures correctly identify the physical and mental capabilities required for the successful completion of required tasks. All occupations will be surveyed by June 1995.
Recommendation 13

The Committee recommends that all potential new entrants to the Navy, including direct entry specialists, be given an opportunity to fully discuss and evaluate the difficult and demanding aspects of service, especially at sea, before making a firm commitment to the Navy.
RESPONSE
Supported

The Australian Defence Force invests significant resources, both financial and training, in each of its members. Therefore, people applying to join the Australian Defence Force must satisfy stringent selection criteria to ensure that they are committed to and capable of performing the tasks that the Government has set for the Australian Defence Force.

During basic recruit and officer training, any member who considers they are unsuited to military life may apply for discharge. Conversely, the Services can discharge persons identified as unsuitable for military life during this period.

All potential new entries to the Navy are afforded an opportunity to discuss and fully evaluate the difficult and demanding aspects of service, especially at sea, before making a firm commitment to the Navy. These discussions take place during the recruiting process and during initial training. Recruiting staff consist of members of various branches so as to enhance the effectiveness of the counselling process. If qualified staff are not available, applicants are referred to experts either by phone or through a visit to a ship or establishment. Personnel who apply for employment in specialist areas must satisfy further selection criteria specific to those areas.

During the Army recruiting process, all direct entry applicants are interviewed by the nominated Corps (specialist) representative in the region. The interview details aspects of career, professional and employment expectations, Army culture and conditions of employment. All candidates are given the opportunity to evaluate the difficult and demanding aspects of Army life before making a firm commitment.

During Air Force's recruit selection, every applicant is made aware of the risks of warfare and the demands of Service life and are assessed on their preparedness to accept these risks and demands. If the applicant does not appear to be sufficiently prepared or committed, then their application may not be recommended.

At the Australian Defence Force Academy, midshipmen and officer cadets are afforded the opportunity to discuss and observe the demands of Service life as an integral component of the Academy's program.
Recommendation 14

The Committee recommends that a review of the management of the RAN's Tactical Electronic Warfare Support Section (RANTEWSS) be undertaken by an independent investigator, reporting directly to the Minister for Defence. In particular, the review should include:
the organisational structure of RANTEWSS;
the selection and training of personnel, including the gender balance required to provide equal opportunity for sea postings;
the establishment, pre-deployment preparation and tasking of tactical teams, including the provision of appropriate equipment and work aids;
the scope for integrating teams more effectively into ships' crews; and
the work practices and conditions of deployed teams.
RESPONSE
Supported in Part

The intent of this Recommendation is agreed. However, the suggestion of reporting directly to the Minister for Defence is not supported. A review of the management of RANTEWSS by an independent authority outside the Naval Program has commenced. The results of this review will be communicated to the Minister for Defence through the Chief of Naval Staff and the Chief of the Defence Force, given that the issues covered by this review address specific operational aspects under their command.
Recommendation 15

The Committee recommends that all personnel in the Navy are assessed in the routine appraisal process for their capacity to develop a good working relationship with other personnel, no matter what their gender or sexual preference.
RESPONSE
Supported

Service men and women are selected, in part, for their ability to operate as a team member. Therefore, personnel are assessed regularly during their careers on how well they relate to, and work with, their colleagues, both male and female, as part of a team.

The Services and the Australian Defence Force Academy have reviewed the criteria used in their performance appraisals to ensure that these aspects are assessed. This is an ongoing process and criteria will be revised if found to be deficient.
Recommendation 16
The Committee recommends that all personnel with supervisory and management responsibilities are assessed for:
their skills in facilitating the integration of women into the Service;
their compliance with the requirement that all sexual harassment complaints are properly investigated;
their ability to assist in the effective resolution of sexual harassment allegations.
Where appropriate, the views of subordinates of the person being assessed should be taken into account in order to arrive at a reliable assessment of these matters.
RESPONSE
Supported in Principle

Personnel who are selected for supervisory and management responsibilities are assessed against broad criteria to determine their skills and abilities in managing staff. This includes their skills in integrating and facilitating the integration of women. The existing criteria adequately encompasses the Committee's Recommendation.

Compilation of performance reports does not involve specifically seeking a subordinate's views, and they are not normally consulted. However, the supervisor's working relationship with subordinates and the supervisor's management effectiveness is scrutinised and taken into consideration as part of normal performance assessment practice.
Recommendation 17
The Committee recommends that the guidelines for the performance appraisal be reviewed:

to clarify the approach that supervisors should adopt to matters such as inadequacies in the assessee's training for tasks, short assessment periods and lack of opportunity for the assessee to demonstrate the particular skills for which he or she is being assessed; and
to ensure that all supervisors are consistent in their approach to performance appraisal.
RESPONSE
Supported

Performance appraisal systems are based on the principles of honesty and integrity but they may be subjective and standardisation can be difficult to achieve. Each Service has set guidelines and procedures for personnel who are required to compile these reports and every effort is made to ensure that assessors follow a consistent approach.

The Navy guidelines for both the officers' and sailors' performance appraisal systems are being revised to take account of this Recommendation. Performance appraisal reports may be subject to modification by Navy Office to ensure consistency in reporting across the ranks.

Army personnel are strongly encouraged to provide supporting comments in the performance assessments that they raise on their subordinates, both soldiers and officers. These comments are required where assessments are markedly higher or lower than the norm. All reports have a specified minimum observation period. In all circumstances, Commanding Officers can defer the compilation of a report, if it is felt that an unfair assessment would be reflected, due to a lack of training or adequate observation. To ensure that a balanced view and assessment consistency is obtained, all reports are commented on by the member's Head of Corps. Reports are then further standardised, at the highest level in the process, either by an adjustment based on an assessment of the reporting officer (for soldiers) or by a comparative cohort history analysis (for officers). In cases of specialist members, such as direct entry officers, often a senior officer within the member's specialisation will have additional input on that member's technical profi ciency.

Air Force personnel are also encouraged to provide supporting comments in performance assessments. This is mandatory for markedly high or low assessments. Air Force performance assessments are subject to minimum assessment periods and assessments must be deferred to ensure that the minimum period is satisfied. Personnel undertake training in raising performance appraisals during the promotion and training courses which all members complete during their Air Force career.
Recommendation 18
The Committee recommends that a full-scale review of the Divisional System be carried out. The review should include in particular:
the effectiveness of the Divisional System in meeting the needs of individuals and in meeting the needs of the organisation;
the impact of the 008 number on the operation of the Divisional System;
the impact of the introduction of Navy Quality Management on the operation of the Divisional System; and
the adequacy of the training of Divisional Officers and Divisional Chiefs for their Divisional duties
RESPONSE
Supported

The principles of Naval Quality Management and equivalent initiatives in Army and Air Force emphasises the desirability of all staff participating and contributing to the management of their workplace. All staff are encouraged to suggest changes to work practices that help create a harmonious work environment and result in enhanced productivity. A flow-on positive effect is a more open communication between staff and their superiors on issues affecting the workplace

The Navy's Divisional System, and the Army's and Air Force's chain of command, place responsibility for the welfare of subordinate personnel on superiors who are required to address incidents of unacceptable sexual behaviour.
The toll-free numbers and quality management programs that exist in each Service provide complimentary tools to the Divisional System and chain of command.
Navy has commenced work on a comprehensive review of the Divisional System which will address in detail all the aspects outlined in this Recommendation.

The chain of command for Army and Air Force will be reviewed in accordance with this Recommendation. Focus groups conducted on a regular basis by Army and Air Force, indicate that the majority of personnel have confidence in the chain of command.
Recommendation 19

The Committee recommends that the potential for tensions between the principles underlying the Chain of Command and the more participatory problem solving principles of Navy Quality Management be openly and more fully addressed at every level of management training in the Navy.
RESPONSE
Supported

In Navy, training in the principles and practice of Naval Quality Management (NQM) have now been included in basic entry courses for both officers and sailors. An essential element of this training is to point out where and when the principles of NQM might apply and when a more authoritative approach might be more appropriate. This is intended specifically to address tensions which might arise from conflict between the two approaches to management.

In addition, a review of Leadership Management and Personal Development training in the Navy has been undertaken. The report of this review calls for a fundamental rethink and recommends that a continuum of training be developed for officers and sailors from Midshipman to Lieutenant Commander, and Seaman to Warrant Officer, respectively. The concept of a continuum has been endorsed, and the formation of a team to develop the training package, drawing on subject matter experts as required, is currently being examined. This training will also help to clarify the issues of NQM and traditional management methods for officers and sailors.

Army Total Quality Management (TQM) is one of a range of management tools available to commanders for continued improvement within their units. From 1995 TQM will be incorporated into Army's through career training program. A comprehensive Army awareness program is underway to ensure that the philosophy of TQM is understood and to minimise the tensions between the principles underlying the chain of command and the more participatory problem solving principles of TQM.

Air Force introduced a TQM program in 1988. This program encourages participation by all staff members in the management of their workplace. A flow-on benefit is a more open communication between staff and their superiors on issues affecting the workplace. In keeping with this style of management, education and training sessions currently being delivered across the Air Force encourage supervisors to accept that Equal Employment Opportunity responsibilities, including sexual harassment, are both leadership and management issues. Surveys conducted before and after education sessions at the bases at which education has taken place to date indicate a marked change in attitude by supervisors.
Recommendation 20
The Committee recommends that:

the behaviour designated as gender harassment in para 4d of Annex A to DI(G) PERS 35-3 be clearly identified as unacceptable behaviour between all personnel, including behaviour between members of the same gender; and
the example in 4b of Annex A to DI(G) PERS 35-3 be reformulated to include derogatory references to both female and male physiological functions.
RESPONSE
Supported

The Defence Instruction General Personnel 35-3 [DI(G) PERS 35-3] `Unacceptable Sexual Behaviour by Members of the Australian Defence Force', has been revised to reflect the Committee's Recommendations and endorsed by the Chiefs of Staff Committee. This Instruction has been promulgated.
Recommendation 21
The Committee recommends that more emphasis be given in the draft DI(G) PERS 35-3 to:
the value of seeking to resolve concerns about sexual harassment by the individuals involved and at an informal level; and

the support mechanisms available to the complainant. The guidance should make explicit reference to all the 008 numbers in the section headed `Avenues of Complaint''. The guidance should also be regularly supplemented by the service-wide circulation of up-to-date lists of Sexual Harassment Contact officers.
RESPONSE
Supported

Within the revised DI(G) PERS 35-3, more emphasis has been given to the value of seeking to resolve concerns about sexual harassment by the individuals involved, at an informal level. Each Service, the Australian Defence Force Academy and the Department of Defence have an extensive network of Sexual Harassment Contact officers. Similarly, each Service, the Australian Defence Force Academy and the Department of Defence are responsible for maintaining and promulgating a current list of Sexual Harassment Contact officers at regular intervals through unit or departmental routine orders.
Recommendation 22

The Committee recommends that the DI(G) PERS 35-3 be more detailed and specific in the guidance it gives on false allegations of sexual offences and sexual harassment. In particular the instruction should outline the procedures that are to be followed and the possible outcomes in the event that a false, malicious, vexatious or patently unfounded allegation is made.
RESPONSE
Supported

In supporting the above Recommendation, the Government notes that Paragraph 6.190 of the Committee's Report indicates that the Committee did not intend the recommendation to apply to situations in which a complaint is eventually unsubstantiated as opposed to situations in which a person knowingly makes an allegation which is false, misleading, vexatious or malicious. The Government recognises that there is also a need to ensure that complainants are protected from victimisation.

The giving of false or misleading information by any member who knows that the information is false or misleading during a Service investigation into unacceptable sexual behaviour, may be subject to administrative action or action under the Defence Force Discipline Act. A Commanding Officer, or other officer appointed to investigate an allegation of unacceptable sexual behaviour, who believes, or is satisfied that false or misleading information has been deliberately given, should seek legal advice as to the appropriate course of action to be taken.

Any Australian Defence Force member has the right at any time to pursue a complaint of sexual discrimination or harassment through the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. All persons involved in a complaint before the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission are required to be honest and accurate in their evidence. A person who furnishes information or makes a statement knowing that the information or statement is false or misleading may be subject to a penalty under the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act s.25 and the Sex Discrimination Act s.93. The Sex Discrimination Act also provides for the Commission to dismiss a complaint that it considers to be frivolous, vexatious, misconceived or lacking in substance. However the Government is concerned that these provisions do not act to inhibit a genuine complaint.

The Committee identified in its Report a perception that there was scope for abuse of the complaints process under the Sex Discrimination Act. The Government notes that there is no evidence which supports a conclusion that such abuse of the process may have occurred under the Sex Discrimination Act.
Recommendation 23

The Committee recommends that, where a PERS 1 or PR 5 is disputed, the superior should see the supervisor responsible for drafting the report and the subordinate separately, before any attempt is made to resolve differences between the parties in a joint meeting.
RESPONSE
Supported

The Navy Instructions covering the completion of PERS 1 and PR 5 reports are being amended to reflect that in the event of an assessment being disputed, superiors must first see the supervisor who drafted the report and the subordinate separately before any attempt is made to resolve differences at any joint meeting.

The Army and Air Force also have in place processes for resolving disputed performance assessments which normally involve, in the first instance, seeing a subordinate separately to the supervisor who drafted the report.
Recommendation 24
The Committee recommends that the Chief of Naval Staff review the censure of Captain Mole, taking into account the Committee's view that:
Captain Mole should have been given an opportunity to respond to the specific details of the censure as finally issued by the Chief of Naval Staff;
the censure carried additional weight because it was made public; and
the severity of a censure at the Chief of Naval Staff level is out of proportion to any shortcomings in Captain Mole's performance as Commanding Officer of the SWAN.
RESPONSE
Supported
A review is in progress to consider all relevant information pertaining to this Recommendation.
Recommendation 25

The Committee recommends that review of Captain Mole's censure should include a parallel review of his performance assessments since August 1992. Furthermore, the Committee recommends that any selection panel considering promotions where Captain Mole is a candidate should have this Committee's Report brought to its attention.
RESPONSE
Supported
A review is in progress to consider all relevant information pertaining to this Recommendation.
Recommendation 26
The Committee recommends that the censure for all other personnel involved in the SWAN incidents be reviewed in the light of the findings of this inquiry.
RESPONSE
Supported
A review is in progress to consider all relevant information pertaining to this Recommendation.
Recommendation 27

The Committee recommends that amendments to the Defence Force Disciplinary Act be considered to allow for alleged sexual offences involving only Australian military personnel that occur outside Australian territorial waters, including on board Australian vessels, to be tried in a civilian criminal court under the relevant law applying in the Jervis Bay Territory in Australia, having been investigated by the appropriate civilian police and prosecuting authorities.
RESPONSE
Under Examination
The Attorney General's Department and the Australian Defence Force are holding discussions on the legal and practical issues surrounding this Recommendation. An early resolution is not anticipated.
Recommendation 28
The Committee recommends that:
the 008 service should remain an integral component of Navy's strategy to eliminate sexual harassment; and
protocols governing the operation of the 008 number be reviewed in the light of experience a year after the tabling of this report
RESPONSE
Supported

It is the intention of all three Services, that the 008 toll-free number will remain an integral component of the strategy to eliminate sexual harassment. This issue is discussed in greater detail in response to Recommendation 39IIIa.

The protocols governing the operation of the 008 toll-free services will be reviewed in 12 months. However, the existing protocols for Navy have been referred to the Attorney-General's Department for review to ensure that they meet privacy and other relevant legislation. Any changes determined as necessary by the Attorney-General's Department will be incorporated into the current protocols for all three Services.
Recommendation 29

The Committee recommends that in future, organisers at the Good Working Relationships seminars apportion appropriate time to the issue of homosexuality and the way in which the guidelines on unacceptable sexual behaviour apply.
RESPONSE
Supported

The rules concerning unacceptable sexual behaviour apply equally to homosexual and heterosexual activities. The issue of homosexuality is already addressed during Navy's Good Working Relationships seminars, all other Good Working Relationship training, and Equal Employment Opportunity programs within Army and Air Force.
Recommendation 30

The Committee recommends that Navy devise a conflict resolution program drawing as appropriate on `Resolving Conflict: Following the Light of Personal Behaviour' as one useful model. Such a program should be used as an additional segment of the Good Working Relationships program to give practical advice to all personnel in the Navy for resolving the conflict associated with sexual harassment.
RESPONSE
Supported

Navy is developing a conflict resolution program which utilises `Resolving Conflict: Following the Light of Personal Behaviour'. Approval from the United States Navy has been obtained to use this program.
In addition to existing programs, Army, Air Force and the Australian Defence Force Academy are examining the United States Navy model to determine its appropriateness to their environments.
Recommendation 31

The Committee recommends that, in developing the guidelines and training for a conflict resolution program as suggested in Recommendation 30, particular attention is given to the development of those skills and techniques which enable individuals subjected to sexual harassment to be more confident and effective in dealing with such harassment at the personal level.
RESPONSE
Supported
Each of the Services is addressing the issue of providing its members with skills and techniques to deal with harassment at the personal level.

Navy's Good Working Relationships training at the most junior level (during initial entry training) focuses on the rights and responsibilities of individuals with regard to unacceptable sexual behaviour. It is emphasised that no individual should tolerate unacceptable sexual behaviour and the various avenues and assistance available for dealing with such behaviour are explained. This training is designed to instil confidence in junior personnel to confront unacceptable behaviour at an early stage.

Elements of conflict resolution and assertiveness are included at the Army's point of entry training. To supplement this program, and to enhance the personal development of a member's assertiveness, conflict resolution and self esteem training is available to all military and civilian personnel throughout their careers. This training is designed to instil confidence in personnel to confront unacceptable behaviour at an early stage.

the Chief of the Air Staff Commanders' Conference—August 1994;
personal endorsement by the Chief of the Air Staff and by the Air Force's senior commanders by written advice to the members of their Commands;

Recommendation 39

Supported

Supported

Supported

RESPONSE
Supported

Headquarters Australian Defence Force will complete its initial program of sexual harassment awareness training seminars by early 1995. This presentation is also given to any soldier who may not have already received individual unit presentations. The Australian Defence Force Academy's interpersonal relationship program is a comprehensive educational package covering: harassment in all forms; Australian Defence Force policies in unacceptable behaviour; dealing with unacceptable behaviour as an individual and as a leader; assertiveness training and discussions of scenarios. Supported

a stand-alone program of once only `catch-up' training for those personnel unlikely to attend through-career training over the next few years;
Good Working Relationships Facilitator training for those personnel who volunteer to facilitate the introduction of these principles and practices in their units;

(c)Procedures should be put in place to ensure that course symbols, such as pilot course badges, in-house publications (both formal and informal) and training materials do not contain unacceptable sexual connotations.

Supported

IIIProvision of alternative avenues of support
An essential component of an effective sexual harassment policy is the ready availability of avenues of complaint other than through the chain of command.

(a)A 008 confidential advisory service should be maintained. Consideration should be given to amalgamating the initial points of contact, so that a single 008 telephone number for all Service personnel replaces the existing 008/1800 numbers for Army, Navy and Air Force. It should be possible for callers to either talk directly to a counsellor or to leave a message at any time of the day or night. Every effort should be made to respond to any message left on the 008 number within 12 hours of the call being received. The service should continue to be widely publicised and reviewed in three years time. Any new staff appointed to the service should be appropriately trained.
RESPONSE
Supported in Part
The Services do not support the amalgamation of the 008 confidential advisory services under one initial point of contact, and each will maintain its individual toll-free telephone number.

Separate toll-free telephone services were established in each Service some 12 months ago. These services are proving to be a valuable tool in providing assistance and confidential advice to members of the Australian Defence Force.

Existing arrangements, within each Service, enable a response to be made to any message left on any of the toll-free numbers within 12 hours. This service is also provided during weekends and public holidays.
The toll-free number is advertised extensively through Service newspapers, advertising posters and during Good Working Relationships and Equal Employment Opportunity training programs.

All operators undergo a telephone counselling course and are educated in Equal Employment Opportunity/human rights issues. Additionally, they are made fully aware of Defence Force and individual Service support systems and complaint mechanisms.

In the Navy's case, the 008 number (Operation Lifeguard) is an integral part of the Good Working Relationships Project and is used to monitor trends in harassment/discrimination occurrences. Considerable effort and resources have been devoted to establishing the service and training its operators. In addition, Navy personnel are able to empathise with the callers and quickly establish a rapport with them. Trust and credibility are essential to the effective operation of the service and Navy has put considerable effort into ensuring the effectiveness of the service during the past 12 months.

In the Army's case, the retention of a single service point of contact is justified by comments from the soldiers in the field who say that they prefer to speak with someone who has an inherent understanding of their situation.
The Air Force considers that the service should be staffed by a non-uniformed and specifically trained counsellor with a professional background who is familiar with the military culture.
This confidential advisory service will be maintained within the single Services, however, the facility will be reviewed in August 1995 to determine:
the feasibility of amalgamating the initial points of contact; and
the appropriate person to receive the call—uniformed or civilian.

RESPONSE
Supported

The training packages used by the Australian Defence Force provide personnel who may be used as alternative avenues, with the appropriate skills to identify and assist personnel who may be at risk. RESPONSE
Supported

The role of Navy doctors, chaplains and other support personnel in relation to sexual harassment matters is emphasised during Good Working Relationships training. `Operation Lifeguard' operators also maintain contact lists of all specialist and support personnel so that callers may be apprised of the services provided by these personnel. The role of specialist and support personnel will be further refined during the review of the Divisional System.

This is a current Army practice and is made known through current policy and in the harassment and discrimination training that all Army personnel receive. It is also included in the Army's sexual harassment pamphlet, and guides, and through the Harassment and Discrimination Helpline.

The Air Force catch-up training for all personnel provides them with the support structures and mechanisms available to assist in regard to the management of discrimination and harassment. This training includes awareness education on the role played by doctors, chaplains, social workers, psychologists and also Program Implementation Coordinators, Equal Employment Opportunity Contact Officers, Commanding Officers and supervisors.

Midshipmen and officer cadets at the Australian Defence Force Academy are made aware of the role of support personnel and other agencies through the training program provided early in their initial training.

(d)An external conflict resolution process should be introduced and made widely known and readily available to any personnel who consider they are subjected to harassment and encounter difficulties in resolving their complaint directly at the unit level.
RESPONSE
Supported

All Australian Defence Force personnel are made aware of internal and external channels for conflict resolution, including the redress of grievance process, the Defence Force Ombudsman and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. All complaints are dealt with promptly and sensitively.

The Navy has successfully trialed an external-to-the-workplace conflict resolution process. Guidelines are being developed to assist managers to determine when it is appropriate to use the conflict resolution process.

All Army commanders are aware of the availability of the Community Justice Program which provides an external mediation/conflict resolution service which operates in all major regional areas. Army psychology officers, medical officers, legal officers, chaplains and social workers who are not normally part of the unit, are also available to provide this conflict resolution service.

The Air Force considers that the 1800 toll-free number, which is staffed by qualified civilian social workers, and is widely publicised and easily accessible, is the most appropriate avenue for conflict resolution that by passes the chain of command.
