IVThe promotion of informal resolution of allegations of sexual harassment

(a)The emphasis in dealing with allegations of sexual harassment should be on informal resolution of the complaint at the local level. Personnel who believe they are being subjected to sexual harassment should be encouraged and given support in resolving the conflict at a personal level.
RESPONSE
Supported

Any Australian Defence Force members who believe that they are being subjected to sexual harassment are encouraged and given support in resolving the conflict at a personal level. The Australian Defence Force believes that the preferred method, and often the most effective way, to prevent the continuation of sexual harassment is for the person offended to approach the harasser, state clearly that the behaviour is offensive and demand that it ceases immediately. However, the Government recognises that there are some cases of sexual harassment where informal resolution is inappropriate and the parties involved need to be aware of the alternate avenues that may be followed.

The Navy has an informal conflict resolution process through the Divisional System. Personnel attending Good Working Relationships training and callers to `Operation Lifeguard' are advised of this process where appropriate.

The Army strongly emphasises to its all personnel that the best method of resolving complaints is informally, at the local level. It is reinforced in all training, policy and information statements on harassment and discrimination issues and by the Army Helpline service.

The Air Force policy is that complaints of harassment should be resolved informally, at the local level wherever possible. This advice is contained in directions to commanders and supervisors and is reinforced in education and training packages.

The Australian Defence Force Academy during initial training programs stresses that complaints should be resolved informally at the local level. This is further reinforced at the senior cadet level and is monitored closely by Academy staff.

(b)If, however, a formal, internal complaint is proceeded with, the procedures followed and the mechanisms that are in place should give assurance to the complainant that the complaint is being fully and properly investigated.
RESPONSE
Supported

Mechanisms are in place across the Australian Defence Force, whereby a complainant is counselled and offered appropriate advice and guidance. During this process the member is reassured and afforded the opportunity to discuss any concerns.
All parties concerned are assured that should a complaint proceed to a formal internal complaint, the allegation will be investigated thoroughly and with sensitivity.

(c)If the internal investigation is not satisfactory to the complainant, or if the person harassed encounters difficulties in pursuing this course, information on all alternative options (eg an approach to HREOC, or to the Defence Force Ombudsman) should be made readily available.
RESPONSE
Supported
This Recommendation has been implemented across the Australian Defence Force. All personnel are made aware of the external agencies which are available to investigate complaints of sexual harassment.
The Defence Instruction has been amended to provide comprehensive guidance on complaint procedures through external agencies.
(d)Recourse to courts martial for resolving complaints of sexual harassment should be regarded as a last resort, after other avenues for resolving the problem have been fully explored.
RESPONSE
Supported

Courts martial are convened only to try serious offences; they are not a mechanism for resolving complaints of sexual harassment. The convening of courts martial follows the most rigorous examination of all the issues.
(e)Assurances must be given at the highest level and monitored to ensure compliance, that there will be no retribution for making a legitimate complaint.
RESPONSE
Supported

The Defence Force policy detailed in Defence Instruction, DI(G) PERS 35-3, issued jointly by the Chief of the Defence Force and the Secretary of the Department of Defence, requires managers to ensure that a member lodging a complaint will not be subjected to retribution. This is reinforced during Equal Employment Opportunity and sexual harassment training throughout the three Services and at the Australian Defence Force Academy. Also, it is an offence under Defence Force Regulations Part XV governing redress of grievances for anyone to dissuade or victimise a complainant.
VImproved procedures for the investigations of complaints
Immediate attention must be given to overhauling the procedures and guidelines for the investigation of complaints to incorporate the following:
(a)Investigation of sexual assault

PARA.TAB: Allegations of sexual assault must be immediately referred to civilian police authorities for investigation.

Provision should also be made for continuing liaison between the civilian investigating authorities, and the military particularly in relation to incidents outside Australian territorial waters pending the adoption of measures in the Committee's Recommendation 27.

PROCTEXT.PARA: RESPONSE
Under examination

Arrangements are already in place whereby the Australian Defence Force refers allegations with respect to those sexual assaults contained in Sections 92 A to E of the Crimes Act 1900 (NSW) to civilian police authorities for investigation. The Government will review the current legal and procedural arrangements relating to all allegations of sexual assault to ensure that all relevant cases are referred to civil authorities for investigation and prosecution.

The Army and Air Force will make arrangements with the Australian Federal Police (AFP) Sexual Assault Unit to provide assistance with the investigation of any allegation of sexual assault occurring outside Australia. The Navy already have these arrangements in place. Also, selected Naval police coxswain investigators and Army military police have undertaken the AFP sexual assault investigation training course.
(b)Investigation of other sexual harassment allegations

PARA.TAB: All personnel appointed to investigate incidents must have had appropriate training in the investigation of such complaints.
In all but exceptional cases, investigating officers should be appointed from outside the unit where the alleged incident occurred.
Investigating officers should not be personally acquainted with any of the parties involved in the incident.

All the Services should establish closer liaison with specialists in the investigation of allegations of sexual harassment, both in terms of training military personnel to conduct such investigations internally and to seek the assistance of civilian investigators in cases where suitable military investigators are not available. Where difficulties arise in appointing suitable military investigators from within the Service where the complaint has been made, the use of trained investigators from a Service other than the one where the complaint was made should also be considered.

PROCTEXT.PARA: RESPONSE
Supported in Principle

The Australian Defence Force recognises the sensitivities surrounding the investigation of sexual harassment allegations. Each Service, within the limitations of operational requirements and personnel levels, is committed to conducting investigations so that justice is done and is seen to be done.

The guiding principle for the conduct of investigations within the Services is that the investigating officers are not personally acquainted with any of the parties involved in a sexual incident. However, the Government recognises that there may be some unique circumstances where this is not possible due to operational demands. Nevertheless, in such cases, if either the complainant or the alleged offender object to the investigating officer on the grounds of personal knowledge, another investigating officer will be appointed. In the case of Air Force the operational environment permits appointment of investigating officers of commissioned rank from another unit. Where difficulties arise in appointing investigators within the parent Service, assistance from civilian consultants or from the other Services may be sought. In cases of sexual assault occurring within Australia, investigations are invariably conducted by the relevant State police authorities.

The three Services have adopted similar measures of liaising with specialists in the investigation of sexual harassment allegations. The police component of each Service maintains a close link with their State and Federal counterparts. Both Army and Navy undertake Australian Federal Police training in the sensitivities and complexities of sexual harassment investigations, in addition to their internal training.

Headquarters Australian Defence Force in conjunction with the Services, is currently preparing a training package including a video to be given to any officer appointed to conduct an investigation. This package will complement the training in each of the Services.
VIEnsuring that supervising officers are accountable

(a)The performance appraisal forms of each Service should be revised so that the extent to which all personnel adhere to the guidelines on unacceptable sexual behaviour is assessed, including the extent to which senior officers carry out their responsibility to take appropriate action to investigate quickly and fairly any allegations of sexual harassment. Care should be taken to ensure that these assessments are given equal weight by, and are comparable across all the Services.
RESPONSE
Supported in Principle

The performance assessment criteria listed in this Recommendation are too specific and can be considered elements of the existing inter-personal and management skills criteria. These are intrinsic to assessing management and leadership ability.

There is also a practical difficulty in including very narrow assessment criteria in personnel appraisal forms which relate to situations or events which are unlikely to be encountered by the vast majority of personnel. Unless an incident has occurred, personnel would not have an opportunity to demonstrate their skills, and this would preclude any valid assessment of performance. Singling out sexual behaviour as a specific element of the performance appraisal process places a disproportionate emphasis on one aspect of human behaviour and inter personal relationships.
The Australian Defence Force therefore prefers to treat the management of sexual behaviour as one element of the assessment of inter-personal relationships, management and leadership skills.
VIIClarifying organisational responsibility

(a)Steps should be taken urgently to establish clearly whether the ADF or the Department of Defence has the responsibility to ensure that proper sexual harassment policies and mechanisms are in place for handling sexual harassment allegations in establishments where both military and civilian personnel, including contract personnel, are employed.
RESPONSE
Supported

With the streamlining of Australian Defence Force functions, in particular the Commercial Support Program, increasing numbers of civilian personnel, both Public Service and contract, are working side by side with their uniformed counterparts. In this integrated environment, the Australian Defence Force and the Department of Defence maintain distinct mechanisms for addressing personnel management issues. However, both organisations have a shared responsibility for implementation of these policies, in jointly prepared guidelines, `Eliminating Harassment in the Integrated Defence Environment' which apply to both civilian and Service personnel. These guidelines will be issued by the end of the year.

Explicit in these guidelines is the need for the Department of Defence and the Australian Defence Force to consult on complaints of sexual harassment which involve both military and civilian personnel. In any case, where any doubt exists as to which `employer' is responsible for dealing with a complaint of sexual harassment, the matter will be resolved by consultation between Headquarters Australian Defence Force and the Department of Defence. If a member of contracting staff complains of harassment by any Defence employee, they are encouraged to take the matter to their employer (the contractor) who will take the matter to the Department's Liaison Officer for the contract under which they are employed.

While each of the Services has separate mechanisms for handling sexual harassment allegations within the civilian and military environment, Headquarters Australian Defence Force will complement this mechanism with the publication of these guidelines.
VIIIMonitoring sexual harassment

(a)Mechanisms should be established for an accurate and comprehensive on-going record of the number and kind of sexual harassment incidents occurring in the ADF. These mechanisms should be such as to enable valid comparisons to be made between the Services and between different units, including training units, within each Service. The records collected should clearly identify the nature of the incident, the action taken and the outcome.
RESPONSE
Supported

Mechanisms have been established for the accurate and comprehensive ongoing record of the number and kind of sexual harassment incidents occurring in the Australian Defence Force. A tri-Service reporting mechanism is detailed in the Defence Instruction and enables valid comparisons to be made between the Services and between different units, including training units.

(b)The Committee notes that, from the records currently available from the 008 numbers, there appears to be a significant difference in the kind of calls being received by the Navy and the kind of calls being registered in the other two Services. In particular, the level of incidents of general harassment in the Navy appears to be as high as that recorded for sexual harassment. All Services should ensure that general harassment as well as sexual harassment is identified and recorded. The categorisation of the calls should be standardised across all the Services.
RESPONSE
Supported
The Defence Force has standardised the categorisation of the toll-free numbers across all Services. These categories are:
sexual harassment/sexual assault calls;
general harassment/victimisation calls;
discrimination calls;
general queries; and
other calls.

(c)All exit interviews should specifically seek to establish whether the person has experienced sexual harassment, the extent and nature of any such harassment, and whether such harassment has played any part in the person's decision to leave the service. Comparative data on the difference at separation in the ranks and length of service between male and female personnel should be monitored.
RESPONSE
Supported

The Army and Air Force currently have exit interview questionnaires which are being amended to encompass harassment issues. The Navy is developing the format for an exit questionnaire to include a specific clause for personnel to advise of any harassment issue which may have contributed to separation from the Service.

An exit interview is conducted by senior staff with each cadet leaving the Australian Defence Force Academy to ascertain whether the trainee has experienced instances of unacceptable behaviour. An exit questionnaire is currently under consideration and will be used in the exit interview.

Comparative data on the difference at separation in the ranks and length of service between male and female personnel is already maintained by the respective human resource planning directorates in each of the three Services.

(d)The Services should conduct a survey similar to that conducted by Major Quinn in 1987 to provide data on women's perceptions of sexual harassment since the major policy changes on integration were introduced. A survey at this time would be a further useful benchmark for future evaluation of the programs now being put in place.
RESPONSE
Supported
A survey will be conducted commencing in early 1995. Major Quinn has been awarded a 1995 Defence Fellowship to conduct a similar study to that which was undertaken in 1987.
IXEstablishment of Advisory Committee

(a)The chain of command should continue to take full responsibility for the development, implementation and monitoring of ADF policy on sexual harassment. It is also essential that the Services develop their own internal expertise in every aspect of the management of sexual harassment, including expertise in group dynamics and conflict resolution. However, there would be value in setting up an Advisory Panel to meet periodically with the Defence Force Policy Committee to assist the ADF carry out this responsibility. The Federal Sex Discrimination Commissioner, the Defence Force Ombudsman, and the present consultants to Navy and the ADF on sexual harassment should be included on the Advisory Panel. In view of the many integrated civilian/military establishments, consideration should also be given to including a representative of the Merit Protection and Review Agency. The HQADF and single Service EEO Units and personnel providing the 008 services should, as a matter of course, participate in meetings with the Advisory Panel.
RESPONSE
Supported

The establishment of a Defence Advisory Forum on Discrimination was announced by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel in August 1994. The inaugural meeting with this Forum and the Defence Force Personnel Policy Committee, including the Commandant of the Australian Defence Force Academy, was held in September 1994. The Forum comprises the Sex Discrimination Commissioner, the Defence Force Ombudsman, the Director of the Merit Protection and Review Agency and representatives from industry, civilian organisations and tertiary institutions. Representatives from the single service Equal Employment Opportunity units were also in attendance. This Forum should provide valuable advice to the Australian Defence Force on a broad cross section of human rights and equal opportunity issues. The next meeting is scheduled for March 1995.
Recommendation 40

The Committee recommends that the ADF report back to the Senate, one year after the Government's response to this Report, on the action taken by each of the Services and the Australian Defence Force Academy to eliminate sexual harassment from the Australian Defence Force.
RESPONSE
Supported

The Australian Defence Force will report back to the Senate in December 1995 on the action taken by each of the Services and the Australian Defence Force Academy to eliminate sexual harassment from the Australian Defence Force.
Recommendation 41

The Committee recommends that the ADF develop further the ADF's guidelines on appropriate professional behaviour and inter-personal relations. Particular attention should be given to both the process of arriving at those standards and the process of promulgating them. The Navy's approach of conducting focus groups to identify issues, followed by service-wide seminars which encourage communication and open discussion of the issue of unacceptable sexual behaviour in the context of appropriate overall behavioural standards provides an effective model for dealing with sensitive and complex matters of this kind. Similar processes should be put in place by all the Services to address the wider issue of professional inter-personal conduct, including general and sexual harassment, and mechanisms put in place for eliminating harassment of any kind from the ADF.
RESPONSE
Supported

The Australian Defence Force accepts the fact that the problem of sexual harassment is part of the wider phenomenon of general harassment. The Australian Defence Force will seek to formalise and reiterate the standards of the military profession of respect, courtesy, fairness and good faith. Headquarters Australian Defence Force is examining the feasibility of preparing a military code of ethics along the lines of the ethos and values programs already in place within the Army. These standards are already imparted to personnel during training and any revised code of ethics will be promulgated through the Services' formal and informal channels.
Recommendation 42

The Committee endorses the principle of equal opportunity for women in the Australian Defence Force and recommends that high priority be accorded to removing, to the maximum extent possible, any remaining barriers to recruitment and promotion prospects for women in the Services. To achieve this, high priority and resources should be given to reviewing criteria for advancement in the Services to reflect accurately the full range of complementary skills and attributes required for an effective and efficient Defence Force. Particular care should be taken to ensure that policies on access to facilities, physical strength requirements, pregnancy leave, fraternisation and the pre-requisites for promotion, do not unfairly or unnecessarily disadvantage women. Equally importantly they must not be perceived as giving an unfair advantage to women.
RESPONSE
Supported

The Government is committed to the principle of equal opportunity for women in the Australian Defence Force. In line with this, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel announced a number of initiatives in late August aimed at maintaining the momentum towards providing equality of employment in the workplace by introducing several initiatives.

The first initiative is the establishment of the Defence Advisory Forum on Discrimination to address the challenges of discrimination and inequality in the workplace. This Forum, comprising senior executives from the corporate sector, tertiary institutions and the Government, should assist senior Defence management in maintaining an awareness of contemporary community programs, trends and strategies in combating discrimination and inequality.

A further study will be initiated in early 1995 on the cultural and institutional barriers which impede the competitiveness of women in achieving higher positions in the Australian Defence Force. This study will also identify actions to be taken by the Defence Force to remove such barriers.

In conjunction with this study, a similar study will be conducted to identify reasons why more women in the Australian Defence Force are not making the Service a long-term career. This study will complement work already being undertaken in each of the Services and will involve exit interviews on the reasons for women leaving the Defence Force.

To reinforce equality in the workplace, a set of performance indicators will be drawn up to monitor the achievements of women in the Australian Defence Force. These indicators will measure the career progression of women against normal male Service expectations. They will address selection for promotion, career-enhancing training programs and attendance at staff colleges. The causes for any disparity will be scrutinised and immediate remedial action initiated, if justified.

GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE INTO LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS:
FEASIBILITY OF NATIONAL ID SCHEME, THE TAX FILE NUMBER
The Government welcomed the tabling in October 1988 of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the tax file number.

In particular, the Government welcomed the conclusions of the bi-partisan majority regarding the Committee's additional terms of reference flowing from the Treasurer's announcement in the May Economic Statement in 1988 that the Government would proceed with legislation to upgrade the integrity of the existing tax file number system.
Specifically, the report states (paragraph 2.21):

"The Committee concluded that the tax file numbering scheme proposed by the Treasurer is likely to improve the efficiency of the taxation system and to assist in the elimination of fraud and abuse of that system."

The Government also noted the Committee's view that it is essential that the uses of the tax file number be strictly quarantined so as to protect the privacy of the Australian community and so as to ensure that the tax file number proposal does not become a surrogate means of establishing a broader identification system.

The Government further noted the acknowledgment of the Committee that it is always open to Parliament to amend legislation, with the exception of the Constitution, in the usual way (paragraph 10.22). There have been occasions since 1988 when different uses of the tax file numbers have been the subject of scrutiny by Parliament.

Some of the amendments to the tax file number legislation have been purely administrative in nature. However, others have had the effect of connecting the revenue and income support systems more closely because most income support payments are income tested.

The latter category involves the tax file number being a pre-requisite for payment of income support and home owner grant entitlements. This approach was taken so that statements by claimants for income support as to their income and domestic circumstances could be independently and automatically verified. The Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990 which was given Royal Assent on 23 January 1991 provides the authority for matching taxation and assistance agency data using the tax file number.

In addition, the Government welcomed the Committee's recommendations in relation to privacy legislation including the principles by which privacy may be protected, the establishment of an independent Privacy Commissioner, and the means of enforcing the principles.

In his Second Reading Speech on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill 1988, the Treasurer foreshadowed that privacy legislation was to be introduced. The Privacy Bill was introduced to Parliament on 1 November 1988. In an effort to protect the rights of individuals, the Bill:
proposed the establishment of the Privacy Commissioner;
set out information Privacy Principles;
vested power in the Privacy Commissioner to develop privacy guidelines; and
articulated rules relating to enforcement, penalties and compensation.

The Bill received Royal Assent on 14 December 1988 and came into effect on 1 January 1989; the same date of effect as for the tax file number legislation. On a number of occasions since that time, the Privacy Commissioner has been involved in consultations with the Commissioner of Taxation in relation to privacy matters concerning tax file numbers. Those consultations have included discussions covering the employment, investment and welfare uses of tax file numbers. and the matching of information using tax file numbers as allowed by the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act.

The Government is satisfied that individuals' right to privacy is adequately addressed and acknowledged in the administration of the tax file number system. (This was reflected in the May 1989 Report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration into the Administration of the Tax File Number System.)
The Government is satisfied that the Committee's recommendations regarding privacy have been fully implemented.

Finally, the Government noted the suggestion of Senators Hill and Alston that the ATO should, before proceeding to upgrade the tax file number system, make further efforts to extend its existing names and addresses matching system to interest reports for partnership, trust and corporate taxpayers. In doing so, Senators Hill and Alston correctly identified this as one of the major problem areas for the ATO, highlighted in the ATO's submission to the Committee. In actual fact, this is one of the key areas which the tax file number is intended to address. The reality is that there is no more accurate, efficient and effective way of matching vast volumes of externally obtained data to client computer records than to use a high integrity numbering system such as the upgraded tax file number. This is clearly evidenced in the private sector where business organisations use their unique client identifiers to accurately match millions of credit vouchers each year. The essential point is that whereas a `names and addresses' matching system results in confusion and thereby inability to correctly match examples, a numbering system avoids that problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to speak to the government response to a report that the Standing Committee on Community Affairs presented earlier last year. This was a unanimous report by the committee, which worked very hard and held many consultations around the country. The issue is of vital importance. It affects many women, most particularly those over the age of 50. That the committee was able to come up with a unanimous report speaks very highly of the work of the committee and the hard work of the secretariat. We today have the government response to its report.

PARA.TAB: The committee made 27 recommendations in the original report. Of them, the government either accepted or supported 24. For a committee, that is not a bad rate at which to score support. It is an issue that traverses a number of things that are also the responsibility of the states. That would have made it more difficult in responding to the report. I understand from quickly reading part of the response that our report was sent to a number of the states for them to also comment. Some of their replies have been fed back into this response, which is very important.

I will highlight a couple of areas that I notice are outside the resolve of the Commonwealth to deal with. But there is a response, and things are being taken to the Australian Health Ministers Conference. One in particular is improving the level of travel and accommodation assistance available to women living in areas outside the major metropolitan areas who require radiotherapy treatment. Whilst this is primarily a matter for the states, concerns about the recommendation will be referred to the Australian Health Ministers Conference. That is a very important move and the way to go. As I said, our report traversed a number of areas that are also the concern of the states. The fact that they are going to be brought to the attention of the states is very important.

Another vitally important issue that we dealt with is the collection of statistics by the cancer registries of the states and territories. We recommended that the statistics collected by state and territory cancer registries be collected on a more uniform and consistent basis and that the data on cancers generally be provided to the Commonwealth government on a timely and regular basis to ensure that current national statistics on the incidence of cancers are readily available.

The government supported the recommendation in principle. However, it is powerless to do very much about it because it is dependent upon what happens at the state level. The uniformity of data collection is being addressed by the National Cancer Statistics Clearing House at the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare in conjunction with the state and territory cancer registries. I commend those organisations involved in doing that.

At present, the core set of data and the standards imposed on this data are robust and directly comparable. That is also very important because we want to be able to compare the incidence, mortality and morbidity figures of breast cancer not only within Australia but internationally to know whether some of the treatment mechanisms that we are using are working.

The response goes on to state that the timely reporting of national cancer incidence data is dependent on the supply of data from the state and territory cancer registries. While some cancer registries are able to provide data 18 months after the completion of the calendar year, others are not able to supply data for up to four years after the completion of the calendar year. It gives several reasons for this: the nature of cancer reporting, such as the compilation of multiple reporting sources; the lack of resources; the volume of the case load; historical impediments; and legislative inadequacies.

The Australian Institute of Health and Welfare and state and territory cancer registries are attempting to improve the timeliness of national incidence reporting. We noticed when we started our inquiry that the reporting of incidence by a number of cancer registries was very out of date; some registries were more than four years out of date. Our inquiry served as a fillip to some of the states to get their registries up to date and to report on a more timely basis. To me, that is an extremely important issue and one that I hope the states will continue to address.

The importance of the treatment regimes and being able to evaluate screening programs is dependent upon getting good, accurate and timely data through. If that is not going to happen in all the states in this country, we are going to find that we do not know where there is a timelag—that is quite significant if it is four years—in being able to evaluate and implement alterations and changes that need to be brought into play. I very much urge the states to take on board the need for this and to do something about improving the timeliness of their reporting.

At the back of the response, an attachment outlines the national program for the early detention of breast cancer and its communication strategy. We found a lack of education and knowledge in the community. For example, women under 50 are not encouraged to come. Women under 40 are certainly not included in the program because it is a mammographic screening program, not a diagnostic program. The difference between screening and diagnostic mammography is not well understood in the general community. I am pleased to see that there is a national program.

There is also a list of the terms of reference for the National Breast Cancer Centre, which was announced just as we were finishing our report. We obviously made a recommendation for it to fulfil a role which is outside what its role was going to be. We did that because we were not sure in our own minds. There is also a listing under the heading `Policy and practice in relation to symptomatic women in the program'. We thought about that issue very deeply, because it involves what is done if people with signs and symptoms who turn up to a clinic are loathe to go elsewhere. It also involves how they are incorporated into the mainstream system so that they do not go away, decide that they have made one attempt to have their problem dealt with and, because they did not get the response they hoped to get, do not bother again. That is also dealt with in this report.

I know that our sister committee in the other place is now compiling a report on the treatment of breast cancer. I await its report with a great deal of interest. I thank everybody who was involved in this report for their contribution. We have made a valuable contribution to this issue. That is borne out by the fact that the government has endorsed just about every one of our recommendations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend Senator West on this report from the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, of which I am a member. She was the chairman of that committee at the time. I also commend the government response. There must be few occasions when a government response is published with the endorsement of the opposition and the unanimous endorsement of the Senate committee concerned.

PARA.TAB: I want to refer to two aspects that are subsequent to the publication of the report and the government response. There are dangers in the program in so far as the recent publications on this issue show that 70 per cent of the target numbers have to respond to screening for it to be shown to be successful. That figure is not being achieved.

The second aspect of it is that we have discovered since the initiation of this inquiry that women are not going back for re-screening after two years. If that does not occur, the program will fall down in terms of the early detection of breast cancer. There is a tendency for women to have a mammogram and say, `I have had my mammogram. I do not have breast cancer'—even knowing that one in 10 will not show up anyway. Having said that, time elapses, they forget and they do not go back for re-screening.

Two major issues must be addressed: firstly, women in the target group must come forward to have a mammogram; and, secondly, they must be re-screened. If 70 per cent of the target group do not come forward and then they all do not come back for re-screening, it will be a waste of money in terms of being able to prove that it has had an effect on the Australian community. With those two caveats, I am very happy to recommend the acceptance of the government response to the report of the Senate standing committee.

I still have one issue to raise with the government and that is in relation to the funding of biopsy, which is a removal of the suspect area to prove whether it is a cancer or not. Our recommendation was that biopsy should not be included. Admittedly, it is a state problem, but, speaking as a surgeon, it is essential in the management of the woman who has breast cancer, particularly from the surgical aspect, that the treatment should continue after the biopsy and that it should not be part of the screening program. If it is part of the screening program, the woman is handed over to the surgeon, having had surgery of some kind or another. This often distorts the picture and does not give the surgeon the full knowledge that he or she needs to have in managing that particular patient. It is a somewhat minor thing from the report's point of view but major to the individual patient concerned.

As a result of our report and the government's response the National Breast Cancer Centre was established. I am very happy to report that the centre has produced its first publication which is to go to every general practitioner and surgeon in Australia to bring them up to date with the current management and detection of breast cancer. I particularly want to commend Emeritus Professor Tom Reeve, who was appointed head of that National Breast Cancer Centre, for the speed with which he has initiated the program and the quality and accuracy of the document that has been produced.

If we cast our minds back, we will see that in the last two years breast cancer has become a major issue within the Australian public's consciousness, not only from women's point of view but from the whole of the public's point of view. The NHMRC has been directed to pay particular attention to this and separate funds have been issued to be spent on the early detection of breast cancer.

When I look back on my time in the Senate, I can speak with pride about the fact that I initiated this within the Senate itself and it had the concurrence of the Democrats, my coalition partners and the Labor Party. This is a unanimous report, as Senator West has mentioned. Speaking as a professional in this field, I was aware of the fact that something needed to be done to raise this topic within the community.

It is an ongoing topic. The incidence of the disease is increasing. It will get worse as time goes on because of the ageing of the population. This is something that we will have to come back to at a future date. I am quite delighted about the raising of consciousness within the community and the fact that we have been able to put the pressure on the states to do something about it. The Victorian government has allowed its electoral roll to be used. This had not happened previously. I commend the response.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation and the Arts Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The main point that I want to stress very briefly this afternoon is the slowness of the government's response with respect to what is really a very important issue. We have seen extensively around Australia outbreaks of blue-green algae. Several years ago we saw 1,000 kilometres of the Darling River infected with blue-green algae and the impossibility for quite some time for people along the river to use that water because of its toxic nature.

PARA.TAB: We have had repeatedly in South Australia outbreaks of algae in the lower part of the Murray, specifically in the area of Lake Alexandrina and Lake Albert, and this has made it impossible for people in the townships of Clayton, Strathalbyn and places like that to again use water for irrigation, stock purposes or, indeed, for human consumption. In the last fortnight I have heard that the people in Strathalbyn have had to switch to alternative water supply. It is a serious problem and one which is increasing in severity and in its spread. It seems to me from reading this government response that it is a totally inadequate response to a very important problem.

In a sense, the blue-green algae outbreaks are really only an indicator of a much more serious underlying problem with our water supplies—namely, that the quality of the water with respect to such things as tepidity, temperature, flow, nutrient content is deteriorating. What happens at the end of that long chain is that sometimes one has an outbreak of algae and that, in a sense, is an indicator of this deteriorating quality. For those reasons, I think it requires a much more vigorous and timely response than is indicated by this report.

The report itself was published, as the document indicates, in December 1993. The government response refers back to the December 1992 statement on the environment by the then Prime Minister in which he gave a Commonwealth commitment to assist in the improvement of water quality. That was in December 1992; it is now almost February 1995.

One finds that throughout this report the government is taking note of the recommendations of the committee, that it is supporting the recommendations, but in fact very little is actually happening. This is against the deteriorating quality of water. Adelaide, for instance—fortunately, although I live in Adelaide, I do not have to drink Adelaide's water; I live in the Adelaide hills and have my own water supply—is seriously in danger of losing its water supply. If there is a combination of very low winter rainfall, similar to what we had in the last year, and high summer temperatures, an outbreak of blue-green algae would make it impossible for Adelaide to pump water from the Murray. In dry years the Adelaide city is sometimes dependent up to almost 90 per cent on Murray water being pumped into the essentially empty catchments of the Adelaide hills and then reticulated down to people in Adelaide itself.

I think that in itself is an extremely serious problem which has not received the sort of response that it should have from government. For instance, on page 3 the government's response states that there is:

SPEECH.PARA: growing community concern about the gradual deterioration in the quality of the nation's water bodies.
That is an admission by government that there is a gradual deterioration, despite the fact that it gave an undertaking in December 1992 to do something about it. It further states:
The Strategy will set an overall strategic direction for water quality management and is based on the principles . . .

It is still future tense. The government is still about to do something. The government has not actually done anything despite the fact that it has been aware of this situation for quite a considerable period.

PARA.TAB: When one turns to the government's response to the specific recommendations of the report one finds that in relation to the country towns water supply improvement program the government has put up $16 million over a period of four years—that is, $4 million per year for the water supply of country towns throughout the whole of Australia. The government response goes on to point out:

SPEECH.PARA: In 1993-94 as a result of the Statement the Commonwealth provided assistance of $4.5 million to 41 wastewater projects in small centres . . .

This is of the order of $100,000 each. It is a totally inadequate amount of finance to undertake the very important work which is necessary. Again turning to the Murray-Darling system, we know that many of the small towns along that very important waterway have inadequate waste water treatment, have inadequate sewage treatment and have inadequate treatment of nutrient run-off from farms. That is what is leading to the nutrient build-up in the Murray-Darling system and ultimately to the toxic blue-green algae.

PARA.TAB: I mention one other issue that I think should have been attacked far more vigorously by government: the issue of phosphorus in detergents—in household detergents, washing detergents and a range of commercially-used detergent products. The committee has made recommendations in relation to these detergents. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that existing and proposed campaigns to achieve lower phosphate levels in detergents through marketing strategies be continued.
It further states:
. . . if a significant reduction in levels of phosphorus in detergents has not been achieved within two years—
we are already halfway through that period—
then legislation be enacted to reduce levels or to ban phosphates in detergents.

These are quite reasonable recommendations which came from the committee. But we find again that the government is leaning over backwards to be kind to the detergent industry. I will read one sentence which I found quite horrifying when I read it. It states:

It should be noted that reducing or eliminating phosphorus in detergents may not be enough to have a significant impact on reducing algal blooms while there are other sources of phosphorus reaching waterways and while there is already a store of phosphorus in streams and sediments.

In other words, the government is saying that, because two or three sources of phosphorus are getting into our streams, we will not tackle this very important source—namely, detergents, which could be tackled very quickly and very easily. Surely, any reduction in the levels of phosphorus is important, particularly in a country like Australia where many of the soils are very low in phosphorus and where, under those conditions, phosphorus is the critical nutrient not only in soil with respect to weed growth but also in our waterways.

PARA.TAB: The government response goes on to talk about the most acceptable mechanism from an industry perspective being the use of economic instruments. In other words, there is an ideological commitment to protecting the needs of industry rather than protecting the needs of the environment.

I simply stress that water is one of the most critical resources in this country. We have an extremely dry continent. We have a continent in which water is the limiting resource for much of our activity. We have a problem with deteriorating water quality. It is urgent for government to take the longer term view. I mentioned this earlier in connection with woodchips and the need for governments over the last three or four decades to have gone into plantation forestry.

Here we have another example of the need for longer term strategies. Unless government does not take note now of the importance of water, unless government does not act to remove phosphorus from detergents—remember that not too many years ago we did not have detergents; we used soap, and we got by quite well without phosphorus in detergents, so we can do it—and unless government is prepared to act and act vigorously, the problems which we are creating for future generations with respect to the quality of water will be very severe indeed.

Those impacts will be just as serious in the economic area as they will be in the social, human and environmental area. It is very short-sighted of government to be looking at the present industries and not looking at the needs of industry in the long term and the economic impacts which environmental deterioration will have on this country if government does not have a more adequate response to this issue than is indicated by this totally inadequate response to this committee report we have before us this afternoon.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The government responded to the report of the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee by putting down this response on 12 December 1994. We are all aware that the government did well to have it ready for the final week of the Senate sitting last December, but there was a great congestion of business. I do not want to make any cheap points about it being put down on the first working day after the Senate rose. Rather, I wish to commend the spirit in which this whole inquiry was undertaken: with the utmost seriousness to seek a comprehensive inquiry by the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee of the Senate and to gain the most positive response from the government towards our findings to see all the measures in place that would most seek to eliminate sexual harassment in the navy, army and air force—from the defence forces of Australia.

PARA.TAB: The government's response is very much in that spirit. There is a real sincerity and substance in the way in which the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mr Punch, advised by the Defence Force senior officers and indeed by the three services—the navy, army and air force—has responded to what I believe is one of the best Senate reports.

Senator Jones, who is in the chamber and is the chairman of the committee, Senator Ellison, who also participated on that inquiry, and I, along with three other senators, have been commended by the government for the useful work that has been completed. We are impatient only to see in practice the actual implementation of the findings of the report in which we have placed a great deal of confidence.

The background set out by the minister in the response is accurate. So is the context in which there is unanimity on the committee's part and the government's part that we firmly endorse the principle of equal opportunity for women in the Australian Defence Force. The government accepts fully the Senate committee's recommendation in the report that there needs to be enhanced education of gender related issues in the three services.

A summary of the Senate report and a structure for the government's response is given. This usefully says that, although we had 42 recommendations, many of them were quite long and in several parts, and the government is responding not only to the 42 recommendations but to the 66 separate components of the Senate committee's report. Fifty-three of the 66 are fully supported. We welcome that. My remarks will concentrate for a few minutes on those others which the minister has listed. Four were supported in principle; five were supported in part; only two of the 66 are not supported; and a further two are still under examination.

There is a degree of misunderstanding in the government's perception of what our report said about the 13 recommendations that are not fully supported. No doubt that is partly the fault of our not writing it more clearly and partly because of some errors of communication. This misunderstanding particularly relates to recommendations 1 and 2 that concern the Sex Discrimination Act. We are all aware that the only person in Australia who took any exception at all to this report was the Sex Discrimination Commissioner. I thought that whilst she was no doubt trying to responsibly carry out the duties of her office, her remarks were rather emotional and overly verbose.

With regard to the heart of the Sex Discrimination Act, which the commissioner rightly must ensure is implemented, she is in some way being put at significant risk by our call in recommendations 1 and 2 that there be amendments to three matters in that act: the hierarchy of complaints of sexual harassment; the advantage, wherever it is possible, to the complainant in informing the alleged harasser that his or her behaviour was offensive; and the provision of appropriate mechanisms, differentiated mechanisms, for dealing with the different degrees of seriousness of unlawful behaviour. We have in mind in particular that this will impact upon the army, the air force and the navy, because every member of the defence services is subject—as are all Australians—to the Sex Discrimination Act.
I stand by not only recommendations 1 and 2 but by all of the recommendations of this report. I refer the government again to pages 30 and 31 of our report. On page 30 of that report, we said:

SPEECH.PARA: The junior female officers on the SWAN told the Committee, for example, that the reaction of many of the crew after the unfavourable publicity it received in September 1993, was to withdraw from the normal interaction that had been developing, as the men came to accept the women's professionalism during the course of the deployment. A mixture of resentment and uncertainty among the male personnel over where the line on unacceptable behaviour was to be drawn had the effect of isolating the women.

We were referring to an unfortunate development which we were trying to remedy. Also, in the next paragraph we referred to the vagaries of the Sex Discrimination Act, which defines a `reasonable person' and which also has subjective elements with regard to the person feeling harassed. We have every sympathy for the law as it is now written.

PARA.TAB: Let me put it this way: the second best situation is the Sex Discrimination Act as it is now written, but we are seeking, with regard to the practicalities of the army, the air force and the navy, some flexibility and some more certainty to be given so that men and women in the defence services are not driven to the difficulties that I have just tried to outline. To do that, we brought forward recommendations 1 and 2.

Of course there are going to be situations where a person who is being harassed will find it totally obnoxious and impossible to confront their harasser. That is often the case in serious cases, and the Sex Discrimination Commissioner says that that is the case in the majority of cases in which complaints are brought. I do not argue with any of that. I do not want to have any argument with the Sex Discrimination Commissioner, whose work is so important. Rather, I ask for that degree of sympathy for the flexibility that we had been seeking to note the hierarchy of complaints.

Sexual harassment can be someone displaying some offensive photograph. We call that a degree of sexual harassment. It is not directed at any individual, and it is not seeking any particular favour from any particular individual. Another level of harassment is where some person touches another person most offensively, or even offensively. That is another higher or more serious level of offence. A very serious offence would be a person requiring a sexual favour of another person in order for that person to gain some advantage or not to suffer some detriment.

We saw in the navy in particular, but also in the army and air force, that this whole range of offences could land the offender, or the alleged offender, before the Sex Discrimination Commission. Therefore there was uncertainly amongst many personnel that, if they put up a particular photograph in one part of their cabin, this could lead them to be taken before the Sex Discrimination Commissioner because it can be construed, given the subjective element in the definition of what is in fact offensive, as offending in terms of sexual harassment?

I ask the government to please look again at recommendations 1 and 2. Please try to understand what we said on pages 30 and 31. We are in no way wanting to insist that it be compulsory that a person being offended must go and speak with the person who is the alleged offender. We want that only where that is reasonable; only where that is going to stop a cumulative effect and actually nip something in the bud so that it does not become a serious offence. I accept the government's response to recommendation 2, which says that, whilst not putting this in legislation, it agrees with the committee but asks that this be a policy matter at the local level.

These are the two main areas where the government is disagreeing with the committee. I note that the other two matters that are still under examination—27 and 39V(a)—are dealing with trials where there are allegations of sexual assault. We are recommending that they be dealt with by a civilian criminal court and, similarly, the investigation towards the trial be dealt with by civilian investigation. This would be the case if the offence occurred anywhere in Australia but, if it occurs outside Australian waters, it would lead to only a court martial being applicable. We want that element to be carefully examined. It is being examined by Attorney-General's and Defence. We will, of course, listen very carefully to the analysis that eventually comes forward. I reiterate that I support the original recommendations.

The other matters supported in part are actually fully understandable. I do not see any difficulty with regard to visits, to telling an offender, to training, to reviewing the electronic warfare section, and to whether the 008 confidential advisory service is amalgamated or remains as three separate telephone numbers. With regard to the support in principle, the government response is understandable.

In summary, I very much welcome the government's response and ask that it give a more sympathetic reading to what we meant with regard to recommendations 1 and 2. We will listen very carefully to the eventual examination of recommendations 27 and 39V(a).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too wish to comment on the inquiry into sexual harassment in the Australian Defence Force. As Senator Teague said, I was chairman of the committee that conducted the inquiry. I am very grateful that the government's response has, to a large extent, supported the recommendations made by the committee. Of the recommendations, 53 were supported, four were supported in principle, six in part and one was under examination. Only two recommendations were not supported and I will come back to those later. The two recommendations that were not supported were also referred to by Senator Teague.

PARA.TAB: Pressure of time precludes me from covering every recommendation, but I would like to comment on several points. In a number of instances the government response draws attention to written orders and pamphlets et cetera as sources for advice on various aspects of military life. These documents are useful as far as they go, but I cannot stress strongly enough the need to deal on a personal level with the many issues associated with sexual harassment. This includes such a basic decision as the choice of a military career. These issues need to be dealt with on a person to person basis or in a small discussion group.

No matter how much information is contained in documents, they cannot be seen as an adequate replacement for open, frank and informative discussion and dialogue about the personal issues involved. One aspect of this—the need for mixed gender focus groups of ADF personnel—is covered in recommendation 39-II(A). The response, which supports the proposal, says:

SPEECH.PARA: Each of the services has mixed gender focus groups in place. When the Defence instruction is reviewed in November 1995 the input from the service focus groups will be carefully considered.

It would be very interesting to know how extensive these focus groups really are. It is puzzling that no mention of these groups was made in the original submissions to the committee. Several of the committee's recommendations relate to the need for a practical guide to all personnel for dealing with instances of unacceptable sexual behaviour. The government's response tells us that headquarters of the ADF, in conjunction with the department, have prepared a detailed document entitled Eliminating harassment in the integrated defence environment. It is to be hoped that this document will be available to every individual in the ADF and that it incorporates a section on conflict resolution.

PARA.TAB: The committee urged that the ADF-wide awareness raising seminars should be supplemented by more specific training for any person wishing to develop skills and techniques for dealing with such harassment at the inter-personal level. The government's response supports the proposal and outlines the supplementary training offered by the three service. It should be noted that the response makes no mention of the Australian Defence Force Academy.

The committee felt there was a need for the introduction of an external conflict resolution process. The response details the present channels available for conflict resolution. The section on the army's community justice program lists medical officers as among those available to provide conflict resolution. It is questionable on the evidence whether they have the training and capability to provide such a service.

One matter raised during the committee's hearings was the question of the need for investigating officers to be appointed from outside the unit where the alleged incident occurred. While the response says that the ADF is sensitive to this issue, I would point out that it puts the view that individually deployed units must have the capability of conducting internal investigations. It also says that, if the commanding officer perceives that an investigation may not be impartial, guidance will be sought from a superior officer to appoint an appropriate investigating officer.

It is my view, and I believe the committee's view, that in all but exceptional circumstances the investigating officer should be from outside the unit. The officer should not be acquainted with any parties involved in the incident. It is imperative that in any incident the complainant and the alleged offender must be apprised of their right to ask the commanding officer for an external investigating officer. The overriding principle must be that justice is done and seen to be done.

I would now like to comment on the two recommendations that Senator Teague commented on. Neither recommendation was supported by the government's response. Recommendation 1 and 2 are interlinked and address the basic question addressed by the committee. A very important issue addressed in the committee's report was the damage that is done if sexual harassment is not dealt with promptly. Situations that may initially be mild or based on misunderstanding are allowed to fester and develop into major problems.

The committee sought to encourage early intervention to resolve a situation that is unsatisfactory to someone before that situation evolves into a formal complaint. Once a situation or formal complaint has been reached, the prospects are that all parties to the complaint—the complainant as well as the alleged harasser—will be hurt. Even if an apology is given or monetary compensation is paid to the complainant, the complainant will inevitably carry the stigma of being called a whinger or someone who does not meet with the requirements that are held within the establishment they are working in. The committee felt that, if possible, such a situation should be pre-empted.

Sexual harassment should be nipped in the bud before the parties involved are damaged. It was with this in mind that the committee put forward recommendation 2. It is disappointing that the recommendation has not been accepted by the government. The committee particularly noted the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission's training package for managers. This package encourages in-house informal resolution of sexual harassment complaints, yet it was not developed until 1993—nearly 10 years after the sex discrimination legislation was passed.

The emphasis has been on punishment for wrongdoing rather than education to pre-empt wrongdoing. Greater clarity for employers about their responsibilities, as set out in recommendation 2, would ensure better outcomes for all those involved. The government's response to recommendation 2 refers to an alleged lack of clarity—and I suppose the committee in some way must accept the responsibility for that—on whether recourse to in-house facilities would be a precondition to the lodging of a formal complaint. This is a matter which can be looked at in different ways.

The issue would have been clearer had the government accepted the committee's recommendation 1. This recommendation said that there should be a clearer distinction between serious sexual harassment, such as brutal sexual assault, and the more mild irritants that are perceived by some people as offensive. In instances of less serious types of sexual harassment, it would then have made sense to make in-house efforts or involvement of an outside body part of the informal conflict resolution.

The in-house efforts or the outside involvement—such as by the Sex Discrimination Commissioner—would be a precondition for formal complaint. Where the harassment is, by community standards, widely regarded as serious, and there is no ambiguity about the offence, then clearly a direct formal complaint to an outside body would be appropriate. The finetuning involved in implementing recommendation 2 should not pose any major obstacles if the basic need to resolve difficulties before they get out of hand is kept clearly in mind. Sexual harassment appears to be a straightforward matter but, as the committee soon found, it is a very complex issue.

Finally, the committee was very pleased with the constructive way in which the government handled the other recommendations made by the committee. The work of the committee and the report that it produced were a credit to the members of the committee and to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I fully support what Senator Jones said on this matter, in particular the way that the committee conducted itself in carrying out this most delicate and difficult inquiry. I believe that this report will stand as a beacon for future years on this problem of sexual harassment.

PARA.TAB: Although the committee's terms of reference related to incidents that occurred on HMAS Swan in 1992 and also to the question of sexual harassment generally in the armed services, I believe that the wider community as a whole could benefit from this report. I think the government has realised that fact in its response to this report. It is interesting to note that, out of the number of recommendations that the committee made, there are only two that the government does not support. I believe that both Senator Jones and Senator Teague have eloquently touched on the problems that confronted the committee and the problems addressed in recommendations Nos 1 and 2.

I believe that the government has misunderstood recommendation No. 2 of the committee, which was aimed at the early resolution of sexual harassment problems in the workplace. It was not a recommendation that stated that employers should take all reasonable steps to prevent an employee from engaging in unlawful acts of sexual harassment so that any victim of sexual harassment would first have to avail himself or herself of those `reasonable steps' and that not to do so would preclude that person from lodging a formal complaint with an outside body. It was not as structured and strict as that.

TALK.START.PARA: —We weren't proposing a legal hurdle.
—As Senator Teague says, the committee was not proposing a legal hurdle, and that is where the government misunderstood the recommendation. The government said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is not clear from the Recommendation whether recourse to `in house' facilities would be a precondition to the lodging of a formal complaint with an outside body.

The committee was looking for the employer to take all reasonable steps to put in place a system whereby the matter could be nipped in the bud internally—at the workplace, within the place of employment—and sorted out by negotiation—that is, by some form of conciliation between the parties—and thereby would not have to go on to any civil action in the courts. That is what the committee was getting at in recommendation 2. During the course of this inquiry, I believe, the committee found that there were a good many instances of sexual harassment which could be sorted out at that level without any formal litigation or sanction against an individual.

PARA.TAB: In relation to recommendation No. 1, the situation is more complex. The committee recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: that the definition of sexual harassment under the Sex Discrimination Act be redefined to reflect more clearly
. the hierarchy of complaints;
.the advantage, where possible, of the complainant informing the alleged harasser that his or her behaviour is offensive;
.the appropriate mechanisms and legal sanctions for the different degrees of seriousness of the unlawful behaviour.

Quite clearly, there are varying degrees of human behaviour. We have recognised this in the law with our recognition of the varying degrees of assault. You can have common assault, assault occasioning bodily harm and assault occasioning grievous bodily harm. That recognises the degree of behaviour.

Similarly, a degree of inappropriate sexual behaviour has been recognised in the various states. I believe that, in the instance of sexual harassment, it is no different. I believe there should be recognition of a hierarchy of situations, starting with the lowest form of sexual harassment and going right through to the most serious form.

PARA.TAB: Since the events on the Swan in 1992, the question of sexual harassment has been canvassed a great deal in the wider community. At the moment, we have an American motion picture entitled Disclosure on this very subject. In fact, it provokes some thought by the viewer in that it is a woman who is perpetrating the sexual harassment against a male subordinate. That is not commonly regarded as the average instance of sexual harassment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has never happened to me.

—As Senator Campbell says, it has never happened to him, and I would not wish it upon anyone. Nonetheless, the fact is that it is now a very important matter which is under consideration in the wider community. I believe that this motion picture has reflected on that. The attention that it has attracted reveals this factor.

PARA.TAB: In recommendation 1, the committee looked at the question of what is sexual harassment. In Australia, we have a society of cultures. As the committee stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Australian society, perhaps more than most, is made up of a mosaic of cultural backgrounds and experiences. What is acceptable to one person may be unacceptable to another.
Professor Kirsner said:
. . . many people come from cultures or families where touching is a routine and supportive activity.

When we look at the wider Australian community, we have to have regard to the fact that there are many different cultures. There are people in the workplace who have varied approaches to how you deal with grief and joy. Some people are more exuberant than others. Some people believe in touching more than is the case with other people. Some people are quite inhibited. What may be thought to be a very harmless gesture by one person can be received as quite offensive by another. It falls upon the legislature to bring in legislation which covers this situation and takes into account the varying degrees of human behaviour. It was Ms Triulzi, who had been engaged by the Navy, who stated:
. . . what we need to understand is that there are lots of elements of grey in understanding what sexual harassment is and is not, and how we distinguish and differentiate those levels of grey.

That precisely is the point that the committee was looking at in recommendation 1. In December 1992, section 28 of the Sex Discrimination Act was amended. What was previously a more objective test was changed to a more subjective test, so that the offence that is created is as follows:
a person sexually harasses another person ("the person harassed") if:
(a) the person makes an unwelcome sexual advance, or an unwelcome request for sexual favours, to the person harassed;
or
(b) engages in other unwelcome conduct of a sexual nature in relation to the person harassed;
in circumstances in which a reasonable person, having regard to all the circumstances, would have anticipated that the person harassed would be offended, humiliated or intimidated.

I stress the words `would have anticipated that the person harassed would be offended'. That requires a person in such an instance as the workplace to anticipate what the other person will feel. This becomes increasingly hard, having regard to the fact that I have mentioned—the diverse cultures and backgrounds that Australian society has.

PARA.TAB: One could be in a factory where there are many people of different nationalities and descents, and one has to go through this exercise of anticipation. One has to look at the other person who may have just won the lottery, or at someone whose close relative may have just died. One then has to ask oneself, `Is it sexual harassment if I put my arm around this woman and say, "My condolences", or if I slap this person on the back and say, "Congratulations on winning the lotto"'? The average person cannot possibly go through that exercise.

I think the government has ignored the problem with a lack of definition. That is precisely what this committee came up against all throughout this inquiry: what precisely is sexual harassment? I join with Senator Teague in asking the government to reconsider this.

I join with Senator Jones, who chaired the committee, in expressing disappointment at the fact the government did not not support the recommendations. In fact, I believe that Ms Walpole, the Sex Discrimination Commissioner, took somewhat of a trite view in saying that that definition was sufficient and that there was no problem. It was not her role to be there of course, but it could have been of great assistance to her if she had been with us throughout the inquiry to see what level of grey there was. In a very minor instance someone could extend sympathy by putting their arm around a person's shoulder—that is at the low end of the scale—and that could be regarded as sexual harassment. It goes right through to someone touching a fellow worker in an offensive manner. In that say one can see the hierarchy of complaints and the area of grey.

Where legislation forbids this, I believe citizens must be given a clearer definition. If subjects throughout the country are to be expected to obey the law, they have to be given direction. It is our duty as legislators to tell them what they can and cannot do. I do not believe that section 28 of the Sex Discrimination Act does that. It leaves it to the individual to anticipate what another person might feel. I really do think it merits close attention.

Sexual harassment is an important matter. I believe this committee provided a beacon to the community at large in relation to the problems faced in the armed services. I believe the committee addressed those instances, in particular in relation to the HMAS Swan, admirably.

The committee, in recommendations 24, 25 and 26, urged reconsideration of the censure of Captain Mole and argued that he not be impeded in his promotion. These were very good recommendations indeed and I note the government's response to them. I have made inquiries and I believe that Captain Mole has since been promoted and that his censure, whilst not being removed as yet, is under review. I am happy to report that to the Senate because I believe that this officer was serving the navy and his country well. As a result of the attentions of some of the media in this instance, he suffered a great deal. In fact, he suffered a setback to his career generally in the navy. I believe the committee saw that and that is why the committee recommended those things. I thought it important to place that on the record.

Nonetheless, I urge the government to reconsider recommendations 1 and 2. I ask it to please look at that section in the Sex Discrimination Act. I would plead for an amendment to that section so that there be more clarity in the definition of what exactly constitutes sexual harassment.
Debate (on motion by Senator Panizza) adjourned.
