DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation and the Arts Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Hon D.G. Stewart to the Australian Soccer Federation dated 19 December 1994, together with the Australian Soccer Federation's response to that report dated 27 January 1995. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to that document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The two documents contained in the volume I have just tabled were received by the committee as evidence during its current inquiry into the role of national sporting coaches in the international transfer of Australian players, which was referred to the committee by resolution of the Senate on 8 December 1994. This inquiry has attracted wide public and community interest and the committee has decided to table these documents so that they may become available through the Australia-wide network of the Australian Government Publishing Service bookshops.

PARA.TAB: The committee held public hearings on this reference on Friday, 27 January 1995 in Sydney, at which the Hon. D.G. Stewart and Mr John Hegarty, the solicitor who assisted him in his inquiry, were heard. The committee also heard Mr John Constantine, the Chairman of the Australian Soccer Federation, and Mr Ian Holmes, the federation's chief executive officer, on that day. The committee is now proceeding with this inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a few comments on the Stewart report. I know that my colleague Senator Baume also wishes to say a few words. Firstly, I congratulate Senator Campbell, the shadow minister for sport, on bringing this matter forward. As a new member of this committee—I am only just availing myself of the facts—I must say I have been totally astounded by what seems to be coming out of this report.

PARA.TAB: Former Justice Donald Stewart did not have any powers of subpoena or any other powers that this Senate committee has, but what he unearthed I believe is the tip of the iceberg of what is quite scandalous behaviour in the transfer of soccer players. Naturally, it has received a fair amount of media coverage, because I think most Australians are concerned about sport. No doubt there will be a lot of discussion on this.

As the time for the discussion of government documents is approaching, I make the point that I was very impressed by the evidence given by Mr Hegarty and by former Justice Stewart. The additional evidence they brought forward to us under parliamentary privilege last Friday in Sydney is something that we will be discussing. Senator Baume and I will be speaking on this matter in the Senate, but just to give some indication of the situation, I would poiont out that a further document that came forward from Blackburn Rovers Football Club in the UK regarding the transfer of a Frank Talia shows that some $200,000 is missing.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Policy Council

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Policy Council performs an important role; namely, it provides a forum to consider industry issues and provides advice to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) from an industry perspective. I think this report outlines the number of important issues the council addressed during the year in review. It provided technical advice to the negotiation process of the Uruguay Round discussions, which we all hope is going to do some good for us.

PARA.TAB: The council has developed feedlot guidelines for the industry, which basically have been very worth while and very good for an industry that has increased in size and stature in Australia. It has also focused on establishing systems within the meat industry to provide more effective links between the producer and the consumer. While it is all very well for government bodies to work on these links, it is something that must be industry driven and meat producers themselves must appreciate the importance of the end user and the importance of, and the need for, consistency in the product.

That is something that has caused a great deal of concern in the last little while—the helix contamination of some of our beef into some of our export markets. Some people have said that the AMLC levy should have been used to help some of those people with the helix contamination problems. Basically, there is a big concern by all of those people who have beef contaminated by helix which, as everyone in this chamber knows, was used to spray cotton. It is probably one of the best and softest chemicals that has ever been used in the cotton industry, but the Japanese and the Americans have nil tolerance of it. When the residue levels get up to one or two, the non-tolerance areas will not accept the product.

The AMLC has a very big part to play in that contamination scare. I think the job will now be left to the AMLC to make sure those markets that have been hurt by that particular scare are recouped. Quite often some of those other countries use some of these things as non-tariff trade barriers. It is quite interesting that the Japanese use helix to spray vegetables and everything else but they have a nil tolerance of it if it is in imported beef.

The report lists a number of project objectives. I am sure many of those are not known about. It does not list what this council's administration costs are, so I cannot comment on whether industry is getting value or not. I think it is very important that any of these industry councils make sure they give full accountability to the producers who make the funds available to keep the councils going on behalf of the growers.

I understand that since this report was published the former chairman, Mr Bob McCarthy, has been replaced by Robin Bligh. I wish Mr Robin Bligh great success in his new job. I do not know the reasons for the change, but I am aware that there is some criticism within the industry of that change taking place. So I hope that the industry sticks together and does the right thing. If we are to have an industry council, the advice has to be objective. I hope that this is going to be so with the AMLIPC in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Brownhill's motion to take note of the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Policy Council annual report. The objectives of the council refer to a body called the residue management group. Its second key objective is to protect export and domestic markets for animal products from disruption to trade and financial losses caused by chemical residue detections. It is in that area that I wish to make a contribution tonight. There are a number of issues concerning the beef residue testing debacle that has come to pass through the feeding of drought affected cattle and even feedlot cattle with cotton trash treated with the chemical helix, which incidentally, as Senator Brownhill said, is a very effective method of killing caterpillars at certain stages of cotton production.

PARA.TAB: I have a number of concerns. Firstly, there seems to have been an extreme lack of leadership in the beginning, and a lack of understanding of the plight of farmers already suffering severe drought being isolated into areas regarded `at risk' and then being forced to substantially meet their own testing costs. The New South Wales government has, to its credit, given considerable assistance in this area. Secondly, the AMLC was not prepared to use its $5 million in residue testing funds which had been set aside, I assume, for precisely this purpose.

Thirdly, it seems that many northern cattle producers, both in New South Wales and Queensland, have been left in an appalling situation. The industry had washed its hands of many producers who had fed cattle through the most severe drought on record and who presently are unable to sell their cattle because they would be over the maximum residue level of this chemical. I am pleased to see that the New South Wales farmers are looking at some way of compensating these producers.

Fourthly, the fundamental point that seems to have been missed by the AMLC is that anything that interferes with Australia's legitimate claim as a clean and green supplier of beef to the world is a problem for all producers, not just for those presently affected by this particular residue problem. It is especially so for northern producers and Queensland producers. Their livelihood was further threatened by this unfortunate combination of drought and the CFZ chemical, which hopefully will not happen again.

The industry must be assured that in future a national management plan will be in place to handle future residue detection problems—and there will always be those problems. It must be there to answer questions quickly, to give leadership, to provide a speedy trace back of contaminants and, overall, to give confidence, to be of benefit to all producers and, most importantly, to give the sort of leadership our international market requires.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the first annual report of the Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation, the Greens WA objected in the beginning to the whole idea of a levy to fund this corporation. The idea of making money from chopping down trees to pay a bunch of industry representatives and bureaucrats to research how the industry can be sustainable is bizarre. I can be optimistic but, given the attitude prevalent in governments, it is likely that this will only be yet another smokescreen—like the national forest policy, the Resource Assessment Commission inquiry or the ESD forest policy—designed to divert attention, while the trees keep falling.

PARA.TAB: By now we know that the way to make the industry sustainable is by agroforestry or to regenerate plantations on degraded, already cleared land. We know that adding value is the answer, not just increasing export volume to make up for declining prices. We know that the answer is not to eliminate the last stands of old growth forest and then try to become sustainable. How much more research do we need? CALM has researched agroforestry for years, but what has it done? It has lacked the will to implement it.

Woodchipping is a tonnage export. It is a high volume, low value industry. It is a heavily mechanised industry that is shedding jobs as fast as possible. It is a large corporate dominated industry; it is a foreign dominated industry. It is not going to create great wealth, unless truly massive amounts of material are shipped out—and the actual benefits will be minimal, relative to expense and sensitive to price.

Since 1986 the price of woodchips has fallen dramatically. Brazil has brought seven million hectares of Eucalypt plantation on line; South-East Asia is bringing huge gum plantations on line; and Spain, Argentina, South Africa and China are all bringing gum plantations on line. These are all plantation based trees. Supply is up, the prices are down and the margins on woodchips are getting thinner.

Woodchipping is capital and technology intensive. It is highly mechanised in an effort to reduce labour costs. This is typical of high volume, low value products for basic economic reasons. It is not going to change. The trend to replace workers with expensive imported equipment will accelerate. The need for capital—usually foreign sourced capital—is also likely to accelerate. Three results will flow from this: jobs decrease relative to export volumes; imports increase relative to the profits from exports; and servicing of overseas loans increase as a portion of export earnings.

As further mechanisation occurs and volume of extraction increases, the use of intermediate inputs, such as fuel, increases. Where they are not imported, domestic supplies that could be used more productively are taken out of availability. Profits are also repatriated and so do not enter into multiplier effects here and are part of a capital outflow from Australia.

Finally, there is the issue of subsidy of forest products generally, and woodchipping specifically. Even without this, there are a number of factors which see money flowing out of the country as a consequence of the export of woodchips. This means that the actual contribution of woodchips to balance of payments is liable to be minimal or negative. At best, we are selling our forests for a mass of potage; at worst, we are paying people to take them away.

Then there is the issue of subsidy to the forest industry. A 1990 New South Wales Public Accounts Committee reported that the state's timber processing industry is heavily subsidised. A Tasmanian report by Saddler, Kohl and Graham concluded that:

SPEECH.PARA: Forestry Commission, bulk power subsidies and transport subsidies amount to over $80 million per year. This represents a direct cost to all other industries in the State, the Government taxes other industries in order to subsidise forestry operations. The economic consequences of this are obviously serious and contribute to Tasmania's low economic growth and high unemployment rate.
Other reports at various times have yielded similar results.

PARA.TAB: Put simply, these operations are not doing the economy any good. The only possible reason to allow them is a hatred of nature and a blind stupidity that believes that chopping down, digging up and killing things is a good way to be a hard-nosed pragmatist.

It is the Greens who are the practical people, the ones who wish to sit down with industry and work out a way through the current problems; and it is the woodchip advocates who are the ideologues. What are not included in this report are environmental goals; what are not included in this report are employment goals. If these were included, then we might get an outcome that we can look forward to, sitting down and working with those people who work in the industry, instead of just looking at the profits of very large corporations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was in the chamber to seek to speak on Aboriginal deaths in custody. But, as time is getting by, I daresay we will not get the opportunity to discuss that. However, I have been motivated to respond to that quite amazing contribution from Senator Margetts. Basically, what she has said to the people of Australia this evening is that the Greens are against the chopping down of any single tree, and that they are opposed to a most dynamic industry which has been very important in Australia's economy from the time of white settlement some 200 years ago.

PARA.TAB: The situation clearly is that it is within Australia's interests that there be research and development of forest and wood products. I would have thought that anybody who was genuinely concerned about Australia's future would be embracing a development corporation which is looking at developing our forest and wood products. I have to say that I agree it would be beneficial if our woodchips did not go overseas. But what happens? When we in Tasmania wanted a pulp mill at Wesley Vale—a mill which at that time would have been the most environmentally sensitive in the world—who were the most vehement opponents of it? It was the Green movement. So instead, the woodchips are being sent to Japan to be processed in a mill which is more environmentally damaging than the Tasmanian mill would have been. These people tell us to think globally and act locally—but their action with the Wesley Vale pulp mill was in exact contradiction to that policy.

Senator Margetts tells us that we ought to have studies and look at our forest and sustainability. We in Tasmania—as you, Mr Acting Deputy President, would know—have had to suffer in excess of a dozen studies. We have had the Helsham report and a whole host of others. But when it does not suit the Greens to adopt a report, they go for another one and another one and another one. Then, of course, Senator Margetts quotes from that famous report—which, I noted, had the name of one of the people from the staff of Senator John Devereux—as being one of the supposedly independent reports that they rely on. It is like the Greens, who seem to rely in Tasmania on their own polls, those that they conduct, and then try to sell them off to the community as having been done by an independent organisation, until they get caught out.

Really, the amount of muddying of the waters that has occurred in this forestry debate is tragic. I do not have a hatred of nature, as suggested by Senator Margetts; I believe that we ought to live in harmony with nature for the benefit of human endeavour. The way to do that is to use renewable resources, such as wood, such as hydro-electric power—as we have in our state—which harnesses natural resources for the benefit of humankind.

There is one thing the Greens will never admit to when they talk about nature and the world and all those wonderful things: human beings just happen to be part of nature; we are to live on this earth; we do have a place in this world. Just as much as rabbits might like to dig burrows for their homes and undermine little banks and trees from time to time, so human beings to make their homes in which they live will chop down trees. If that means that I am a hater of nature, then the chances are that the beavers in Canada, or wherever, that cut down little saplings to dam rivers are also haters of nature. If a little animal does it, it is okay; but when human beings want to do it, that is outrageous; that is a hatred of nature. It is about time that the Greens got onto this planet earth with both feet and realised that—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate on the motion to take note of the annual report of the Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation. I will make some very brief comments. This report would normally be commended by the Greens because it endeavours to look at forests and wood products and work out ways in which the industry can become sustainable.

PARA.TAB: If the timber industry were sustainable at present, then we would be in the happy position of the industry never needing to log old-growth and high conservation value forests. Unfortunately, this insistence that the industry cannot survive without logging in old-growth and high conservation value forests means that the industry is not sustainable. It also means that, because there is such a reliance by this industry on these native forests, when those forests are gone the industry will not be sustainable in any sense of the word. It is certainly not environmentally sustainable now.

It was pleasing to note that Senator Abetz said that renewable resources are what we are looking for. That is quite correct. I am very pleased to agree with Senator Abetz. However, in relation to the timber industry, renewable resources mean plantation and agro-forestry. Old-growth forests are not a renewable resource. Trees are renewable because they grow, but forests are not renewable.

Australia is very fortunate. It is an ancient continent. It has historic, beautiful, longstanding forests that have never been logged. If we log those forests that have never been logged before, then we are destroying them forever. They will never be renewed. Trees will grow, but forests are extinguished by the first logging and intrusion into them. Honourable senators need to learn the difference between trees, plantations and forests because old-growth forests are a unique ecosystem. They are very precious and valued world wide, but they do not seem to be valued in this country.

The list that the federal government has developed, which protects only some forests and leaves others vulnerable, even though the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) indicated they are high conservation value forests, is a hit list for the timber industry. It means that where you declare forests to be of high conservation value but you fail to have the political will to protect them, you render them vulnerable.

To claim that it is the state's responsibility to protect those forest areas against road making and other activities is an abrogation of the federal government's responsibility. The states have already said that they will not protect even those 509 areas that have been reserved for rescheduling and assessment. Therefore, what we are doing is throwing away something very valuable.

The forest research levy, from which this study will be financed and which some of my colleagues in the Senate agreed to, is actually a way of giving permission to log all forests and trees for $1 a tree, whether it comes from a sawmill or is imported. The very important point is that if there is a $1 levy for each tree and that levy does not differentiate between a plantation log and a 400-year-old tree, then we are giving moral permission, through this funding to the Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation, to act at the expense of our natural heritage.

It is of national interest that the federal and state governments do not have the political will to protect high conservation value forests and old-growth forests, and merely charge a levy of $1 per trunk. I take no joy from the fact that the levy goes to fund this organisation. I regret that, by this levy, we are giving moral permission for the destruction of our precious forest heritage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not come into the chamber to rebut some of the outrageous statements that the Greens have put on the record tonight, but I think it is an appropriate time to do that in defence of our native forests. Our forests are not disappearing. Australia has approximately 43 million hectares of native forest. Of that, just over seven million hectares, or one-sixth, of this estate forest is managed specifically on a sustainable basis for wood production. About one per cent of that seven million hectares is harvested and regenerated every year. That means that any area logged will, on average, not be logged again for 100 years.

PARA.TAB: The second point that is worth making is that the forests are not logged for woodchips alone. Timber is a natural and renewable resource competing with non-renewable commodities like steel, aluminium and plastic. Native forests are logged for the purpose of providing sawn timber for housing, furniture and for use in the construction industry. The waste from sawmilling is then either converted into woodchips or burnt or wasted at sawmills. Similarly, in the forests, trees from the harvest area that are unsuitable for sawmilling are either chipped or left to burn or rot. If woodchipping were to stop, sawmills would still need the same number of trees to be logged. The only difference would be that the by-product would be wasted, and that has been put on the record a couple of times today.

The third point is that no animal or plant has been threatened by logging. The federal government's Resource Assessment Commission determined with its exhaustive study into Australia's forests that there is no evidence that any plant or animal species has been threatened with extinction because of forest industry activities. Given that state forests have been logged for more than 100 years, this is sound evidence of the resilience of our forests.

The fourth point—and this is a question the Greens would like answered—is why do we not get all our wood from plantations? The reason is that Australia's wood needs are currently met about equally by domestic native forests, domestic plantations and imports. Australia's 100 million hectares of plantations could not supply further shortfalls from native forests. It simply means that we would have to import more. We presently have a current account deficit on the importation of timber or timber products of around $2 billion a year. If the Greens would like to see our current account deficit rise even more, then perhaps they should look to that as a solution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts is nodding again.

—She would do it by the importation of plastic sandals, I guess. The final point is why don't we use all the woodchips in Australia? The Greens would be interested in the reason for that, even though they probably know it. Due to the political uncertainty about the forests, which they engender, companies are not prepared to make the very large investment of up to a billion dollars that is needed to build plants for pulp and paper manufacturing in Australia. Senator Abetz, my colleague from Tasmania, knows a great deal about that. There is a provision in our export wood licences for chips to be first made available to domestic manufacturers for local processing. Only the surplus is exported.

—I endorse the comments of Senator Sandy Macdonald and point out that the Greens have misrepresented the facts today. Senator Chamarette should note that there are no 400-year-old trees being woodchipped. That is typical of the misrepresentation in this debate.
—You can see them going down the road at any time of any day.

—Senator Margetts, you are very good at ideals. When you stand up here you are the most idealistic person in the Senate, but that is what you should stick with. You should stick with your ideals because when you branched off into the financial areas you were utterly incorrect to say that the global markets for the forestry products are on the decline, that the margins are thinning. That is utterly incorrect. It is quite the opposite. Australia is losing valuable export opportunities because of this log jam.
—Order! Consideration of government documents is now concluded. It being 7.20 p.m., I propose the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the National Party in the Senate to extend our condolences to the family of Thomas Gilmore, who recently passed away at the great age of 87. During an extremely varied working life, Tom Gilmore served as both a federal parliamentarian in the Far North Queensland seat of Leichhardt and as a state parliamentarian in the seat of Tablelands—which is currently held by his son Tom Gilmore Jr.

PARA.TAB: A lifelong member of the National Party, Tom Gilmore was born in 1908 in the mining town of Wolframcamp, west of Mareeba. After leaving school at 14, Tom Gilmore undertook many diverse jobs and the experience gained from working with a wide variety of people from all walks of life enabled him to be an effective representative of the Queensland people when he entered politics later in his life. Tom worked as a clerk in a hardware store, a tally clerk on the wharves, cut sugarcane by hand—truly backbreaking work—and he was also an ambulance bearer and a fireman on a sugar mill locomotive.

In 1931, Tom Gilmore returned to the family tobacco farm and worked there until the outbreak of the Second World War when he joined the RAAF and served in Bundaberg and Sydney—age precluding him from participating in overseas war service. When he was demobbed in 1945, he was sent home to Mareeba with instructions to grow vegetables to feed the allied troops who were maintaining a strong presence in the area.

In 1949, Tom became an inaugural member of the Tobacco Leaf Marketing Board. That same year he won the federal seat of Leichhardt, becoming a member of the Menzies-Fadden government. A conscientious and hardworking member, he served the people of Leichhardt well and was unfortunate to lose the seat in the double dissolution election in 1951. However, he made many political friends and was able to realise a long-held ambition to serve alongside such Country Party greats as Arthur Fadden and Black Jack McEwen.

His friendships spanned the political spectrum with his forging of a friendship with Ben Chifley—possibly due to their shared experience as clerks and firemen early in their working lives. Ironically, it was Chifley's actions in opposing the restoration of the Commonwealth Bank Board, which had been abolished by him in 1945, that triggered this double dissolution—which was only the second in federal history at that time.

Tom Gilmore continued to play a significant role in agropolitics and served for many years on the North Queensland Tobacco Growers Cooperative in the capacity of member and chairman. He also continued his strong involvement in the organisation he helped establish—the Tobacco Leaf Marketing Board. In 1957, Tom Gilmore entered state politics when he captured the seat of Tablelands. He continued his hard work for the people of the Tablelands and was an effective advocate for the tobacco and sugar industries that underpinned the economy of that region.

I had the honour of knowing Tom Gilmore personally. He was always an excellent fount of knowledge on the detailed workings of the tobacco and sugar industries and was generous in his time in providing me with information about these key industries. He was one of those people who was very highly respected in the National Party. He used to send us little memos when he thought we had done things that warranted his encouragement.

In this 75th year of the National Party, it is very important to acknowledge the people who have made a significant contribution to the fortunes of the National Party—to acknowledge those who have played a role in the shaping of Australia's second oldest political party that developed from unification of farmers organisations in Western Australia in 1913, instigated to oppose the unconscionable trading practices inflicted on them by some merchants, to the truly National Party it is today with a presence in every state.

Lifelong National Party members who have devoted years of service to the party deserve our respect and appreciation. On behalf of the National Party in the Senate, I proffer our respect and appreciation for Tom Gilmore's many years of service to the National Party and extend our sympathy to his son and his family and his friends.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to put on record my appreciation and, I am certain, the appreciation of many of my colleagues in the House of Representatives of the life of Jack Birney, Reginald John Birney, who was the member for Phillip in the House of Representatives from 1975 to 1983 and who died earlier this month. I was fortunate to be able to attend his funeral in a packed church in Randwick with many people who had regarded Jack Birney with affection. People across all political persuasions went to pay their respects to him.

PARA.TAB: He was a `oncer'; in other words, he was one of those elected in 1975 who were derided by some members of the then opposition as people who would only grace the parliament for one term. We were called `oncers' and, as a result, we accepted that appellation with some enthusiasm when we got returned for two and three terms.

Jack Birney survived as a member of parliament until 1983 and was, in fact, a genuine representative of his area. I campaigned with him on several occasions, and it was amazing to see how he seemed to be very friendly with people and known throughout his electorate. If one said that you could not go into a pub in Phillip without most of the people in that pub knowing him, that might give a false impression of his after-hours behaviour.

There was no doubt that he was a true son of that area. He played first grade cricket for Randwick. He was a wicket keeper. I suppose he had some of that mischievous, puckish sense of humour that wicket keepers have, particularly when you are about to face a difficult bowler from the other end and the wicket keeper will give you advice about the easiest way to get out to him. He played on the wing for Randwick Rugby Union Club and was a highly regarded sportsman. I imagine that most of us here in parliament remember him for his dedicated service to the people of Phillip.

Unfortunately, Jack Birney is now the third of those members elected in 1975 to the Liberal benches to have died. Senator John Knight was the first to die, in office. Jim Bradfield has also passed away—and now Jack Birney.

TALK.START.PARA: —When were you elected?

—I was elected in 1975 to the House of Representatives, so I was also alleged to be a `oncer', but I was, after defeat in 1983, elected to the Senate. Every year we people derided as `oncers' who have survived in politics have a dinner, and I know it will be a matter of major disappointment to all of us that at the 20th anniversary dinner, which will take place as near as possible to 11 November this year, we will not have Jack Birney's company.

PARA.TAB: Jack Birney's presence was always an occasion for humour and a touch of practical jokery. He emanated a feeling of genuine friendship and delight at being with his colleagues. I must say that, at our upcoming `oncers' dinner, Jack Birney will be very seriously missed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to pay my respects to the late Reginald John Birney. I must confess to one and all that I have never heard him called Reginald John Birney; he was Jack Birney. I, like my friend Senator Michael Baume, was one of those elected in 1975 who became known as the `oncers'. I think 43 of us were elected at that time. It was an election that changed the face of Australian politics. Jack Birney was an important part of that change. As Senator Baume said, he represented his electorate of Phillip for three parliaments until 1983.

PARA.TAB: I did not have the pleasure of knowing Jack Birney as well as his New South Wales colleagues. He was very much a New South Welshman, but he was also a person who just oozed being Australian. He was a very rugged individual. He was a very laconic chap. He had a terrific sense of humour. He had a very dry sense of humour and a very sharp wit. He was very much a straight shooter. What you saw with Jack Birney was what you got. In that capacity, he was very committed not just to the Liberal Party and its ideals and principles but also to the wellbeing of his constituents, regardless of their political or other allegiances. As I said, he was very much an Australian. He was very committed to Australia's present and its future.

I join with Senator Baume in saying a few brief words in memory of a man who was respected very deeply by all of those who knew him and who were his colleagues in this place. He will be very sadly missed, as Senator Baume said, by those many hundreds of people who attended his funeral and by the much wider community of contacts that he had as well.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 27 July 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the treatment of defence rental subsidies as a fringe benefit by the Department of Social Security (DSS) for family payment purposes:

(1) When is the next projected change to the services group rent scheme, and what effect will that change have on the number of Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel whose family income will be adversely affected by the DSS rental assessment.
(2) How many ADF personnel will be affected by the change to negative gearing arrangements to be introduced in 1995.
(3) Have any discussions taken place or has there been any communication between the department and the DSS in relation to the change to negative gearing.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The next change to the Group Rental Scheme is projected for July 1995 and under current arrangements will not have any negative effect on DSS entitlements of ADF personnel. This is dependent upon the DSS benchmark for `Special Housing' locations remaining at its present level of $80 per week.

(2) The number of ADF personnel affected by the change to negative gearing arrangements to be introduced by the DSS on 1 January 1995 is not known. Negative gearing details are a personal matter between individuals and the Australian Taxation Office.

(3) Discussions were held on a number of issues relating to the DSS changes to assessments for family payments. The effect of the changes were discussed as a whole, including regarding negative gearing. While Government policy integrity was maintained in the income testing arrangements, agreement was reached on the anomalous impact of the treatment of rental subsidy for ADF members.

The Government recognised that the treatment under the Social Security test ran across longstanding ADF policy which treats personnel at the same rank on a similar basis with regard to housing and provides subsidies which standardise housing costs, irrespective of their location. Such an anomalous impact was not seen as being the case for negative gearing.
However, in recognising the home ownership difficulties experienced by members, the ADF has two provisions available to members who own homes and as a result of postings are unable to reside in them.
The two ADF homes loans, the Defence Service Home Loan and the Defence HomeOwner Scheme are fully portable, ie they can be transferred between properties.

Home Purchase or Sale Expense Allowance allows for the reimbursement of some of the unavoidable legal, conveyancing and real estate cost associated with the purchase or sale of residences as a consequence of being posted.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 4 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is Mr Robert Kelly, Food Standards Officer Grade 4, at the Northern Co-operative Meat Company at Casino, NSW, an authorised officer of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS).

(2) (a) Is Mr Kelly a shareholder in the Northern Co-operative Meat Company at Casino, NSW; if so, what is the extent of Mr Kelly's shareholding; and (b) did Mr Kelly declare his pecuniary interest in the Northern Co-operative Meat Company to AQIS.

(3)(a) Did Mr Kelly, or any member of Mr Kelly's family, receive an educational scholarship or any other form of financial benefit from the Northern Co-operative Meat Company; if so, what was the dollar value of the scholarship and/or financial benefit; (b) was the scholarship or financial benefit declared to AQIS; if so, when was the declaration received by AQIS.

(4) What action is taken by the Minister, department or statutory body against companies which give or offer financial benefits to public officials assigned to regulate the activities of such companies.

(5) What action is taken by the Minister, department or statutory body against authorised AQIS officers who accept financial benefits from the companies whose activities they are assigned to regulate.
(6) What action does the Minister, department or statutory body intend to take against the Northern Co-operative Meat Company for offering or giving a financial benefit to Mr Kelly.

(7) What action will be taken against Mr Kelly if he is found to have (a) accepted a financial benefit from the Northern Co-operative Meat Company; and (b) failed to declare his financial interest to his employer.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) (a) Mr Kelly is a member of the Co-operative and holds 100 non-tradeable shares valued at $1 each. Mr Kelly operates a small hobby farm and membership of the Co-operative is required for his cattle to be slaughtered at the Co-operative.
(b) No.

(3) (a) and (b) Mr Kelly's son won the Keith Gooley Scholarship in 1991. The scholarship is an educational award involving an open selection process of eligible candidates by a selection panel which included the retired headmaster of the Casino High School and Mr KF Gooley after whom the scholarship is named. The award was widely publicised in the media and was listed in the Co-operative's annual report for that year.

(4) The precise action to be taken in response to allegations of impropriety against companies regulated by public officials will generally depend upon the nature of such allegations and would therefore have regard to the particular circumstances of the case.

(5) Due process as required under the Public Service Act would be followed. In this context, reference would be made to the AQIS Code of Conduct for Staff and the Guidelines on Official Conduct of Commonwealth Public Servants.
(6) & (7) In the light of the answers to questions 2(a), 3(a) and 3(b), no action is proposed. However, all AQIS staff have been reminded of the requirements of the AQIS Code of Conduct for Staff.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 12 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the corporatisation and competition between Telecom and Optus resulted in record profits for Telecom for the 1993-94 financial year.
(2)(a) Is there a community service obligation required of Optus and Telecom which is either monitored and/or regulated by Telstra; and (b) what is Telstra's total annual expenditure.
(3) Which areas of Tasmania will receive Telecom's proposed expanded digital service by 1995.
(4) What is the timetable for when the rest of Tasmania will be included in the digital system.
(5)(a) What benefits has corporatisation brought to Telecom; (b) how can these benefits be demonstrated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from Telstra:

PARA.TAB: (1) Telstra advises that its profit for the 1993-94 financial year was a record for the company and this was due to a number of factors including: higher demand for telecommunications services stimulated by price reductions for those services since the inception of competition; and Telstra's continuing efforts to control and reduce expenses.

(2)(a) Under the Telecommunications Act 1991, the Minister has designated Telecom as the Universal Service Carrier to provide and maintain the standard telephone service and pay-phones to all Australians, wherever they live or carry on business. As the Universal Service Carrier, Telecom may register a claim with AUSTEL for reimbursement for the cost of meeting the Universal Service Obligation (USO), in loss-making areas, from the other "participating" carriers.

Under the Telecommunications (Universal Service Levy) Act 1991, Telecom, Optus and Vodafone have been declared "participating" telecommunications carriers. This means that they are required to share the costs of meeting the USO—based on their share of timed telecommunications traffic.
AUSTEL is responsible for administering the USO arrangements. AUSTEL is also required to monitor and report to the Minister regarding Telstra's performance in meeting its USO.

(2)(b) AUSTEL gazetted its assessment of the Universal Service Obligation for the 1992/93 financial year on 3 June 1994 (see Table A). The total Net Universal Cost was estimated at $149,170,304. Telstra's contribution towards the costs of providing loss-making services in ensuring universal service during 1992/93 was assessed at $147,714,485. Optus was the only other "participating" carrier during 1992/93 and its contribution was assessed at $1,455,819.
AUSTEL is currently assessing the USO liabilities and entitlements for the 1993/94 financial year.
(3) & (4) Telstra advises me that it proposes that by December 1995, all Tasmanian exchanges will have digital equipment available for those customers who need such access for advanced services.

ANSWER.PARA: Telstra advises that it plans to have all exchanges in Tasmania fully digitised by December 1998.

PARA.TAB: (5)(a) Telstra has advised me that corporatisation and the associated rapid commercialisation of its operations have reaped substantial benefits for the Company through greater attention to outcomes and the relationships between costs and revenues.

(5)(b) Telstra advises that the benefits of corporatisation can be demonstrated by: the Company's ability to generate the necessary cash flows to support its capital expenditure program; its improved customer service; and competitive price structure.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Employment, Education and Training: Mr J. Morgan

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 18 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) On what date was an act of grace payment of $13 963.48 paid by the department (DEET) to Mr Jim Morgan.
(2) Why was the payment made.
(3) Is Mr Morgan an employee of the Department: if so, in what capacity is he employed: if not, in what way is he associated with the department.
(4) Was the car that Mr Morgan loaned to the training program a private vehicle leased in his own name.
(5) From where is the car leased, and what is the exact lease cost per week.
(6) What is the make and model of the car, and in what year was it manufactured.

(7) (a) What regulations exist regarding the loan of private vehicles to DEET programs; (b) are people who loan vehicles to DEET programs given monetary compensation; and (c) under what circumstances are compensation payments made in regard to private vehicles damaged whilst on loan to a departmental program.
(8) How long had Mr Morgan's vehicle been on loan to the department.
(9) What was the exact nature of the DEET training program to which Mr Morgan's vehicle was on loan.
(10) (a) What was the vehicle being used for when the engine trouble occurred; and (b) who was the driver of the vehicle at that time.
(11) (a) What was the nature of the engine trouble which resulted in a "blown motor"; (b) what is the precise and correct description of the problem; and (c) on what date did the vehicle break down.
(12) (a) How many quotes were received for the repair of the vehicle, and what were the names of the suppliers; and (b) what were the exact quotes received for the repair of the vehicle.
(13) What was the exact amount of compensation for lease costs, and what was the exact amount of compensation for restoring the car to operational condition.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) An Act of Grace payment of $13 963.48 was made to Mr Jim Morgan on 18 August 1994.

(2) The payment was made to Mr Morgan as the delegate for act of grace payments considered that in the special circumstances of the case the Commonwealth had an obligation to compensate Mr Morgan for the lease costs from the date of the vehicle breaking down to the date of the decision to make payment.

(3) Mr Morgan is not, and never has been, an employer of DEET. He was contracted to provide transport for Aboriginals as part of a training program, "Woody Weed Control", jointly administered by DEET, the Queensland Department of Lands and a local Aboriginal organisation, Yamba Housing Co-op.
(4) The vehicle was a private vehicle leased in Mr Morgan's name.
(5) The vehicle was leased from Australian Guarantee Corporation Limited (AGC) at a rate of $134.25 per week.
(6) The vehicle is a 1984 model Toyota Landcruiser "troop carrier".

(7) No specific regulations exist regarding the loan of private vehicles to DEET labour market programs. Program providers may provide transport to and from and during courses/work programs. They are responsible for any arrangements which may include use of private vehicles, vehicles owned by the organisation or hiring from a third party. DEET has insurance to cover participants of a number of labour market programs, such as JobTrain, for Public Liability of $5 million and Personal Accident of $100,000. The insurance covers all kinds of transport including all travel by private vehicles.
(8) It was arranged that Mr Morgan's vehicle would be available for use in the course from 27 April 1992 for the six weeks of the course.
(9) The Training program to which Mr Morgan's vehicle was on loan was designed to train Aboriginals in the control of woody weed.
(10) (a) At the time of the vehicle's breakdown it was being used to transport course participants to Elton Downs via Hughenden. (b) The vehicle was being driven by one of the course participants.
(11) (a) (b) The engine trouble was caused by a perished radiator hose which resulted in the engine overheating. (c) This occurred on 27 April 1992.

(12) There were 4 quotes obtained. Three of these ranged between $6,000.00 and $8,286.00. The Department does not have any further details in relation to these quotes. The other quote was for $10,677.73, and was obtained from Horizon Automotives.
(13) The payment represented only the lease costs incurred by Mr Morgan on the vehicle from 26 April 1992 to 29 April 1994. There was no payment made for repair costs associated with the vehicle.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 18 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the cost of computer hardware and software purchased by the department for the 1991-92, 1992-93 and 1993-94 financial years, and what is the breakdown of the projections for the 1994-95 financial year.
(2) What is the average lead time needed between the decision to purchase, the order and the installation of computer hardware and software.
(3) What is the average life of the department's computer hardware and software before it is considered obsolete or superseded by newer, more advanced models.

(4) What funds were returned to the department through selling obsolete computer hardware and software in the 1991-92, 1992-93, 1993-94 financial years, and what is the breakdown of the projections for the 1994-95 financial year.
(5) What was the cost of facsimile machines purchased by the department for the 1991-92, 1992-93, 1993-94 financial years, and what is the breakdown of the projections for the 1994-95 financial year.
(6) What is the average lead time needed between the decision to purchase, the order and the installation of facsimile machines.
(7) What is the average life of the department's facsimile machines before they are considered obsolete or superseded by newer, more advanced models.

(8) What funds were returned to the department through selling obsolete facsimile machines in the 1991-92, 1992-93, 1993-94 financial years, and what is the breakdown of the projections for the 1994-95 financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)-(3) I am advised that the question is not in a form which would make the provision of meaningful replies possible. For example, computer hardware comes in a number of forms and the costs range from small to very large amounts, depending on the hardware in question. It would not be possible, without an expenditure of resources which could not be justified, to extract records of minor purchases.

Similarly, software may at one extreme be very inexpensive, and purchased over the counter, or at the other be very costly and acquired through major tendering processes. Much software may not be purchased at all, in the sense of legal ownership transferring from the producer to the Commonwealth, even though there is Commonwealth expenditure. Concepts like average lead times for decisions to purchase, and average life of hardware and software are imprecise and meaningless in this context.
In the circumstances, I am unable to authorise the expenditure of money and effort involved in trying to assemble the information.

(4)&(8) The department disposes of equipment which it no longer needs in a variety of ways, including by tender, auction and by trade-in, in some instances by item, in others by lot. It is not possible, therefore, to answer this question in its current form.
(6) The department does not keep records in a form which would enable it to answer this question. Machines can be, and usually are, purchased and installed very quickly after the need is identified.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice. on 19 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Since 1 January 1994, how many quarantine protocols for the export of Australian meat products have been, or are in the process of being, renegotiated by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS).
(2) For each of these protocols: (a) what is the importing country; (b) what is the product in question; and (c) what is the nature of the changes made or proposed.

(3) Have any protocols been renegotiated, or proposed for renegotiation, so as to require AQIS or a national body to be the authority conducting export inspection in Australia; if so, what is the nature of these protocols. and do they include protocols for offal and pet food.
(4) How many AQIS officers have been required to travel overseas in order to renegotiate these export protocols.
(5) Which countries have been visited and, in each case, what has been the cost.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service has agreements on conditions for the export of meat, meat products, edible offal and a range of other animal products with over 100 countries. At any time over 50 different items may be in the process of negotiation in order to gain market access to a new country, to add a different product to an existing market, or to renegotiate existing agreements in the light of recent animal or public health developments. In a few cases veterinary agreements, such as one currently being negotiated with the European Union, provide a framework for the conduct of animal product exports to particular countries.

(2) Many countries have been approached by AQIS during 1994 either to gain market access to a new market, to add a different product to an existing market, or to renegotiate existing agreements in the light of recent animal or public health developments. The product range has varied from meat from domestic species to emu and kangaroo skins to feathermeal.

(3) Most countries require certification provided by a Government veterinary service for the majority of animal product imports. Usually certification indicates that specific inspection tasks have been performed or contains statements attesting to the animal and public health status of a particular product. These arrangements typically apply also to pet food and offal.

One of the objectives of the AQIS International Market Access Program, being developed jointly with industry, is to negotiate greater flexibility in the access requirements imposed by other countries, including in relation to the specification of the body in Australia which is to be responsible for inspection and/or certification.

(4)&(5) AQIS staff visit overseas countries as required with the objective of securing favourable conditions for Australia's exports of meat and meat products. AQlS also maintains veterinary counsellors in Brussels and Washington. DC to handle matters arising in the European, North America and Mexican markets. No AQIS officers have travelled overseas specifically in relation to the formal renegotiation of quarantine protocols for the export of Australian meat and meat products since 1 January 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 31 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What control mechanisms does Australia have over spent nuclear fuel from the Republic of Korea which contains Australian uranium and might be reprocessed by a third party such as Russia or France.
(2) What control mechanisms does Australia have over spent nuclear fuel from Japan which contains Australian uranium and might be reprocessed by a third party such as Russia or France.
(3) What control mechanisms does Australia have over spent nuclear fuel from any country which contains Australian uranium and might be reprocessed by a third party such as Russia or France.
(4) What control would Australia have over Korean spent nuclear fuel containing Australian uranium and reprocessed in Korea itself.
(5) What control would Australia have over Japanese spent nuclear fuel containing Australian uranium and reprocessed in Japan itself.
(6) What control would Australia have over spent nuclear fuel containing Australian uranium in any country which is to be reprocessed in that country without being transferred to any other.

(7) (a) What are the agreements between the Australian Government and the following Governments for the latter countries' retransfer of plutonium containing Australian uranium: Germany, Japan, South Korea, North Korea, Belgium, United Kingdom, United States of America, France, Sweden, Finland, Canada, Philippines and Egypt; and

(b) for these same countries, please detail whether each individual consignment of plutonium to be retransferred has to be agreed to by Australia; if not, what are the conditions and terms of the agreements, the ratio of agreement per consignment for each country.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Spent nuclear fuel containing Australian Obligated Nuclear Material (AONM) in the Republic of Korea (ROK) remains subject to the provisions of the Agreement between Australia and the ROK concerning Cooperation in Peaceful Uses of Nuclear Energy and the Transfer of Nuclear Material, which entered into force on 2 May 1979. Under Article VIII of this Agreement, AONM subject to this Agreement may not be reprocessed within the ROK or transferred to a third country without the prior written consent of the Australian Government. Requests for such consent would be considered on a case-by-case basis. No such request has been made in respect of reprocessing.

(2) Spent nuclear fuel containing AONM in Japan remains subject to the provisions of the Agreement between Japan and Australia for Cooperation in the Peaceful Uses of Nuclear Energy, which entered into force on 17 August 1982. Pursuant to Annex B (the Reprocessing Settlement) and the Implementing Arrangement of the Australia/Japan Agreement, Australia exercises its prior consent rights on a programmatic basis so that AONM may be reprocessed in Japan or in an eligible third country as part of a long-term nuclear fuel cycle program. A condition of this programmatic consent is that the facility in which reprocessing will take place is included within the Delineated and Recorded Japanese Nuclear Fuel Cycle Program (DRJNFCP). The DRJNFCP is an integral part of the Australia/Japan Agreement and the provisions of the Implementing Arrangement which outline the DRJNFCP are of treaty status and are published (along with the Agreement) in the Australian Treaty Series (No. 22 of 1982).

Australia has also given programmatic consent to certain retransfers of AONM subject to the Australia/Japan Agreement within the Delineated and Recorded Japanese Nuclear Fuel Cycle Program. In accordance with arrangements established in 1992, Japan notifies Australia of such retransfers, including those of spent fuel containing AONM, approximately six months in advance of each transfer.

(3) Australian uranium may only be exported or retransferred to countries with which Australia has bilateral nuclear safeguards agreements. These agreements lay down stringent conditions for the use and transfer of AONM. Within Australia's network of bilateral nuclear safeguards agreements, five agreements (those with Euratom, France, Japan, Sweden and Switzerland) contain reprocessing settlements, allowing those treaty partners to retransfer and reprocess AONM under a programmatic consent regime based on conditions previously agreed to by the Australian Government. The remainder of Australia's bilateral nuclear safeguards agreements, except that with the Russian Federation, require prior written consent from Australia to be sought on a case-by-case basis before reprocessing of AONM could take place. To date no such consent has been sought. The agreement with the Russian Federation does not provide for reprocessing and only covers toll processing on behalf of third parties at the "front end" of the nuclear fuel cycle; that is conversion, enrichment and fuel fabrication.
(4) Refer to the answer to question (1).
(5) Refer to the answer to question (2).
(6) Refer to the answer to question (3).

(7) (a) and (b) Retransfers of AONM including Australian Obligated Plutonium (AOPu) either in irradiated nuclear fuel assemblies, or as plutonium dioxide powder or as mixed uranium and plutonium oxides (MOX) either in powdered form or in fabricated fuel assemblies, are subject to the conditions contained in the relevant bilateral nuclear safeguards agreements outlined in (1), (2) and (3) above.
Australia does not have a bilateral safeguards agreement with North Korea (DPRK) and therefore that State is not eligible to have AONM exported or retransferred to it.
