TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 8 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 330 (Senate Hansard, 30 August 1993, page 596) and in particular to (6) of that answer which states that the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) treats very seriously all matters which come to RBA's attention relating to prudential supervision of banks: (a) why didn't the Governor of the RBA: (i) agree to a meeting with Mr Alwyn Johnson, as specifically requested by Mr Johnson in his letter to the Governor of 1 July 1991, (ii) reply in writing to Mr Johnson's letter of 1 July 1991, and (iii) formally request Mr Johnson to fully document all his concerns about the Tasmania Bank/Savings Bank of Tasmania so that those concerns could be fully evaluated by the RBA to enable appropriate action to be taken; (b) why did the Governor of the RBA, while ignoring a written request from Mr Johnson for a meeting, proceed to have a meeting with Mr Johnson's superior, Mr Paul Kemp, on 19 September 1991 and a subsequent meeting several weeks later in Hobart; (c) given the significant role that Mr Johnson had played in earlier preventing the Tasmania Bank from collapsing by setting out his concerns in a letter to the then Premier of Tasmania, Mr Michael Field, why didn't the Governor of the RBA take Mr Johnson and the concerns he raised more seriously; and (d) in light of Mr Johnson's summary dismissal from the Tasmania Bank less than 24 hours after talking to the Governor of the RBA about his concerns with the Tasmania Bank/Savings Bank of Tasmania, what should other bank officers do when they have serious concerns about senior executives in their bank and wish to inform the RBA of such concerns without losing their livelihood and careers.

(2) With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 330 (Senate Hansard, 30 August 1993, page 596) and in particular to (7) of that answer which states that the RBA would be very concerned, and would object strongly, if it believed that a bank employee had suffered in any way as a result of providing information in good faith to it: (a) why did the Governor of the RBA not show concern by objecting strongly to the sacking of Mr Johnson, which occurred 2 days after Mr Johnson's letter of 1 July 1991 to the Governor and 1 day after the Governor had phoned Mr Johnson; (b) why hasn't the Governor of the RBA publicly supported Mr Johnson's action of writing to the Tasmanian Premier about the problems of the Tasmania Bank; and (c) in a letter to Mrs Johnson of 20 August 1991, why did the Governor of the RBA state that `the issue of the circumstances of your husband's separation from the bank and the question of possible compensation are matters to be pursued through channels other than the Reserve Bank'.

(3) With reference to a letter of 20 August 1991 from the Governor of the RBA to the wife of Mr Johnson: (a) given that the letter stated `As to the soundness of the banks concerned . . . [it is] a matter which does come within the responsibilities of the Reserve Bank', why was it left to the actions of Mr Johnson to help prevent the collapse of the Tasmania Bank, and what was the RBA doing; and (b) given that the letter stated that the RBA did make `a number of enquiries': (i) what was the point of the RBA making these enquiries when Mr Johnson was not even asked to document all his concerns so that the RBA would have been in a position to fully evaluate them and then take appropriate action, (ii) to whom did the RBA direct its `number of enquiries', and did the RBA in effect make enquiries to the very executives about whom Mr Johnson had very serious concerns, and (iii) why didn't the Governor of the RBA request the Tasmania Bank/Savings Bank of Tasmania to call in external independent auditors after he received Mr Johnson's letter of 1 July 1991, rather then accepting assurances from the very executives about whom Mr Johnson had concerns.

(4) (a) Why did the Governor of the RBA act unethically by breaching the confidence of Mr Johnson when he disclosed to Mr Kemp the contents of the letter written to him by Mr Johnson on 1 July 1991; and (b) in divulging the contents of the letter written by Mr Johnson on 1 July 1991 (marked private and confidential) to Mr Kemp in a telephone conversation on 2 July 1991, did the Governor of the RBA betray the confidence of Mr Johnson and breach section 16 of the Reserve Bank Act 1959; if so, why did the Governor do this.

(5) With reference to a letter written by the Governor of the RBA to the Senate Select Committee on Public Interest Whistleblowing on 29 December 1993: (a) given that depositors were fleeing both the Tasmania Bank and the Savings Bank of Tasmania, as confirmed by official Reserve Bank statistics, and that Mr Kemp was representing the loss of deposits as being confined to the Tasmania Bank, did the Governor of the RBA check on the outflow of deposits from both banks; (b) given that the Governor of the RBA stated that he receives many letters alleging improper practices and given that the RBA has only ever received correspondence from one whistleblower, why wasn't Mr Johnson given a proper hearing, including a meeting with the appropriate authorities; and (c) given that the Governor of the RBA stated that Mr Johnson's concerns were treated very seriously, notwithstanding their generality and that these concerns were not fully detailed in Mr Johnson's letter of 1 July 1991 in which he sought a meeting with the RBA, why didn't the Governor of the RBA formally request Mr Johnson to fully document all his concerns about the Tasmania Bank/Savings Bank of Tasmania so that those concerns could be fully evaluated by the RBA to enable appropriate action to be taken, and why, instead, did the RBA meet with Mr Kemp on 18 September 1991 and again in Hobart several weeks later.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: I have raised the honourable senator's question with the Reserve Bank which provided the following answer.
(1)(a)(i) See reply to Question 1473(1).
(ii) See reply to Question 1473(2).
(iii) See reply to Question 1473(3).
(b) The Governor did not meet with Mr Kemp on 19 September 1991. See also reply to Question 1473(4).
(c) See reply to Question 1473(5) and 1480(1).
(d) See reply to Question 1555(2) and 1480(1).

(2)(a) As stated in the reply to Question 1480(1), it is the Reserve Bank's understanding that Mr Johnson was made redundant following a restructure of the merged Tasmania Bank/Savings Bank of Tasmania; the decision to terminate his services was reached after an independent assessment was made of his suitability for a management position in the merged bank. This understanding is supported by the terms of a settlement reached between Mr Johnson and Trust Bank Tasmania following civil action brought by Mr Johnson for wrongful dismissal; the Reserve Bank has been advised formally that the terms of the settlement specify that:

"(a) Alwyn Johnson and the Bank [ie. Trust Bank] accept that the termination of his employment on the 3rd July, 1991 was as a result of the genuine redundancy of his position and the unavailability of any suitable position to which he could be redeployed.

(b) Alwyn Johnson accepts that in no way was the decision to terminate his employment the result of any vindictiveness or persecution whether as a result of any involvements he may have had in bringing to light information concerning the former Tasmania Bank, or for any other reason."
(b) See reply to Question 1480(2).
(c) See reply to Question 1480(3).
(3)(a) See reply to Question 1480(4).
(b)(i) See reply to Question 1473(3).
(ii) See reply to Question 1480(5)(a) and (b).
(iii) See reply to Question 1555(1).
(4)(a) See reply to Question 1555(3).
(b) See reply to Question 1555(3) and (5).

(5)(a) The Reserve Bank monitors continually changes in the assets and liabilities of banks; Tasmania Bank and the Savings Bank of Tasmania were no exception. In November 1990 Tasmania Bank experienced a moderate outflow of deposits following the announcement by the State Government of significant losses for that bank. The bulk of the outflow occurred in the first two days after the announcement. The Reserve Bank consulted with the bank during this period and was fully aware of the extent of the outflow. The Savings Bank of Tasmania's deposit holdings fell by 6 per cent over the four month period following the State Government's announcement of problems in Tasmania Bank in November 1990. By July 1991 this fall had been all but completely reversed. Changes of this magnitude can be associated with factors such as changes in balance sheet structure and a bank's pricing policy for deposits.
(b) See reply to Question 1473(3).

(c) See reply to Question 1473(3). The Reserve Bank did not meet with Mr Kemp on 18 September 1991. Mr Kemp called on the Head of Bank Supervision Department on 17 September 1991 to update the Reserve Bank on the integration of the Savings Bank of Tasmania and Tasmania Bank. The Governor, while in Hobart on 3 October 1991 to speak at a conference, called upon Mr Kemp to discuss various issues relating to the Trust Bank Tasmania. In carrying out its duties as prudential supervisor of banks, the Reserve Bank routinely meets with senior executives of banks.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 9 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Please provide details of the unit known as Asset Services, including its corporate status, personnel, mode of operation and objectives.
(2) In how many locations in Australia does Asset Services operate as an independent business seeking work in the private sector.
(3) What taxes or dividends does Asset Services pay.
(4) Is it the Minister's intention to continue the operation of this unit.
(5) Does the Government have any plans for privatisation or sale of this unit.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Asset Services is a business unit within the Department of Administrative Services (DAS). Asset Services' core business is as a nationwide maintenance contractor. In that role Asset Services undertakes minor and medium size property improvement projects on existing facilities. Asset Services employs over 2700 people. Asset Services is the largest permanent employer of building industry employees in Australia employing some 2000 blue collar workers and apprentices. Asset Services regards Commonwealth customers as its prime market target.

(2) Asset Services has thirty-five separate operations (profit) centres. Each of these centres may operate from more than one location. In total Asset Services delivers its maintenance services from about ninety locations throughout Australia. Asset Services does not actively seek work from the private sector but does seek to undertake work for state and local governments and including education institutions.

(3) Asset Services meets all normal business costs, including building fees, licences, superannuation, interest paid on borrowings, workers' compensation, insurance, rents, vehicle costs, fringe benefits tax, sales tax where applicable, from the income it earns. When undertaking non-Commonwealth work Asset Services must make allowance for all indirect taxes such as payroll tax, sales tax, customs duty, excise duty, fuel tax, financial institutions duty, bank account debits tax and stamp duty, and pay these costs out of the sales income earned.
Asset Services in 1993-94 paid a $1,000,000 dividend as a result of its trading in 1992-93.
(4) Yes.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 8 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What plans does the Government have for the army base at Puckapunyal in Victoria.
(2) How many, and please identify what, army units have been transferred permanently out of Puckapunyal in the past 5 years.
(3) How many, and please identify what, army units have been brought into Puckapunyal permanently in the past 5 years.
(4) What stage has been reached in the Government's proposal to shift the school of artillery from Sydney to Puckapunyal.
(5) When is any decision expected on this proposal.
(6) How many personnel will be involved in any transfer of the school of artillery to Puckapunyal.
(7) If the school of artillery is not shifted to Puckapunyal, what other army units will be relocated to Puckapunyal.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Defence intends to retain the Puckapunyal Army Base. The base is a major training location for Victorian-based units of the Australian Defence Force and is also utilised by New South Wales-based units.

(2) In financial year 1992-93, 21st Construction Squadron relocated from Puckapunyal to Brisbane. The 1st Armoured Regiment will be progressively relocated to Darwin during 1995 and the move is planned to be complete by December 1995.
(3) None.

(4) The Department of Defence is currently examining options for the relocation of the Artillery Centre, which includes the School of Artillery, from Sydney to either Puckapunyal or Townsville. A recommendation is planned to be submitted to Government early in 1995.
(5) A final decision is expected in 1995.

(6) Approximately 170 military personnel and 200-250 dependants would be involved in any transfer of the Artillery Centre to Puckapunyal. In addition, some 300 students per year will pass through the school.
(7) No other proposals are being considered at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 9 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware of a minute prepared by the Migration and Ethnic Affairs Policy Division dated 6 June 1989 advising the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs that 'DEET officials were most concerned at the impact upon institutions of a sudden cessation of students from the PRC (People's Republic of China)—some institutions would be bankrupted if they were required to refund fees. In addition, programs for students in other countries would have to be cancelled where institutions were dependent for viability upon the PRC component. If cessation results from actions of the PRC Government the industry has no option but to adjust as best it can. If actions by the Australian Government stopped the program the industry would presumably seek some form of redress . . . Deferment of processing avoids the necessity of institutions refunding fees and buys us time to consider this aspect in the light of developments.'.
(2) Was this minute discussed by Cabinet or provided to Cabinet.

(3) Did a number of colleges have financial difficulties as predicted by this minute following the Government's decision to refuse visas to more than 20 000 students from PRC who had paid fees to Australian colleges; if so, are these institutions entitled to some form of redress.

(4) If the decision to cease accepting students from the PRC was made in order to protect the integrity of Australia's immigration program as stated in the answer to question on notice no. 1615 (Senate Hansard, 11 October 1994, page 1615 (sic) 1465), why was this outcome considered more important than the predicted consequence by departmental officials that some colleges would be made bankrupt and given less priority than the integrity and viability of Australian private education colleges which the Minister had enthusiastically encouraged to expand into providing education to PRC students.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am aware that my colleague, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, acknowledged the minute in Hansard on 11 October 1994.

(2) I am advised by my colleague, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs that, after a search of his Department's files, no evidence can be found that the minute was received by the then Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs or considered by the Cabinet of the day.

(3) In 1989, the international students' program was put under severe pressure by the tightening of entry measures in response to a growing overstay rate, particularly by PRC students, as well as the backlog in visa processing created by the closure of the Australian Embassy in Beijing following the events of Tiananmen Square.

At about the same time, a number of English language institutions in Australia closed. In June 1990, the Commonwealth Government wrote to all ELICOS and Special Studies institutions detailing the procedures and guidelines to be followed if they wished to request provision of temporary financial assistance to cover short-term cashflow problems but not to compensate for any loss of profits. Those institutions which had a solid financial base, recruited students from several countries and, therefore, were not largely dependent upon the PRC market, were able to adjust to the visa changes and sustain viable businesses which have contributed to the further development of the export education industry. (ELICOS figures indicate that there was a 50 percent increase in enrolments in that sector between 1993 and 1994.)

(4) The Government tightened global entry criteria for ELICOS and other non-formal courses of less than twelve months' duration in 1989 when it became apparent that large numbers of students were remaining in Australia after completion of their studies or were using educational programs, especially ELICOS, as a means of back door migration.

The new visa processing arrangements were introduced in all countries to ensure that bona fide student applications for study in Australia were processed speedily. The new criteria for the entry of genuine students were implemented to enhance Australia's multi-million dollar export education industry and to uphold the integrity of Australia's immigration policy.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 15 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984:
(1) Does Treasury preside over the Act.
(2) What section of Treasury administers the licensing, conduct and oversighting of the Act.
(3) What licences or accreditations exist for those persons, agents or brokers operating under the Act.

(4) Is a Mr Andrew Raymond Gordon Fraser a Member of the Legislative Assembly of New South Wales, a person licensed, accredited or registered to operate under the Act; if not, was Mr Fraser at any time licensed, accredited or registered to operate under any section of the Act; if so, when did he cease to be licensed, accredited or registered to operate under that Act, and for what reasons.
(5) Was Mr Fraser operating within the insurance industry under any other Act that applied to that industry, if any, prior to the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984.

(6) Have there ever been any complaints against Mr Fraser whilst he was, or was not, licensed, accredited or registered under the Act; if so: (a) what action, if any, was taken about the complaints; and (b) what was the result of such action.

(7) Has Mr Fraser ever been an agent on behalf of a company where there is an agreement between him and that company to act as an agent; if so: (a) what was the agency; (b) what was the insurance company with which he had the agency; (c) when did that agency cease; and (d) what was the reason for the cessation of such agency.

(3) The Act provides, amongst other things, for the annual registration of life and general insurance brokers, and agents of foreign insurers. It does not provide for the licensing or accreditation of agents.
(4) A search of the ISC data base has not revealed Mr Fraser as having been registered as a broker, or a director of a registered broker.
(5) Unknown.
(6) The Government does not believe it is appropriate to comment on whether or not complaints have been made about individual citizens.
(7) Unknown
(8) Unknown

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 15 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What were the options for the use of HMAS Derwent after being decommissioned.
(2) Why was the decision made to conduct blasting tests on HMAS Derwent.
(3) How was the decision made to conduct blasting tests on HMAS Derwent.
(4)(a) Was selling parts of HMAS Derwent for scrap an option considered by the Government and (b) was this option viable, if so, why; if not, why not.
(5) Was there a market for scrap from HMAS Derwent at the time the options were considered.
(6) To which countries and fleets could Australia have sold parts of HMAS Derwent for scrap, and approximately how much money would Australia have earned.

(7) Was there an environmental impact assessment undertaken to assess the effects of blasting HMAS Derwent with a guided missile; if so, please provide the Senate with the report of the impacts to the environment, if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The options for the disposal of the former HMAS Derwent after being decommissioned on 8 August this year were limited to sale for scrap, or sinking. This was as a result of a series of destructive tests planned by the Defence Science and Technology Organisation. The sale for scrap option eventually became non-viable because of the extent of the damage to the ship.

(2) The decision to carry out a series of destructive tests on the Derwent hulk was made because the planned disposal date for the Derwent coincided with the Defence Science and Technology proposal to conduct the Ship Survivability Enhancement Program. The program involves not only blasting tests but also fire, smoke, fragmentation and limpet mine damage.

(3) The most important asset of the Royal Australian Navy is its personnel. Both the Falklands and the Gulf conflicts showed that the survivability of the ships themselves is critical for the survivability of the crews. In both these conflicts, little-understood secondary effects of weapon strikes significantly exacerbated the effects of the initial `hit'. In 1991, the Navy first proposed a series of destructive tests on a recently de-commissioned warship to validate computer models and engineering algorithms with a view to improving the combat survivability of Australian warships. As a result, the Defence Science and Technology Organisation developed the series of destructive experiments currently being performed on the Derwent hulk to collect data to assist the Navy to meet that goal.
(4)(a) A variety of disposal options were considered for HMAS Derwent and this included sale as scrap.

(b) The option to sell Derwent as scrap was not considered viable as the damage inflicted by the Ship Survivability Enhancement Program will more than likely render the hulk unsafe to undertake a long-term tow on the open ocean to the ship-breakers yards in mainland China or the Indian Sub-Continent.
(5) There is always a market for scrap in any configuration and at any time.

(6) Equipment required by the Navy has been removed from the Derwent with some removed for sale and/or exhibit purposes by community groups. Sale of ships of this nature and demolition markets are basically confined to mainland China which is paying in the region of $US157—160 per light displacement ton delivered to the Shanghai area under its own power. Ships under 6000 tons light weight are basically not attractive and require payment of an import tariff of 6 percent. Prices quoted from the Indian Sub-Continent are somewhat higher at approximately $US 170—187 per light displacement ton dependent on type and time of delivery.

It is an accepted fact that sales to China are on a more reliable cash basis in contrast to the Indian Sub-Continent which requires the sellers to negotiate on the basis of letters of credit payment after the ship has been beached at its point of delivery.
On the above quotes it is estimated that the Derwent would attract in the vicinity of $US 330K—350K in revenue if sold for scrap value less costs associated with this option, ie. delivery.

(7) Copies of a Feasibility Study and a Development Plan undertaken by the Navy prior to the experimental program are provided. These reports consider the environmental impact of the experimental program as well as a Risk Management Plan. These reports were examined and approved by both the Commonwealth and West Australian Environment Protection Authorities. The Navy has consulted with local, state and federal authorities at each stage of development of this plan. The experiments will be completed on 2 December 1994 and have been extremely successful, providing much valuable scientific data and very realistic training opportunities for the Navy fire-fighting and damage control teams.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 16 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the answer to a question without notice asked on 16 November 1994 regarding the American ultra-right wing extremist Lyndon La Rouche, Jr, and the visit on a tourist visa by Mr Webster Tarpley, an associate and advocate of Mr La Rouche:

(1) Is the Minister aware that: (a) the Australian arm of the La Rouche movement, the Citizens Electoral Councils of Australia, has stated that one of the purposes of Mr Tarpley's visit to Australia was to launch a magazine called The Coming Fall of the House of Windsor; (b) the magazine, of which Mr La Rouche is listed as the founder and contributing editor, contains articles accusing the British Royal Family of heading a world wide criminal organisation responsible for mass genocide throughout the world; (c) Mr Tarpley is a member of the editorial board of the magazine; and (d) the Citizens Electoral Councils of Australia is actively endorsing and promoting the distribution of the magazine.
(2) Was the Citizens Electoral Councils of Australia or any individual representing the CEC involved in obtaining a tourist visa for Mr Tarpley.
(3) During his visit, was Mr Tarpley involved in promotion of the La Rouche magazine or any other political activity; if so, what action has been taken, or can be taken, by the department.

(4) Would a person on a tourist visa be in breach of their visa regulations if they assisted, by active involvement or advice, in helping political organisations disrupt the legitimate business of visiting overseas dignitaries.
(5) Do current visa regulations contain provision to prevent visitors to Australia from making statements, or spreading material, promoting racial hatred and vilification.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Neither the Citizens Electoral Councils, its editorial board nor its publications have previously come to the notice of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.
(2) No, the Citizens Electoral Councils was not involved in Mr Tarpley's visa application.

(3) As reported in the press, Mr Tarpley has addressed the National Press Club. If he does become involved in activities of a political or promotional nature there may be grounds to consider cancellation of his visa. This will depend upon the degree and nature of the activities.
(4) People on tourist visas are expected to undertake activities of a recreational nature. Activities of the nature you mentioned may constitute grounds for cancelling a visa.

(5) The Migration Act and Regulations contain provision to refuse entry to Australia to, or cancel the visa of, any visitor likely to vilify a segment of the Australian community, incite discord in the Australian community or a segment of it, or become involved in activities that are disruptive or threaten harm to the community.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 21 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Australian Living Standards Study which was commissioned in 1991:
(1) How many reports have been produced from this commission.
(2) Is the study completed and has a final report been produced; if so, please provide a copy; if not, why not.
(3) Please supply a copy of the terms of references for the study.
(4) What have been the major findings of the study to date.
(5) Over what period has the study continued, and why has it taken this amount of time for a final report to be produced.
(6) What are the costs involved in producing the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Twelve.

(2) All topic reports required under contract have been completed. A final overview report of the Australian Living Standards Study (ALSS) project is due to be submitted to the Department of Human Services and Health by the end of the year.
(3) A copy of the original contract dated 7 December 1990, with amendments on 1 March 1991 and 30 June 1992 has been provided to the honourable senator.
(4) The reports have only recently been received and have not been analysed in sufficient detail to offer a specific summary, however, there are two general findings:

there are different advantages and disadvantages which attach to living in different types of areas—inner, middle and outer metropolitan and rural areas. It must be noted that such major costs as housing are greater in inner metropolitan areas and generally less the further one lives from the centre. Also, the further one gets from the centre, access to public transport diminishes, reliance on the private automobile increases, and distances from services and amenities are often greater.

For those in outer metropolitan and rural areas, disadvantage to those on lower incomes is reported as more significant than disadvantage arising out of the distance from their homes to essential private and community services.

(5) Initial specific-purpose funding by the Commonwealth was agreed in December 1990. Some questionnaire development—including broad consultation with Government agencies, service providers, other researchers—had preceded the agreement for this supplementary funding while further questionnaire design, printing and training of fieldwork supervisors took place in 1991. Fieldwork commenced in 1991. Changes in personnel within Australian Institute of Family Studies and the re-orientation from locality to issue based report delayed work on the project.
The contracted reports were completed progressively, with the final six rural topic reports delivered on 31 October 1994.
(6) A specific-purpose grant of $1.08 million was provided by the Commonwealth for the Australian Living Standards Study.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 19 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware of the inability of many home owners and business proprietors in the Torres Strait to obtain adequate general insurance cover.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 21 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the Government's response to a recent report by Amnesty International which details a number of human rights concerns in Hong Kong.
(2) Has it been possible to confirm recent reports suggesting that China intends to dismantle Hong Kong's democratic institutions and the reforms encompassed in Governor Patten's reform proposals.

(3) What representations has Australia been making to China on the need to maintain democratic institutions in Hong Kong as well as respecting international human rights standards once the colony is transferred to Chinese sovereignty in 1997.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) My Department has studied the Amnesty International report and noted its concerns about human rights in Hong Kong.

We are aware of the debate over how to strengthen institutions to promote and protect human rights in the Territory. This debate should not obscure the fact that Hong Kong is one of the freest societies in the region, where the rule of law operates effectively.

The Australian Government considers that adequate provision has been made to safeguard human rights in The Hong Kong Special Administrative Region after 1 July 1997 under the 1984 Sino-British Joint Declaration, which has international treaty status and has been registered with The United Nations. We consider that the two sovereign powers, which are signatories to the Joint Declaration, have an obligation to ensure that its provisions are fully implemented after the transfer of sovereignty from Britain to China in 1997, including, in particular, the provisions guaranteeing independent judicial power, and rights and freedoms, including those of the person, of speech, of the press, of assembly, of association, of travel, of movement, of correspondence, of strike, of choice of occupation, of academic research and of religious belief ensured by law.

We also hope that China will continue to report to the UN annually on human rights and civil liberties in Hong Kong, under the terms of the two human rights covenants, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR) and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights (ICESCR), which extend to Hong Kong, as mentioned in Annex One of the Joint Declaration.

(2) China has declared its intention to dismantle the three-tier political structure in Hong Kong as it presently stands, having been modified through legislation passed by Hong Kong's Legislative Council in June this year, and to create an interim legislature in 1997 to ensure continuity in laws, to handle urgent business and to arrange elections for a permanent legislature. We hope that whatever arrangements are made for the future Hong Kong Special Administrative Region are democratic and transparent and in accordance with the wishes and interests of the Hong Kong people. The spirit of the Joint Declaration and China's 1990 Basic Law in fact encourages building an even more accountable and representative government in Hong Kong over time. China has enshrined these guarantees in its own domestic laws regarding Hong Kong, i.e. the 1990 Basic Law.

(3) Australia monitors developments in Hong Kong closely and will continue to do so during the transition period. We have an active dialogue with both sovereign powers on matters relating to Hong Kong and our interests in the Territory. I myself have raised Australian concerns about human rights and political reform issues with senior British and Chinese representatives, as have my Ministerial colleagues and senior Australian officials. China has given assurances that it will meet its obligations under the Joint Declaration.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Regional Development, upon notice, on 23 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the purpose of the video production by Parham Media Productions, at a cost of $63 000 for the Local Government and Urban Development, Office of Local Government.
(2) What are the innovation awards.
(3) Who will utilise the video.
(4) How many copies of the video were produced.
(5) What is the life expectancy of the video, for example, can it be used for the next round of innovation awards.
(6) What other promotional material was produced for the innovation awards.
(7) What was the cost of this promotional material.
(8) What was the cost of distributing the promotional material.
(9) What was the response to the promotional material.
(10) When were the awards held and where.
(11) What costs were associated with the presentation of the awards.
(12) What course of action will be taken in relation to promotional videos in 1995 or the next time the awards are to be presented.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The purpose of the video is to promote the National Awards for Innovation in Local Government, increase the number of entries and enhance the quality of applications.

(2) The National Awards for Innovation in Local Government is a system of awards designed to recognise and reward innovative practices in Local Government. An important aspect of the Awards is the dissemination of information about such practices throughout Local Government. They have been conducted since 1986.

(3) We expect that the video would be useful to a number of organisations such as Local Government authorities throughout Australia, State Local Government Associations and Departments, current and prospective sponsors, and my Department.

(9) In 1993-94, over 230 entries were received in eight categories.
(10) Last year, 1993-94, the Awards were held in Canberra at the National Convention Centre on Tuesday 17 May 1994.

(11) The Institute of Municipal Management administer the Awards for $75,000pa on behalf of my Department. In addition, there is a salary component for the time of Departmental officers who are involved in the Awards. This involvement is of a limited nature.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the cost of advertising the new twenty dollar note?
(2) What is the purpose of this advertising?
(3) What is the breakdown of the advertising budget?
(4) Who approved the budget for the advertising campaign?
(5) Was the advertising campaign put to tender; if so, what was the outline of the tender?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Reserve Bank has spent (approximately) $1 million in educating the public about the new twenty dollar note.

(2) Each time the Bank issues a new note, it has an obligation to ensure that the public becomes quickly familiar with the note, especially the security features. This allows the note to be immediately accepted in transactions. It also helps to discourage counterfeiters from taking advantage of the public while the note is unfamiliar. The Bank's approach on this occasion was no different from the past.

(3) A little over half of the budget was spent on television, and a little over a quarter on press advertising; most of the remainder was for printed material for distribution through banks and other high volume cash-handlers.
(4) The budget for the advertising campaign was approved by the Governor of the Reserve Bank, in accordance with the Bank's standard financial management procedures.
(5) The advertising campaign was put to tender. In broad terms, prospective tenderers were asked to provide proposals to:
create a wide and general awareness that a new twenty dollar polymer note was to be issued;
describe the new twenty dollar polymer note and its special security features;
raise the level of awareness as to why polymer notes are being introduced; and
make best use of the budget which the Bank had allocated to the task through a multi-media approach (being mindful of the Bank's need to be careful and prudent in use of public funds).

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Employment, Education and Training: Acting Courses

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 23 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many acting courses, covering film, television and stage, have been purchased by the department through the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES).
(2) What is the cost of these acting courses for the 1992-93 and 1993-94 financial years and the 1994-95 financial year to date.
(3) How many unemployed clients of the CES, who have taken part in one of these acting courses, have successfully gained employment within this field.
(4) What criteria does the unemployed client have to fulfil to be placed on one of the aforementioned acting courses.
(5) What organisations provide the courses concerned.
(6) How many acting positions have been filled by the CES.
(7) What other costs have been accrued in providing the aforementioned acting courses.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1), (2), (3), (5) and (7) The Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) purchases training for jobseekers by buying entire courses or individual training places on training providers' existing courses. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Tourism, upon notice, on 23 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) At a cost of $100 000, what type of services were provided by Econsult Australia concerning ecotourism.
(2) At a cost of $199 800, what type of services were provided by Social Change Media concerning ecotourism.
(3) What are the results of these two consultancies.
(4) How will the results of these two consultancies be utilised.
(5) How long did each consultancy take to complete.
(6) What other costs have been borne by the department in relation to ecotourism, including the recent ecotourism conference in Hobart.
(7) What information was gained by these two consultancies.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Tourism has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Ecotourism Business Development consultancy currently being undertaken by Econsult Australia is expected to provide the following services:
(a) a skills audit identifying core ecotourism business skill needs and current training provisions;
(b) a survey review of current training available and development of `best practice' training/curricula guidelines;
(c) identification of existing ecotourism organisation networks, regional business development networks and cross links between the two and development of guidelines for more successful networks; and
(d) development of a training and support strategy and an implementation program.
(2) The Ecotourism Education consultancy currently being undertaken by Social Change Media is expected to provide the following services:
(a) a National Ecotourism Education Strategy incorporating a national needs analysis of ecotourism target groups;
(b) a comprehensive inventory of ecotourism education materials and training courses for publishing as a resource guide; and
(c) materials and detailed strategy for a targeted awareness campaign.

(3), (5) and (7). Neither consultancy has yet been completed. Information gained by the two consultancies will be made available following the receipt of final reports for these consultancies, which are due with the Department of Tourism in June 1995.
(4) The results of the two consultancies will be utilised as follows:
(a) Ecotourism Business Development—to improve the level of business skills among ecotourism operators.

(b) Ecotourism Education—to promote an increased awareness and application of the principles and practices of ecotourism to a range of audiences including the media, the tourism industry, education and training bodies and consumers.

(6) The Government released its National Ecotourism Strategy in March 1994 and $10 million has been provided over four years from 1993-94, for programs to help implement the Strategy through the National Ecotourism Program.

A $40,000 grant was provided under the 1993-94 round of the National Ecotourism Program (Conferences and Workshops component) to the Tasmanian Department of Tourism, Sport and Recreation to assist with hosting the 1994 World Congress on Adventure Travel and Ecotourism held in Hobart on 7-10 November 1994. This funding was primarily used for:
a Seminar on Sustainable Design and Ecotourism which was held in conjunction with the World Congress; and
the preparation of a Guide to Innovative Technology for Sustainable Tourism which provided all delegates with a take-home reference to available sustainable technology.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 23 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the Commonwealth supply funding for the Australian Country Information Service (ACIS) with sole responsibility for administration resting with local government, whether councils or governing committees.

(2) What monitoring and control of ACIS programs does the Commonwealth undertake to ensure that ACIS projects and personnel are operating effectively, and that isolated communities are getting value for money spent.
(3) Is the Minister aware that the ACIS information officer on King Island has been dismissed and that no reasons have been given for her dismissal.
(4) Will the circumstances surrounding her dismissal be investigated.
(5) Is the Minister aware that reports of the officer concerned show that she has been highly regarded by ACIS in Canberra and by her local community for the work she has done.
(6) What implications does this dismissal have for the continued funding for the ACIS position on King Island and other similar isolated communities.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. The Government does fund the Australian Country Information Service (ACIS). The Grantee has the responsibility for the employment of the facilitator and the administration of the grant. The Commonwealth ensures that there is adherence to the terms of the agreement.

(2) A contract between the Commonwealth and the grantee sets out the terms of the agreement and the monitoring and reporting arrangements. The Agreement requires that the grantee supply an audited, annual financial statement, monthly statistics on the number and type of contacts, surveys the community to identify the effectiveness of the service and submits an evaluation report. An annual training conference is held in Canberra which is attended by the ACIS facilitators. These initiatives ensure the involved communities are serviced effectively and efficiently.
(3) The Commonwealth has been informed that the ACIS facilitator has been replaced and that the services of the previous occupant had been terminated.
(4) The employment of the facilitator is the responsibility of the grantee and the Commonwealth is not involved in the appointment or dismissal of these employees.
(5) The Commonwealth has been satisfied with the King Island ACIS service and delivery.
(6) None.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 28 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Have Government advisers consistently under-estimated the costs of coal-fired power generation and over-estimated the costs of renewable energy technology such as solar energy and windpower.

(2) Is it a fact that when the true cost of transmitting power to some rural communities is included, and the cost of construction and maintenance of sub-stations and high tension lines is fully accounted for, alternative energy sources such as solar, wind and natural gas fuel cell electricity generation are actually quite competitive on a cost per kW/hour basis and are likely to become more so.

(3) What response does the Minister have to statements by two consultants to the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories at a public briefing on 24 November 1994 that "there has been a huge amount of disinformation" and "10 years of appalling advice" provided to both State and Federal decision makers with regard to greenhouse and energy issues.
(4) Has the United States of America actually experienced considerable economic benefit as a result of implementing energy efficiency measures in recent years.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (2) Yes. There are several instances where rural properties have been connected to the grid when renewable energy power supply systems would have been a cost effective alternative. This is particularly so where rural properties are far removed from the nearest grid lines and/or the electricity requirements of properties are small. For example, the University of New South Wales has estimated that, in many instances, renewable energy power supply systems could represent an economically viable alternative to grid connection for rural households faced with a grid connection cost of more than $15,000. Cost estimates of this nature underpin the Renewable Energy Promotion Program through which the Government has provided $3 million over the past three years to promote the use of commercially viable renewable energy technologies, particularly in rural and remote areas of Australia. Approximately 80 renewable energy displays which will be available for public inspection are being established throughout Australia.

(3) I am not aware of the context in which these specific statements were purported to have been made. However, I understand that they may relate to the launch of a book by journalist Gavin Gilchrist entitled "The Big Switch—clean energy for the twenty first century". The book contains considerable criticism of officers of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. Examination of these criticisms (see, for example, the Hansard report on the Alternative Energy Seminar hosted by the House of Representatives Standing Committee for Long Term Strategies on 28 September 1992) shows that these officers have been selectively quoted. This results in a misleading impression that these officers were not providing balanced advice on the prospects for using renewable energy technologies in Australia.

(4) Over the past decade, the US Federal and State Governments have undertaken major energy efficiency programs. They have also put in place regulations for electricity utilities to invest in energy efficiency through what is commonly known as demand side management (DSM) programs. Although the US has benefited economically from implementing many of these measures, recent studies suggest that several of the utility-DSM measures were far from economically viable on their own account. The results of these studies has led to a thorough re-examination of the cost effectiveness of DSM measures in the US, particularly compared with the cost-effectiveness and consequent benefits to the overall economy of government run energy-efficient programs.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the fact that the annual report for the Australian Defence Industries (ADI) was tabled in the Senate on 16 November 1994, one day after the estimates hearings of the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee began:
(1) When was the ADI annual report printed.
(2) When was the ADI annual report made available to the Minister.
(3) Why did the Minister not arrange for the ADI annual report to be tabled prior to the relevant estimates hearings.
(4) Will the Minister provide an undertaking that Government business enterprise and statutory authority annual reports will all be tabled in the Senate prior to estimates hearings.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Not all copies of the Company's annual report were produced in a single print run. Initially, only a small quantity of advance copies required for the Annual General Meeting (AGM) of 31 October 1994 was produced. Subsequently, bulk printing of additional copies of the report was arranged by ADI.

(2) One advance copy of the Company's annual report was provided to me on 17 October 1994 in my capacity as the shareholder on behalf of the Commonwealth. Fourteen days is the minimum period of notice required to be given under the Corporations Law and Company's Articles of Association.

(3) The Department of Defence received the 366 copies of ADI's annual report for tabling purposes on Friday, 11 November 1994, and made arrangements with the Tabling Office to table the report on 16 November. A submission seeking my approval to tabling the annual report was prepared on 14 November and approved on that day. The annual reports were delivered to the Tabling Office on 15 November.

(4) It is not possible to give an unequivocal undertaking that annual reports will be tabled to coincide with the Senate Legislative Committee hearings. The requirements and processes leading to the preparation of annual reports are determined by the Corporations Law and the Commonwealth guidelines for Government Business Enterprise. Nevertheless, every effort will be made to table the annual reports as soon as possible after the respective AGMs.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 30 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) What is the level of funding provided by the Commonwealth Government for Aboriginal health worker accredited training; and (b) what is the breakdown of that funding for each State or Territory.

(2) Has the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Corporation for Health Education and Training (ATSICHET) received any funding for health worker training; if not, why have ATSICHET's submissions been unsuccessful.

(3)(a) What is the total level of funding for training provided by the Commonwealth to the Northern Territory; (b) how much of this mainstream training funding is allocated to Batchelor College; and (c) how much funding does the Department directly provide to Batchelor College in the Northern Territory without going through the Northern Territory Government.
(4) How much funding does the Department directly provide to Aboriginal medical services for training purposes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) The Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET), provides assistance for Aboriginal health worker accredited training in two ways. Through the Aboriginal Education Strategic Initiatives Program (AESIP), DEET provided a total of $5,265,383 for the period 1990 to 1994. Assistance is also provided through its labour market programs. However, information on assistance provided under labour market programs is not

ANSWER.PARA: readily available and to collect and assemble the information required to answer the honourable Senator's question would be a major task. I am not prepared to authorise the resources involved in assembling this information solely for the purpose of answering the honourable Senator's question. (b) The breakdown of the AESIP funding for the period 1990 to 1994 is Queensland $1,437,203, Western Australia $330,444, Tasmania $15,000 and Northern Territory $3,482,736.

PARA.TAB: (2) ATSICHET has not received any funding for health worker training under AESIP. In late September 1994 ATSICHET submitted a proposal for funding of health worker training. That proposal did not set out the details of the assistance that ATSICHET was seeking from the Commonwealth and DEET has been undertaking discussions with ATSICHET in an attempt to finalise the details of their requirements. However, regardless of the outcomes of those discussions it will not be possible to provide supplementary AESIP funding for the 1995 academic year as all funds have been allocated.

(3)(a) Funding for training provided by the Commonwealth to the Northern Territory is provided from three sources: Vocational Education and Training assistance is provided to States and Territories through the Australian National Training Authority (ANTA) which is responsible for the actual allocation. In 1994 gross funding from the Commonwealth to the Northern Territory, provided through ANTA, will total $9,990,455. Second, assistance may be provided under labour market programs. The allocation to DEET's Northern Australia Area for the training component of labour market programs in 1994/95 is $18,255,000. Third, assistance is provided through AESIP and the Northern Territory will receive $18,231,950 in 1994. (b) and (c) Allocation of ANTA funding to Batchelor College is a matter for the Northern Territory Education and Training Authority. Direct funding to Batchelor College that can be identified for the period 1990/91 until 1993/94 totals $240,435 under labour market programs. During the same period an amount of $3,482,736 under AESIP was paid as supplementary assistance to Batchelor College through the Northern Territory Department of Education.

(4) Information on the level of funding the Department provides directly to Aboriginal medical services for training purposes is not readily available. To collect and assemble the information required to answer the honourable Senator's question would be a major task. I am not prepared to authorise the resources involved in assembling this information solely for the purpose of answering the honourable senator's question.
